Title: Paying for Rubbish: Does It Work?
In many places, families do not pay directly for the rubbish they throw away. They pay through local taxes, but a family that throws away a lot of rubbish pays the same as a family that throws away a little. This can be a problem because more rubbish means more work and costs for the city.
One idea is to make families pay for each bag of rubbish. This might make them throw away less and recycle more. Some cities in America tried this. They sold stickers for rubbish bags, and only bags with stickers were collected.
In Charlottesville, Virginia, people had to pay 80 cents for each bag. The number of bags went down by 37%, but people just put more rubbish in each bag. The weight of rubbish only went down by 14%. Some people even dumped rubbish illegally to avoid paying.
Recycling went up by 15%, but many people were already recycling before the new rule. The study found that raising the price of stickers did not reduce rubbish by much. A 10% increase in price only reduced rubbish by 0.3%.
The study suggests that other things, like income and education, might affect how much rubbish people throw away. Richer towns throw away more rubbish and recycle less because people have less time.
Charging for rubbish is not a bad idea, but it is complicated. Simple solutions can have unexpected results, and sometimes we need detailed studies to understand them.

Theodore Zeldin talks about how our work life might change. Do you feel respected and appreciated at work? Just having a successful career is not enough anymore. Many people feel their jobs are not valued or understood. Even famous people can feel unhappy. Loving your job used to be special, but now you need to think about how your job affects you as a person. Does it help your mind, character, and relationships? This is important. If your job makes you boring or too busy to learn new things, then no amount of money or status can make up for that. 
Zeldin wants to find out how work can help us grow as people, not just be a way to make money. Work should be a good part of life, helping us find new talents and meet different people. But this doesn't mean getting rid of unemployment is the only goal. As people get more educated, they want jobs that are interesting and useful. Work should be like a piece of art, with a happy person at the center.
Many jobs, like doctors and accountants, are not as appealing as they used to be. Doctors are often stressed, and accountants worry about their job's ethics. Architects can't always be creative, and managers are stuck in bureaucracy. Many workers feel their values don't match their company's values.
Zeldin is studying different jobs to see how they affect people. He looks at what makes people happy and respected. He wants to find better ways for people to earn a living. It's not just about making money; it's about finding the right people to work with and feeling alive at work.
For example, hotel workers often have low pay and long hours, but they have a lot of potential. Hotels could be more than just places to sleep; they could be cultural centers where people from different countries meet and learn from each other. Hotel staff could use their skills and knowledge more, but they are often limited by the focus on profit.
Zeldin believes work is about relationships. People want to be independent and choose their jobs and colleagues. They need to communicate well with others, even if they are from different fields. Good conversation is important because it helps people understand each other and creates respect. Every time we have a meaningful conversation, the world changes a little bit.

**Broadcasting: The Social Shaping of a Technology**
The word 'broadcasting' originally meant spreading seeds by hand. It is a metaphor for planned growth and success. Broadcasting involves central resources that spread information. This text explores why new technology, like TV, was organized in a way that fits this metaphor. 
TV is similar to other communication tools like the telegraph and telephone. But, unlike them, TV was seen as a one-way, mass medium from the start. This fit the way modern societies were organized. Some people tried different ways to use TV, but these were just experiments.
In the 1930s, some people in Britain tried to use TV like a telephone. Magazines showed how to build TV equipment. But big companies set standards that stopped these small experiments. So, TV did not become a two-way communication tool.
In the USA, TV was first used in theaters and was seen as a competitor to movies. In Britain and Germany, people watched TV in public places. The idea of two-way TV was not popular, and public TV viewing was more common.
Manufacturers wanted to sell TVs for home use. As people earned more money, they could buy TVs for entertainment at home. This happened in many Western countries and is now happening worldwide.
Broadcasting became important for governments to share information with everyone. It helped create a sense of community in countries. Broadcasting was seen as a way to give people equal access to information and participate in society.
Today, TV is changing, and the idea of broadcasting might change too. Broadcasting might be seen as a way of using technology during a certain time in history.

**Clutter**
Sometimes, it feels like no matter how many things you have, you never feel safe. It's normal to want a home that meets your needs, but sometimes wanting more things can get out of control. Modern ads are made to make us feel insecure. They tell us, "If you don't have this, you are not good enough." To see how much ads affect you, try not to read any billboards next time you walk down the street. These expensive ads make us want to buy things without us even knowing it. We see them everywhere - on TV, radio, newspapers, magazines, posters, t-shirts, the internet - all telling us to buy more.
**Caves**
Scientists and researchers around the world study caves. They want to know how caves started, how water moves in them, and what lives inside them. Caves are a small but interesting part of nature. They make us curious and we want to learn more about them. Many people have studied caves for a long time, especially in places where caves are important to our lives. But visiting caves can be hard because you need to be fit. So, both scientists and people who like to explore caves for fun study them together.
**Weather Watch**
A long time ago, people watched the weather with just their eyes and senses. This helped start the science of weather, called meteorology. Today, we use satellites and computers to get weather information quickly. Computers can solve hard math problems very fast. Meteorology uses big words that are hard to understand for most people. But simple weather knowledge is still important. Human experience helps turn computer data into weather forecasts. People can still notice things about the weather that help scientists understand it better.

**Music and Theatre**
Not long ago, I thought opera was mostly about theatre. But after working at an opera house, I learned that music is the most important part of opera. In theatre, the words and the actors are the main focus. The actors and the audience usually speak the same language. 
At a music concert or opera, many people, like me, might not know much about music. Some might feel embarrassed about this, but most are amazed by the performers' skills. Watching a great musician is like watching athletes; we see how much better they are than us. 
Theatre audiences have different expectations. They might not understand an actor's skill and often think they could do it too. They are not usually impressed by long speeches, though they often ask actors, "How do you remember all those lines?" 
This doesn't mean theatre audiences are easier to please. Many people go to both theatre and music events. In theatre, audiences and performers are more equal, no matter how difficult the play is. 
Can music learn from theatre? I think so. Music performances are full of emotion and can be like theatre. But music events often feel formal, with strict dress codes and a focus on conductors and soloists. This can make the audience feel less important. 
Sometimes, music audiences clap at the wrong times, which can interrupt the performance. But many things are being done to make music more welcoming. For example, Jonathan Dove's opera "In Search of Angels" was performed in different places, making it a special experience for the audience. 
I wish music had more of the excitement and risk that theatre can have. Sometimes, performing in unusual places can surprise both the audience and performers. It might be uncomfortable, but theatre audiences are used to following artists to new places. 
Most plays are performed in a traditional way, like music concerts. But I believe music events can change. I love both theatre and music and want more people to enjoy them as much as I do.

**Sand**
I think sand is amazing because it can become things like glass and concrete. But, I don't like sand when it's just sand. For me, it's a problem between the car park and the sea. It blows in your face, gets in your food, and hides things like keys and coins. When you are wet, sand sticks to you and is hard to remove. But when you step on a towel, get in a car, or walk on a clean carpet, it falls off. For days, you find sand on the floor when you take off your shoes and socks. Sand stays with you for a long time. I don't like sand.
**Lock and Key**
People have always wanted safe homes. Long ago, they used a beam to lock the door. Now, we have electronic locks with many combinations. But people still like using a key. Some companies tried using smart cards for locks, but people prefer keys at home. One company made an electronic lock with a real key because people like it.
**Modern Art**
I was worried about visiting the new Tate Modern gallery because I don't understand modern art. I like some things, like furry art, neon lights, and big photos. Maybe if I knew more, I would have more opinions. Art is not about understanding but feeling it. This idea is nice, but it doesn't work for me. The new gallery helps visitors understand art better. They have labels that explain the art and what it means. This helped me understand the art better.

**Every Picture Tells a Story**
When books are made into movies, a lot of the story is cut or changed. This can be hard for the writer, but it can also be interesting. When I worked on a movie script, I saw that I could remove a lot of the talking and details from the book and still tell the same story. This doesn't mean the book's words were not needed. It's about how each type of story, book or movie, needs different things. In books, we often see repeated details about characters and who is speaking. This helps us understand better. In plays, which are mostly talking, the extra words make it feel like real speech. Some modern plays use a lot of extra words that don't add much to the story, just to show people are talking.
**Watching Movies**
When we watch movies, we can feel like we are part of the movie world. It's like we leave our real life for a while. But when the movie ends, we come back to the real world. Some people used to think movies were just for fun, not art. They liked watching movies but didn't think they were important.
**The Film Studios**
The Leiper Film Company studios had many different buildings. It was hard to find your way around because everything looked the same. There were three main entrances, but only one took you where you wanted to go. It was confusing for new people, but the people who worked there knew their way. The studio made movies that helped people escape from their everyday problems for a few hours.
**Film-makers**
Many people want to make movies. There are many books and courses about how to write scripts and make films. Some people, like Robert Rodriguez, became famous by making a movie with a small budget. He made his first big movie when he was young. In the past, filmmakers took more time to learn their skills. They worked on small projects before making big movies. Now, without big studios to help, new filmmakers have to be more independent.

In those days, many council houses were on the west side of the city. They were small and not very nice, made of orange bricks or white stucco. In summer, a factory two miles away made the air smell bad, like sulphur. In the morning, you could see paperboys holding their noses because of the smell.
I don't remember much from my early life. But I do remember sitting near a window and looking at the houses. I also remember faces I can't name, my mother ironing towels in a house that might not have been ours, and snow falling on a big mansion.
My mother was a small, often angry woman. I didn't understand why she was angry, so I couldn't make her happy. Even as a child, I knew she was different. She was very lonely, even in a room full of people. She liked things to be proper and clean, which was not common where we lived. She often told me to 'behave properly'. This meant not going into neighbors' gardens, sitting quietly for a long time, and listening to radio shows she liked.
My mother had some friends. There was Mrs. Buddery, who liked the Royal Family, Mrs. Winall, who didn't talk much, and Mrs. Laband, who was more lively. They often talked about things like bad legs, cold weather, and ungrateful children. I often felt like they were talking about me.
Growing up in West Earlham was the same for everyone. Until you were five, you stayed at home. I remember playing on a rug while my mother sat in a chair. After your fifth birthday, you went to Avenue Road infants school. Some kids had a mother with a bike to take them. My mother let other kids take me to school.
I remember the summer holidays. Sometimes, I saw the world outside West Earlham. There was an old man who told stories about the Merchant Navy. Once, I went to a charity event where a woman gave out lemonade and talked about a group called the League of Pity. My mother didn't like it because she thought they just wanted money.
My mother didn't like politicians. She thought they were greedy. But she cared about my education. Sometimes, she took me to the Norwich Castle Museum. We looked at paintings, and she even made a joke once about a painting of a Roman soldier.

**Philadelphia Avenue**
I walked down Philadelphia Avenue on one side of the street. It was getting dark, and the air was wet and sticky. I felt like I was sneaking around. I knew this street well because I grew up here. My neighbors were the Matzes and the Pritchards, and there was Han Kieffer's grocery store. My first friends lived in the houses of the Krings and the Pottses. I didn't know everyone by name, but each house was special to me. As I moved down the street, I noticed the houses changed. The porches were lower, and the front yards were smaller. Over time, some houses became stores, and some stores became homes again. I wondered how people lived in these places that used to be shops.
**Bachelor Fads**
Rick Gilbert is a furniture designer. He lives in a flat that used to be a curtain warehouse. The flat has big brick walls and large doors. Rick didn't want an open space, so he used a big plastic sheet to make a hallway and hide his office. This way, the kitchen is in the middle, and he can use it for cooking or meeting clients. He used light wood for the floors and mixed modern furniture with old pieces from his family.
**Bruce Chatwin**
Bruce Chatwin was a writer who loved to travel. His life was full of secrets and stories. His first book, "In Patagonia," was published in 1977. It was a travel book that was very exciting and different. Chatwin sometimes changed facts to make his stories more interesting. He believed that traveling could help people discover amazing stories from the past.
**Swimming**
One summer, it rained a lot, and I went swimming in the pool behind my house. The rain made bubbles on the water, and it was very peaceful. During this time, I thought about swimming across Britain. I wanted to follow the rain to the sea and explore new places. Swimming, like walking and cycling, helps us see the world in a different way. It lets us find places that are still wild and mysterious.

'CRYING Charles Darwin thought that crying did not have a clear purpose for humans. He was probably wrong. Scientists now say crying is important for social reasons. Psychiatrist John Bowlby said crying helps mothers and children become close. Many people think children cry because they feel helpless. But why adults cry is harder to understand. The sound of crying is less important than seeing someone cry. In early human groups, crying might have helped people trust each other and feel connected. We can cry for other reasons too. We might cry to show we care about people who are treated unfairly. Sometimes, we cry without wanting to, like when we hear beautiful music or speeches. We might cry during a sad movie, especially when we are with others. Crying seems to have a social purpose, but scientists are still studying it.'

**The Heat is On**
We all know about global warming, but how much warmer will the Earth get, and how will it change our lives? Many people have an idea of what global warming is, but we are not sure about what will happen because of it. A warmer climate will probably change the weather everywhere in the world. Since the air is connected to everything on Earth, changes in climate will affect plants, animals, water, and soil. Humans use these natural resources to grow food, build cities, and support many people. So, changes to these resources are important.
The problem is knowing how the world will change and what is causing these changes. In the last 100 years, human actions have increased some gases in the air, which are related to global temperature. These gases are likely affecting the climate now and will continue to do so. We know that greenhouse gases and global temperatures have changed together over the past 40,000 years. This shows they are probably connected. Evidence suggests the Earth's surface has warmed by about 6°C in the last century. Most scientists think this is not natural and is partly due to human pollution.
Scientists use computer programs called general circulation models (GCMs) to predict what will happen with higher global temperatures. These programs use physics and chemistry to study temperature, pressure, and other climate factors. However, they are not perfect and are expensive to use. We do not fully understand all climate processes, but we know it is complex. Despite these challenges, most people agree that climate change will happen faster than before.
GCMs predict that by 2100, the average global temperature will rise by 1°C to 3.5°C, sea levels will rise by 15-95 cm, and rainfall patterns will change. Extreme weather like heatwaves, floods, and droughts may become more common. These changes will affect the environment and humans. Climate change can change where forests and grasslands are, the species they have, and their benefits to us. This includes food, water, and where we live. Some effects may be bad, but not all. Some changes might be good. For example, in Australia, warmer temperatures have helped wheat grow better since 1952.
However, many future effects of climate warming are not good. Small climate changes can affect water availability, especially in dry areas. Problems may start in places where there is already little water. The Mediterranean Basin is one example, where less rain has been seen in some areas. Rain is now more in autumn and winter, less in spring.
Another problem is changes to glaciers. This will affect ice, plants, animals, and human structures. The Arctic ice might melt completely, which could help marine transport but also increase iceberg dangers. The most visible effect of global warming might be rising sea levels. Warmer water takes up more space, and melting ice adds more water. Many people live near coasts, so rising sea levels could cause big problems. Cities like London, New York, and Tokyo might face flooding. Many people could lose their homes and become environmental refugees. Small island countries could disappear if the worst happens, affecting their people and culture.

'Mission to Mars Wanted: a middle-aged, married couple for a 501-day trip to Mars and back. Applicants must be strong and healthy. This is the plan of millionaire Dennis Tito, who wants to send a spaceship on 5 January 2018. The spaceship will go about 160 km above Mars. It will use Mars's gravity to come back to Earth without using more fuel. This is important because the next chance to go to Mars after 2018 is in 2031. New technology is needed for this mission. If everything is ready in time, the spaceship might go. Even if it doesn't, the work will help future space missions.'

**Aesthetics**
Sometimes, art can make it hard to understand what art really means. Art is often seen as just a building, book, painting, or statue, separate from our everyday life. But real art is about what it does to our experiences. Some art is so admired that it becomes hard to see it in new ways. When art becomes famous, it can feel separate from the people and times that created it. This makes it hard to understand its true meaning.
Art is often put in a special place, away from other human activities. People who study art need to connect art with everyday life. Just like mountains are part of the earth, art is part of our experiences. To understand art, we need to look at everyday things, not just the art itself. 
We can enjoy flowers without knowing how they grow, but to understand them, we need to learn about soil, air, water, and sunlight. The same goes for art. We should start with simple experiences that catch our attention and make us happy.
Many people enjoy things like movies, jazz, and comics without thinking of them as art. When art is only in museums, people find joy in everyday things around them. Some people think art is only in special places, but real art is also in our daily lives. When art is connected to everyday work and life, people appreciate it more.

**Observing Lions**
People often think of lions as amazing hunters. They imagine lions working together like a team to catch their food. In the evening, lions quietly come out of the shadows and surround their prey. Lions seem to be very social animals, working together for a common goal, which is to get their next meal. But after watching lions for many years, we have learned something different. We started studying lions in 1978. We wanted to know why lions hunt together, take care of their cubs, and scare away other animals with loud roars. If an animal's success is measured by how many babies it has that survive, then working together might not always be good. If an animal is too nice, others might take advantage of it. So, why do lions work together? We thought we would find the answer in two to three years. But lions are very good at doing nothing. It took us a long time to learn about their behavior. Wild lions can live up to 18 years, so we are only now starting to understand them.
**Pop Music Review**
Bedrock's third album was very important for the band. The album, called "New Life," changed rock music in the country for the next ten years. The old style of rock music was serious and had loud guitars. The new style was lighter and mixed different sounds. The album had songs about everyday life and feelings. It also had fun sounds like fairground organs and brass bands. The band used humor and did not hide where they came from. The album showed that Bedrock was good at writing songs and mixing different styles. Some songs were about simple things like sunbathing and Sunday afternoons. But the best songs were deeper and more emotional, like "So Low" and "To the Brink." The album had 16 great songs with no bad ones, which was rare for long CDs.
**Extract from an Autobiography**
As a child, I loved stories about "The Sibyl," wise women from ancient times. My mother told me a story about one Sibyl. She offered nine books to the King of Rome for 300 gold pieces. He said no, so she burned three books and offered six for the same price. He said no again, so she burned three more. He finally bought the last three books for 300 gold pieces. I learned a lesson from this story about selling and life. I was often a lonely child. I wanted to play with other kids, but they said no. My mother told me to do something fun so other kids would want to join me. It worked, and I never forgot that lesson. When I got a chance to write a travel book, I wanted to find something interesting to write about. I don't like traveling much, so I told my editor where I didn't want to go. I like to visit old places because I enjoy thinking about the past.
**What Becomes of Your Manuscript?**
When you send your book to a publisher, it goes into a big pile called the "slush pile." A junior editor or an experienced person who works part-time will look at it. They want to find something new and interesting. If they like your book, they will show it to a senior editor. Then, it will be discussed in a meeting. The editor will need to explain why your book is good and if it can sell well. They will also think about if you, as an author, can write more books in the future. They might want to meet you before deciding to publish your book.

**Advertising Challenges in the Early 1990s**
If you worked in advertising in the early 1990s, it was a tough time. The economy was bad, and it was worse than expected. In Britain, in 1991, the economy shrank, interest rates were high, people spent less money, many lost their jobs, and many homes were taken back by banks. Every business was affected, especially car and building companies, which lost 30% of their business. Many people and companies in different countries suffered.
Advertising people were not the only ones losing jobs, but those who kept their jobs felt a lot of pressure. They had to help companies make money with less money for advertising. They were told to do more with less. At the same time, marketing became more important. Companies started to focus on making products that customers wanted, not just what was easy to make. This change made marketing more respected but also more challenging.
Marketing was seen as a solution to many problems, and a lot of money was spent on advertising. But in the 1990s, the advertising industry faced its worst time in years. The bad economy made companies look closely at how much they spent on advertising. They wanted to know if it was worth the money. Many companies were not sure if advertising was giving them good results.
Companies wanted better advertising strategies and creativity. They wanted the best people working hard for them. Advertising people had to find ways to do more with less money. This was hard because of the recession and other changes like new laws, changing customer needs, and advertising in other countries.
The pressure was on to make advertising work better. But help was not easy to find. Companies and advertising agencies were busy dealing with these problems and did not share their secrets. Books and seminars did not always provide useful information. They often made advertising seem better than it was, which did not help those responsible for it.

**The Lure of the Kitchen**
When I was at university, I wanted to be a chef. This was not a common choice among my friends. Cooking is not an easy job. Chefs work long hours, have a lot of pressure, and do not earn much money. But I still wanted to be a chef. I was not happy at university. The work was hard, and the social life was not fun. Being a chef seemed like a good change. It felt more real and honest than my life at college. My love for cooking also came from a special meal I had at a famous restaurant in London. The food was amazing, and I wanted to learn how to cook like that. I started reading cookbooks, visiting markets, and making fancy meals. My history degree was not important to me anymore.
**The Swimming Lesson**
The swimming teacher at my school was a small, strong man with tattoos. He used to be a drill sergeant. I asked him to teach me how to dive. He told me to sit at the edge of the pool, put my hands above my head, and roll forward. I practiced this for an hour. Next time, he taught me to dive standing up. He was very strict and always told me to keep my legs straight and point my toes. The next week, I tried diving from the high board. It was very high, and I was scared. I tried to remember what he taught me and jumped. For a moment, I felt like I was flying. When I hit the water, my dive was not good, but I felt very happy. I understood what it means to feel 'free as a bird.'
**The Traveller**
Some people love adventure and do not care about comfort. They climb dangerous mountains, sail alone in the sea, and eat strange foods. These people are different from most of us. We like our comfortable beds and safe lives. We think these adventurers are strange, but they live in a world we do not understand. We are happy with our microwaves and phones, and the only danger we face is crossing a busy street.
**Sailing**
Jonathan Raban is a writer who is afraid of the sea, but he spends a lot of time sailing. He is not the best sailor, but he is good enough. He sails because he likes to write about it. Sailing gives him exciting stories to tell. His boat has a device that shows his exact location on the sea. He likes this device, but he thinks other sailing tools, like the compass, have changed how people connect with the sea. Before the compass, sailors had to watch the waves and feel the sea. Now, they just follow the compass, and the sea is just a big space. This is why Raban has time to look at the waves carefully.

**Holiday Reading**
Summer gives us two great joys: leaving home and reading books. These joys are connected. Books help us feel at home in the world. We can see our own experiences in stories from long ago or far away. In books, we find our own thoughts and feelings. Authors can describe things we feel but cannot say. They write clearly about things we find confusing. This is amazing, especially if the book is from a different place or time. We feel thankful to these writers for helping us understand ourselves. 
Reading and travel help us see new things. When we go to a new place, everything is interesting. The same happens when we read a great book. It shows us things we did not notice before. We start to see the colors of the sky, changes in a friend's face, or feelings we did not know we had.
**Author's Note**
These travel stories were first in the Observer newspaper over seven years. I made some small changes, but not many. I fixed a few mistakes. In one story about China, I thought the Hong Kong dollar would stay strong, but it fell later. I did not change the story because it was written at that time. Like other travelers, I was there, not knowing what would happen next. This is the story of travel: seeing the world with just a ticket. I believe travelers can see things clearly. Even a postcard can have a purpose.
**Ecotourism**
The word 'ecotourism' is often used wrongly. It started in the 1980s when people cared more about the environment. Travelers wanted to know their trips did not harm nature. Now, 'ecotourism' can mean many things, like living with tribes or a short boat trip. It includes cultural visits, nature, wildlife, or adventure. The original idea was good, helping people make smart choices. But without clear rules, travelers can get confused about what is true ecotourism.
**Transylvanian Journey**
I lost my notebook from my trip to Transylvania for 50 years. I found it again by luck. It helped me remember that time, but not perfectly. In Transylvania, I stayed in friendly homes for weeks. When I stopped moving, I stopped writing. I thought there was nothing to write about. When I traveled again, I wrote only short notes. I worried about the order of events when writing this book. But then I decided it was okay to let the story tell itself.

**Fashion**
Fashion is not just a new thing. It did not start only in the 1800s and 1900s with big businesses. Fashion, like style and design, has been around for a long time. Many people who study fashion say it started in the 1500s and 1600s when people began trading more. As societies grew and more clothes and accessories were made, the meanings of clothes also became more complicated. Today, it is hard to say exactly what any piece of clothing means. For example, a man's suit can mean different things to different people and in different situations.
**Writer**
People often think that all writers are very successful because of stories about big deals for new books. But for most writers, life is not like that. Many writers have other jobs during the day and write in the evenings. This way, they have a steady job even if their book does not sell well. Some writers, like me, do different small jobs, like teaching or writing articles, to make money. I have heard about writing jobs at a chocolate factory, but I have never had one. By doing different jobs and with help from friends, I can still write my book.
**Sudden Fame**
Our small shows around the country started to sell out, and we needed more security to handle the many excited fans. We had to use secret ways to enter the places we played to avoid being surrounded by fans. On nights when we were not performing, it was hard to go out without being followed by fans. In just a few days, we became famous. Our fans watched everything we did, and our managers took care of all our needs. Even though I was always shy, I started to feel very confident, which is a strange feeling for shy people in such situations. In short, I felt very overwhelmed.

**Music - The Future Ahead**
Technology is changing how we live, work, and enjoy our free time. Susan Hallam talks about how this affects music in Britain. In the late 20th century, we had more ways to listen to music, like radio, TV, records, tapes, CDs, and videos. But, there were fewer live music shows and jobs for musicians. More people can listen to music now, and this will probably continue because music is important to us. Music is part of big events in the country and gives people many ways to enjoy it, both formally and informally. A world without music is hard to imagine. The question is not if there will be music in the 21st century, but what kind of music it will be and if people will still want to learn to play instruments. I think people will still want to learn. The music industry makes a lot of money in Britain, and musical skills will still be important for jobs, especially in media. Playing an instrument can also help develop skills early on. Research in the USA shows that music can help with spatial reasoning, a part of intelligence. In Europe, group music lessons have shown to help with social skills and focus in children. Playing an instrument might also help with skills like good study habits and being organized. Because of these reasons, people will still want to learn instruments in the short term. 
What about the future? Will things change, and how? I think two things might happen. First, people will listen to more types of music. New styles will mix different kinds of music. Second, technology will be used more to make and play music. This will make it easier for people to create music without needing a lot of technical skill, but it might also mean fewer live performances. More people of all ages might want to make music together in their communities, reflecting their local music traditions. 
To prepare for this future, music teaching needs to change. More people should be able to learn different instruments throughout their lives. This means the way we teach and measure progress in music will need to change to include more musical skills. Musicians will need to learn how to inspire and teach people of all ages, work with large groups, and have skills for community work. This is a big change from how things are done now. It will also mean showing the public the value of music education. 
Finally, we need to make music more important in our lives. Music is crucial, but often we don't notice it. Everyone in the music profession should work together to change this.

**The Actor's Craft**
Sometimes people make fun of actors. This happens because actors often talk about their work in interviews. They should be like the dancer Pavlova, who said, "If I could tell you, I wouldn't dance it." But instead, actors often say things that sound silly or are just gossip. Paul Scofield, a famous actor, said that acting is interesting only when you do it. Talking about it makes it seem less real. Every time an actor starts a new play, they learn everything again. When the play ends, they feel empty until the next one.
**A Review of Hamlet**
Adrian Lester plays Hamlet, a young man between being a boy and a man. His acting is simple and confident. He uses the words and his body very well. Lester's Hamlet is a young man who is angry but also funny and kind. His acting is very good. You can see how he uses his body, like his arms, to show his feelings. Another actor, Handy, also shows this in his role as Horatio. Acting makes us ask: What is acting? What is real behavior? Who makes these characters come alive?
**One Director's Approach to Rehearsal**
This director starts rehearsals with a method called "dropping in." The stage manager shows the script on a screen. Actors listen quietly when others speak. When it's their turn, they read the line, think about it, and then speak. For example, if the line is "Queuing all night, the rain, do you remember?" they breathe, imagine the scene, and then speak. The director says not to plan too much. Just be open and trust that something will happen.
**The Perfect Theatre**
The perfect theatre makes you feel like you matter. Going to the theatre is special, and the staff should know that too. The theatre should connect the actors and the audience. Everyone should be able to see and hear well. The size of the theatre is important. It should fit the human voice and body. Many old theatres did this well. They feel like they have history, like old church steps. You can't please everyone with a play. People want to see something new and surprising.

**Paul Simon and Rock and Roll**
In the 1950s, rock and roll was very popular with young people. But it also changed the lives of older people and the middle class. It helped create new rock stars. These young people listened to rock and roll and knew it would be important for their future. Paul Simon, like many young people in the US, heard this exciting new music on Alan Freed's radio show, Moondog Rock'n'Roll Party. This show was very important for young people who wanted to become rock stars. Just like John Lennon in Liverpool, who listened to Radio Luxembourg, Paul Simon loved the music from Freed's show. He wanted to stop just listening and start making his own music.
**Snow Adventure**
There was no clear path, but I thought I could walk safely if I was careful. The wind was strong and pushed me down as I slipped on the ice. Suddenly, the snow under me broke, and I fell into a hole about four feet deep. The snow had covered a gap between two rocks, and I fell through a thin layer of snow. I climbed out, feeling scared and thinking about what I would do if the hole was deeper. I sat against a pine tree sticking out of the snow to think about my situation. In one hour, I had only walked half a mile. I knew I had to change my plan.
**Qualitative Research**
There are many books that help researchers with qualitative research. These books talk a lot about collecting data, but not much about how to analyze it. Many people find data analysis confusing. So, we asked different social scientists to talk about how they analyze data. The goal was to share ideas and understanding about data analysis, not to make a guidebook. We wanted to make the process clearer. This is not easy, so we let our contributors share their work in different ways, like personal stories or more formal writing.

**Screen Learning**
A few days ago, I saw my six-year-old eating noodles in a funny way. He was pulling them up with his teeth and trying to look like a dinosaur. He said, "I'm a little dinosaur." He was copying a scene from a TV show. I asked him what he remembered about dinosaurs, but he didn't remember much. Many people like using the internet and computers for learning, but is it a good way to learn? One father tried an interactive program with his son. The father read the words, but the son only played with the pictures. The father thought, "If he had spent ten minutes with a book, he might have learned something." TV, like my son and his noodles show, gives ideas but not always learning. Research says learning happens best with teachers or parents talking with children. New technology can help teach, but schools are still important.
**Hollywood**
By 1918, most of the world's film-making moved to Hollywood. People living there didn't like it at first. They thought the new people were not polite. But they accepted it because Hollywood became successful. Success in Hollywood means making a lot of money from movies. Hollywood knows a good movie when it sees one. In less than 100 years, Hollywood became as famous as New York, Rome, or Paris. It changed a lot. A long time ago, there were orange trees and a small store. Now, it is a big place, but still feels like a small town. People in Hollywood talk about movies, who is dating who, and who is working on what project. Successful people often want to leave, but many people in show-business still come to Hollywood.
**Photography**
Photography was created by artists in the 1800s. They wanted to keep a real record of what they saw. They used light, lenses, and chemicals to make pictures. These pictures were more real and detailed than paintings. Some artists didn't like this and said photography wasn't art. They thought it was too real and not creative. But photographers knew they found a new way to show the world. They used cameras like other artists use brushes and pencils. They wanted to show nature and people in a new way.
**Book Illustration**
In the past, every children's book had pictures. This was also true for many novels for older kids. But over time, there were fewer pictures in books. Children's publishing was busy, but it didn't have a lot of money. This meant some work was not very good, but the best artists always did their best. The old black-and-white pictures are like a mix of junk and treasure. They are great for research or just looking at. Some of these treasures are coming back. They might be reprinted or shown in exhibitions. Soon, a smart publisher might make a series of classic children's book pictures from this time.

**Blogging: Sharing with the World**
Some time ago, a website talked about the dangers of telling everyone where you are online. The website said that when you say, "Hey, I'm at this place," you are also telling everyone, even people you don't know, that you are not at home. This made people think about the problems of sharing too much online. The internet lets us share everything about our lives with many people. This can be exciting because it might bring us money or fame. So, we start sharing our secrets, photos, and stories online. But later, we might find out that it can be dangerous and confusing.
This might sound sad, but don't worry. Some people have already explored this online world before us. They were the first bloggers. They lost jobs, made and lost friends, and dealt with being famous, all before social media was popular. These bloggers have learned lessons that we can learn from too.
In January 1994, a 19-year-old student named Justin Hall started sharing his life on the internet. Back then, the internet was mostly used by students and scientists. Hall saw it as a way to share his life story. He wrote about everything, and people loved reading about his adventures. But one day, he had to stop because his girlfriend said, "Either the blog goes, or I do." He learned that sharing too much online can make people not trust you.
In 2002, Heather Armstrong, who worked in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. She wrote about her job sometimes. One day, someone at her job shared her blog with her bosses, and she lost her job. This shows that what we say online can affect our real lives. But Armstrong's story ended well. She got married, started blogging again about her family, and now her blog helps support her family. She learned that just because we can say anything online, it doesn't mean we should.

'Enough Sleep? Many people today feel tired all the time. In busy and rich countries, people often have trouble sleeping and feel anxious. In the USA, 40 million people have sleep problems. Some books in Britain talk about people who can't sleep or about places where people study sleep. People are interested in sleep, how it works, and why we have problems with it. A sleep expert says, 'People need more sleep. They wake up early to avoid traffic.' A researcher did an experiment. He let people sleep up to 14 hours a night for a month. After three weeks, they slept about eight hours a night. This shows they needed more sleep before. In Europe, a university in England studies sleep. They look at how tiredness affects sailors, how noise affects sleep, and how tired drivers are dangerous. They find people to study by advertising in student newspapers. These people get paid and change their sleep for the study. Dr. Louise Reyner says some people worry because they put things on their heads to study them, but they can't see dreams. The lab is more interested in physical things. They have a car simulator to study tired drivers. People come in the afternoon after little sleep. They drive while answering questions. The road looks endless, and the sun is bright. Many say they won't fall asleep, but they do. A video shows a driver trying to stay awake. He blinks and nods off, and the car goes off the road. Coffee can help. Dr. Reyner says two cups can make you a safe driver for a short time. She suggests using tablets, energy drinks, and caffeinated gum. Shift workers might need them. We know some things about sleep. Humans sleep in cycles like other animals. There are four stages of sleep, from light to deep. Dreams happen in light sleep, and the brain stops the body from moving. Scientists think sleep helps repair the body, but they are not sure. Women sleep a bit longer than men, and older people need less sleep, but we don't know why. Some researchers say sleep helps us pass time safely. In the past, people had different sleep patterns. A professor found that between 1500 and 1850 in Britain, people slept in two parts. They went to bed early, woke up after midnight, stayed awake for an hour, and then slept again. This time was quiet and good for thinking. Poor people liked this time because they were free from work. By the 17th century, with more light, rich people started sleeping like we do now. The industrial revolution made people work longer, changing sleep for everyone. In some places outside Europe and America, people still sleep in parts. They sleep for a few hours, wake up, and then sleep again. In some tribal societies, noise and danger make it hard to sleep all night. It seems people everywhere need more sleep.'

'I was wearing very expensive cowboy boots, standing on rocks in the Arizona desert. I had a full cowboy outfit, but I was not a real cowboy. I looked at the Arizona mountains and knew I did not belong there. I flew in from Denver and thought I might look like a cowboy, but that feeling went away when I saw a real cowboy at the Phoenix airport. He wore a dirty shirt, needed a shave, and carried a dirty bag. He looked at my new boots and walked away.
I used to be a racing driver, and I loved it. But I don't race anymore. I wondered what I should do now. I thought I could talk about races on TV, but many other drivers wanted to do that too. I tried to sell classic cars, but nobody was buying. Being an 'ex' racing driver is hard. People don't want to hear about how I almost became a champion. Even if I was a champion, people would only listen for a short time.
I miss racing cars. I miss the speed and the excitement. I miss the people and the reporters who cared about what I said. Being a little famous was nice. Now, I have a lot of free time. The phone doesn't ring much. I looked at the sky and saw some birds. They seemed to tell me to leave their nest alone. I realized I had a lot to learn about being in the desert.'

**Vancouver**
In the last ten years, many people from all over the world have moved to Vancouver, in western Canada. In the evening, people like to walk in the city, and if you walk with them, you might hear many different languages. People come to Vancouver because it has a mild climate, beautiful views of the ocean and mountains, a clean and safe environment, and good schools and jobs. Some people complain about the new buildings, but the new people and tourists have helped the city grow. Vancouver was once called 'Terminal City' because it was a gateway to other places. Now, it is more of a gateway than ever.
**Writing Letters**
Journalists like me are usually not good at writing letters. Some say it's because we don't like writing for free, but I don't think that's true. It's more likely because we try hard to make our writing have a big impact, so writing a simple letter is difficult for us. Real artists, who don't think about the effect of their words, don't have this problem. I think a real artist knows how to use words well. When Shakespeare wrote his famous lines, he probably didn't think about why they were so good, but they showed he was a great writer.
**Supermarket Opening**
In the past, opening a new supermarket in Britain was a big event. A soap star, a disc jockey, or a minor royal would come to cut the ribbon. Now, new supermarkets open so often that famous people are not needed. Why pay a celebrity when anyone can open it for free? Last week, people waiting to enter a new Superbuy store didn't care who opened it, as long as they were first in line. One customer heard that the first five men would get a bottle of aftershave, and the first five women would get flowers. This news spread quickly, making those at the front feel happy and those at the back feel jealous.

**Citizen Kane**
The movie *Citizen Kane* came out in 1941. There was a lot of talk about it because people thought it was about William Randolph Hearst, a famous newspaper owner. The movie did not make a lot of money at first, even though many people liked it. Later, television made it popular again. Many people who make movies today say it inspired them. This is surprising because it was the first movie made by Orson Welles. Welles said he did not know what he could or could not do, so he just did what he wanted. He had a great team, including cameraman Gregg Toland, writer Herman J. Mankiewicz, and special-effects expert Linwood Dunn. Welles and Mankiewicz decided to make a movie about a newspaper owner like Hearst. Welles thought this was a great chance for him to be both the director and the actor.
**Dermot and Carmel**
Dermot thought Carmel was acting a bit strange that morning. He told her twice that he might be late and might stop at the golf club on his way home. He needed to talk to someone, and the golf club was the best place. Carmel nodded but seemed like she didn't really hear him. Dermot asked, "Will you be okay? What are you going to do today?" Carmel smiled and said, "It's funny you ask. I was just thinking I have nothing to do today, so I might walk downtown and look at the shops. It feels a bit lazy to just enjoy the day." Dermot smiled back and said, "You should enjoy yourself. And if I'm late, I won't need dinner, so don't worry about cooking." Carmel replied, "No, that's fine."
**Title Race**
A recent study shows that job titles can make people feel jealous and unhappy at work. A survey found that 90% of bosses and 70% of workers agree that titles can cause problems between coworkers. Surprisingly, 70% of office workers would rather have a better job title than a pay raise. This shows that people care a lot about their job titles. Today, nobody wants to be seen as less important. The new job titles focus on skills (like specialist or coordinator) but are really just nicer ways to say the same thing.

I was in Vienna to take photos. Taking photos was my job and my passion. I loved how light looked on things and how one photo could show the feeling of a place or person. I always hoped to take the perfect photo. I had a lucky moment once when a photo I took of smoke from a burning oil well was wanted by newspapers everywhere. After that, I worked for myself, but things didn't go as planned. That's why I was in Vienna, not somewhere more exciting. But I was still taking photos and getting paid, which was good.
I got the Vienna job by chance. I had taken photos of London for a book called "Four Cities in Four Seasons." The book also included Paris, Rome, and Vienna. The Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, left the job in Vienna, so they asked me to do it. I was free, and they liked my work. Things at home weren't great, so I was happy to go to Vienna.
They put me in a hotel in the old city. I had been to Vienna before with my wife, but it was busy and hot, and I didn't take many photos. This time, in January, it was cold and different. I knew I would enjoy it and take great photos.
The first day, I didn't take any photos. I rode the trams around the city to feel its mood. The weather was cold and set. I wanted to make this my Vienna, not like Schussner's photos. I waited for the right moment to take photos.
The next morning, I went out early. Snow had fallen, and the city was quiet. I wanted to take a photo of the cathedral, but it was hard to fit it all in one shot. Still, it could be magical. Photography has always felt magical to me. Watching a photo develop is like seeing a mystery unfold. That's why what happened that morning didn't surprise me.

Kinetic Art Exhibition
Something amazing has happened at London's Hayward Gallery. It has become a place full of wonder. This change is not because of a big, expensive show. Instead, it is because of a special exhibition about kinetic art. Kinetic art is art that moves or shows movement. This exhibition looks at the history of kinetic art in the 20th century. It shows that making art that moves has been important for many years, even if not many people noticed it before. The exhibition has many paintings, drawings, documents, and films. Guy Brett, who knows a lot about kinetic art, put it all together. There are not many explanations, so visitors can enjoy finding out things on their own.
David Hockney
David Hockney is an artist that many people like, even if they do not usually like art. People might like his work because it is easy to understand or because it shows fun things. Some people might like him because he is a nice person and funny. Some critics think Hockney is not a great artist. But maybe he seems less important because he is very popular. Hockney knows he is not the best artist and thinks it is okay if his work is not seen as great. Only time will tell how important his art is.
Window-shopping - an Art Exhibition
I have seen many art exhibitions. Some are great, and some are not. Sometimes exhibitions try to show that many artists think the same way. This can be interesting, but sometimes it feels forced. I wanted to do something different. I worked with seven artists in an empty warehouse. We called it 'Window-shopping.' Each artwork was different, but they were all art. For example, Sam Cole's knitted cats moved around on a toy train track. Matthew Crawley broke a video camera, and it flickered on a screen. These artworks were very different, but they worked well together. I did not try to make a big statement about art. Art is personal, and each artist decides what they want to do.
Art History
Some people love looking at paintings but do not want to think too much about them. They worry it will ruin their enjoyment. Some art historians focus on theory and not on the pleasure of looking at art. This is like thinking that knowing how a dish is made will make it taste less good. But knowing more about art can make it more enjoyable. Our enjoyment of art is not just about our personal taste. It is also about what our society values. So, while enjoying art is important, thinking about it can also be interesting. In the past, people thought art was different from thinking, but now we know they can go together.

**Metals**
A long time ago, people in the Stone Age might have wanted to make themselves look nice. They could have found shiny yellow stones, like gold, by the river. These stones were not like normal rocks; they were special and pretty. Gold was soft and easy to shape, so people liked it a lot. Copper might have been found by accident too. When people saw how useful copper tools were, they looked for more copper and learned how to get it from rocks. This is how people started working with metals.
**St Ives**
We walked down a small, winding street with our bags. The wind was very strong, and the waves were cold and big, hitting the walkway. No one was outside, and all the houses by the water had their windows closed tight. We saw the weather get worse as we arrived in St Ives on a small train. The sky was dark and grey. Visiting Cornwall without a car in bad weather did not seem like a good idea anymore. I told my friend we would have nice walks by the sea and warm evenings by the fire.
**Computer Modelling**
Studying the past is hard because it is gone. The people who lived in good and bad times are not here anymore. We do not know exactly why they lived in certain places or how they formed families and villages. Archaeology gives us some ideas, but we cannot test them like we do with science experiments. But maybe we can use computers to help. Computer modelling lets us create old landscapes and fill them with digital people. These virtual people can act like real people. We can change things like rain or the number of people and see how they react.

**Vervet Monkeys**
Cheney and Seyfarth studied vervet monkeys. One day, the leader male monkey saw a new male monkey near their trees. The new monkey wanted to join the group. If he joined, the leader might lose his position. The leader monkey had a clever idea to keep the new monkey away. When the new monkey tried to come closer, the leader made a sound that means a leopard is near. The new monkey got scared and went back to his trees. This happened many times. But then, the leader made a mistake. He made the leopard sound while he was walking calmly on the ground.
**What Cats Catch**
In a village in England, people counted what their cats caught. In one year, 70 cats caught over 1,000 animals. An American professor saw this and thought all cats in Britain might catch 100 million birds and small animals each year. But this is not true. Most cats live in towns and catch fewer animals. The important question is: are there still enough birds? The answer is yes. In winter, people feed birds, and gardens have places for birds to live. The survey showed cats catch many birds, but they are not destroying the bird population.
**Buffalo's Day**
Buffaloes are very important to marsh people. Every morning, buffaloes leave their sleeping place slowly. They make tired sounds as they go to the reed beds. They stand at the edge of the water, making noises about how tired they are. Then, the leader buffalo goes into the water. In the water, they move slowly and make quiet sounds. They swim with just their noses above the water, looking very tired. They spend the day in the reeds, eating green plants.
**PICASSO, Pablo**
In 1940, Picasso painted fish while he was in a fishing town. The painting shows a fish seller's table with a crab and some fish. The fish look like they are still alive. The painting is hard to understand because Picasso used flat shapes and soft colors. It looks calm, like underwater. But there is a feeling of a fight coming between the fish and the crab. The sharp shapes in the painting make it feel a bit dangerous.

Photography
For the last 150 years, photography has been used to capture all parts of human life. In this short time, photography has grown to show moments in time and space. It lets us see quick moments and both big and small things. Photography has shown us pictures from faraway places on Earth and in space, as well as the complex and difficult parts of modern life. It is a very important way to show human life.
But, using pictures to record events is much older. The first pictures go back to about 35,000 years ago. We do not know exactly why early people made cave paintings. They might show real hunting events, be used for magic to help with hunting, be religious symbols, or just to make life more colorful. Pictures are a big part of human culture.
People have always asked if pictures show the truth and what their role in society is. Many people believe that "seeing is believing," so pictures have always been important. When photography was invented in the 1800s, it was a big deal. People thought it could show the truth automatically. The camera was seen as a machine like the human eye, making images that looked like what we see. The camera could capture real images, which artists had tried to do for a long time.
Some people thought everyone could understand photos, no matter where they were from. In 1933, a photographer named August Sander said even people far away could understand a photo of the sky. But as the world became more connected, we started to ask if photos can be understood the same way by everyone. Is photography like language, which is different in each culture?
Photography is often seen as showing real evidence, making it seem clear and easy to understand. People often show photos to share their lives, like saying "this is my grandson." Since its invention in 1839, photography and how people use it have changed a lot. Photos have become historical documents, showing us about the people and times they were made in.
I want to show that the camera is not just a tool that records events. Photography can also help bring social and political change. For example, the Italian Renaissance in the 1400s changed how people saw the world with new ways of showing images. Photography has helped create the media culture we have today and shows the hard truths of the world.

**How to Write Poetry**
Writing poetry can be tricky. There are no strict rules, but you need to read a lot, write often, and let your imagination be free. Some people need to feel safe to write, while others write when they are sad. Some write on a schedule, and others wait for inspiration. All ways are okay if you are true to yourself. Listen to your inner voice and let it grow.
**The Short Story**
In a short story, you can't have too many characters or long descriptions. Flashbacks should be short and only used if needed. A memory in the main character's mind can help move the story forward. Dialogue, or talking between characters, can show different sides of a story quickly. Every word in a short story is important, so make them count.
**Screenplays**
Writing a screenplay is like playing chess. At first, you might not know what will happen next, but with practice, you see the whole picture. In chess, you learn about openings, middle games, and end games. The more you play, the better you understand. The same goes for writing screenplays.
**Looking at Writing**
Speaking is natural for humans, but writing is not. All children learn to speak without lessons, but writing systems were created by a few advanced societies. Writing has improved over time, but it is not easy for everyone. Children are naturally good at speaking, but writing is something they must learn with effort. We need to understand how writing works and how children learn it.

I have never started writing a book with more worry. I call it a novel because I don't know what else to call it. I don't have much story to tell, and I don't end with a death or a marriage. Instead, I leave the reader wondering. This book is about my memories of a man I met only sometimes, and I don't know much about what happened to him in between. I could make up things to fill the gaps and make the story clearer, but I don't want to do that. I just want to write what I know. To avoid embarrassing people who are still alive, I have changed the names of the people in this story, and I have made sure no one can recognize them. The man I am writing about is not famous. Maybe he never will be. When he dies, he might not leave any mark on the world, like a stone thrown into a river leaves no mark on the water. Then my book, if anyone reads it, will be read only for its own interest. But maybe the way he lived and his strong and kind character will influence others, and people will realize he was special. Then it will be clear who I am writing about, and those who want to know about his early life might find something useful in my book. I think my book will be helpful to people who want to write about my friend. I don't claim that the conversations I wrote are exactly what was said. I never took notes, but I remember well what matters to me, and I believe I have written them truthfully. I said earlier that I have not made up anything, but I have done what historians do by adding speeches I did not hear to make the story more lively. I want people to read my book, and I think it's okay to make it interesting. Smart readers will know where I have done this, and they can choose to ignore it. Another reason I am worried about writing this book is that the people I write about are from another culture. It is hard to know people, and I think you can only really know people from your own country. People are not just themselves; they are also where they were born, the games they played, the food they ate, the schools they went to, and the books they read. These things make them who they are, and you can't know them just by hearing about them; you have to live them. You can only know if you are them. Because you can't really know people from another country, it's hard to make them believable in a book. I have only written about people from my own country before, and if I have written about others in short stories, it's because you can describe them briefly. You give the reader a general idea and let them imagine the rest. In this book, I don't pretend my characters see themselves as I see them; they are seen through my eyes.

**Poetry Recitals**
Today, poetry can be confusing because there are many different styles and ideas about poetry. Some poets write poems to be read in books, while others like to perform their poems in front of people. This has created two groups: the "literary" poets and the "popular" poets. 
The "literary" poets focus on writing poems that are deep and complex. These poems are best enjoyed when read on a page. On the other hand, "popular" poets write simple poems that are easy to understand when heard. They enjoy performing their poems for an audience.
In the last twenty years, public poetry readings have become more common. These events happen in small towns, schools, colleges, and arts festivals. Poets read their work to people, and sometimes music is included in the event. 
For "popular" poets, performing is good because their poems are made for live audiences. But for "literary" poets, it can be hard because their poems are complex and might not be understood right away. 
Listening to poets read their work can be fun and helpful. It shows how the poet wants the poem to sound. However, it is still important to read poetry on the page to fully understand it. 
The main reason for poetry recitals is to make people enjoy poetry and see it as something fun, not just for experts.

**Oral History**
Historians are using more oral stories, but this has problems. When someone tells their story, it is not always a clear picture of the past. The historian chooses who to talk to and what to talk about. Even if the historian just listens, their presence can change how the person remembers and talks about the past. The final story is influenced by the historian's background and how they understand history. Historians help create new evidence, but the person telling the story is also not directly connected to the past. Their memories can be mixed with things they heard from other places, like TV. They might remember the past as better than it was or feel sad about things that happened later. Feelings make the story seem real, but they might come from later events, not the past.
**Animal Science**
There are two main ways to study animals: looking at how their bodies work and looking at their behavior. Physiologists study how nerves, muscles, and senses work together. People who study the whole animal look at how animals behave and what affects them. In this group, psychologists study how animals learn, often in labs with animals like rats and pigeons. Ethologists study natural behavior in wild animals. These two groups are now working more together. Physiologists think their methods are very important, but even if we know how every nerve works, we still need to study behavior. Behavior has its own patterns that we need to understand. Trying to explain a bird building a nest by looking at nerve cells is like trying to read a book with a microscope.
**The Social Sciences**
When students start studying social sciences, they need to learn two things at the same time. They need to know the content of the subject and how to study it. This means learning the facts and research in textbooks and understanding how this knowledge is found and organized. Social sciences are not just common sense. Each social science looks at a different part of social life, uses different study methods, and has its own ideas. These basic ideas help social scientists go beyond everyday understanding and make each subject different.
**Classical Architecture**
In Ancient Greece and Rome, architecture was more than just building. The Roman architect Vitruvius said architecture is about order, arrangement, proportion, symmetry, and distribution. He used some Greek words for these ideas, which came from earlier Greek writings we don't have now. Vitruvius did not include utility and function in his main definition, but he did talk about the best ways to build for different uses. The focus was on architecture as an art. Classical architecture has complex origins. Before, there were simple huts in Greece and Italy that did not meet Vitruvius' artistic standards. These simple forms were important and continued into more advanced architecture. Even if a classical temple looks fancy, it is basically a simple, single-room hut.

The two sisters, Lily and Mui, kept Lily's driving a secret from Chen for a while. Lily would drive around the area, going over a small bridge with a bump. Chen found out but was amused instead of angry. He was happy that Lily could drive and started planning a trip with her. They decided to go on a Monday morning next month, so they wouldn't lose any customers. Lily practiced driving in the meantime. Mui bought a road map and got a discount, which impressed Chen, but Lily felt Mui didn't trust her driving skills.
On the day of the trip, they left home and soon reached the English Channel. Lily drove very well, and even Mui, who was ready to give directions, had to admit it. Lily overtook some slow cars, and Chen applauded her. They arrived at a seaside town and parked the car. Lily was careful about parking rules and paid a fee to avoid problems. She locked the van doors carefully. Chen joked that no one would steal the van, which upset the sisters.
Chen took their son, Man Kee, to see the sea. He thought about Man Kee's future and wanted him to have a good education and own many restaurants. The sea made Chen feel thoughtful. He saw a ship in the distance and showed it to Man Kee, saying it was special and would take them home one day. Lily and Mui joined them, and Chen let Man Kee look through a telescope. When Lily tried to look, the ship was gone, and she only saw seagulls.

Title: The Well
I read that if you look from a deep hole, you can see stars during the day. I asked you to help me try this. You watched as I pulled up the well bucket and climbed in. I told you to lower me down. I didn't think about how heavy the bucket would be or that you might not be strong enough. You held the handle, but when I moved the bucket, I fell into the well. I hit my head and saw strange lights. Later, I realized they looked like stars in cartoons when someone gets hit.
At first, I was confused, then scared, then angry at you for letting me fall. I was also worried about what Mother would say. You called down to ask if I was okay. I didn't answer at first, but when you called again, I stayed quiet. You ran to get help. I quickly climbed out of the well and hid. I heard voices from the castle. Mother and Father came with you and Arthur. Mother was very upset. Father told Arthur to use the winch. You looked shocked.
I was hiding, feeling excited but then saw the wet spots I left on the ground. I was scared they would see them. Father was looking into the well with a flashlight. Mother was screaming, and I felt guilty. I wanted to get back at you, but now I was in trouble. I didn't think it would get this serious. I needed a plan.
I came out of hiding, pretending to be hurt. I told them I found a secret tunnel from the well to the moat and escaped. I thought they believed me until Father asked me to repeat the story. I added that the tunnel collapsed, so no one could check. Father didn't believe me. He looked at me like he saw me for the first time. He told me not to be ridiculous and walked away.
Arthur looked at me sadly. He knew I was lying and worried about what kind of person I would become. His look made me feel worse than Father's words. I realized they both saw through my lie, and it made me think about how I should act in the future.

**Moving Day**
Susan is a widow, and her children are grown up. She has to leave her family home. A van with "Removers of Distinction" written on it is there to help. Fred, the removal man, and his team are packing everything. Fred is careful with the breakable things. The house is beautiful, with four floors and a view of a small harbor. Susan remembers the years spent there with her children.
When they bought the house, her son Robert, who was five then, asked how they would bring the house home. Now, Robert is an adult and is helping with the move. He is making sure Susan doesn't talk about the piano. Francesca, her daughter, is also helping. She is very careful with the Steinway piano.
Fred, the removal man, says people often cry when they move. Susan understands why. She remembers when they first moved in. The piano was a problem because it got stuck on the stairs. Her husband Peter, who has passed away, solved the problem by using a crane to bring the piano through a window.
Now, Susan is older, and the stairs are hard for her. She worries about the piano again. Fred tells her they are almost done, just the piano is left. Susan feels emotional but doesn't cry. When the piano is safely moved, Robert and Francesca start laughing, and Susan joins them. They are happy and relieved. As they leave the house for the last time, they are laughing together.

'Online Book Reviews for Everyone
Writing your own book reviews online: is it just for fun? From the start, the Internet was meant to be open to everyone. In theory, anyone could write or share things online. But in the early days, you needed some technical skills. However, one area that became open to everyone was book reviews. On Amazon.com, the first big online bookstore, anyone could write a book review. Amazon's idea was simple: anyone could say what they thought about a book and give it up to five stars. Each book had its own page, and new reviews appeared automatically. This way, Amazon got free reviews, and people could see what other readers thought about a book, not just what the publisher or professional critics said. Other online bookstores did the same, but Amazon was the biggest, with over 80% of the online market. Because of this, Amazon had the most reviews and also some problems. Many reviews were submitted every day, so it was hard to check them all. Amazon had a team to make sure reviews followed their rules. For example, reviews with only one word, personal attacks, or spoilers were not allowed. But reviewers were anonymous, so some bad reviews were only removed if Amazon found them. This allowed for some tricks. For example, some writers gave their own books great reviews. One writer, Lev Grossman, wrote fake good reviews for his book after getting bad ones. He was caught when he wrote about his trick. Authors could also comment on their own books through a special link. Most authors used this to encourage people to buy their books. Some even shared their email addresses to talk directly with readers. However, Amazon did not always check if the comments really came from the author, except for famous writers. For example, a fake comment pretending to be from John Updike was removed. Problems mostly came from readers, not writers. When James McElroy's book about a cheerleading team was published, it got good reviews from the press. But people in the book felt upset and wrote angry reviews on Amazon. These reviews disappeared after a few days. Despite this, Amazon thought having many reviews was good for business. Reviews were meant to be a place to talk about books, not a chat room. So, Amazon watched popular books closely to make sure reviews followed the rules. Funny reviews were often found on less popular books. For example, a children's book called The Story about Ping inspired jokes because 'ping' is also a computer term. One review compared the book's story to the Internet and said it explained networking concepts. But most reviews on Amazon were serious. They gave a good idea of whether a book was worth buying. The writer George Orwell once said that reviewing too many books meant pretending to have feelings about them. This is why letting everyone review books is a good thing.'

**Art in Modern Times**
In the last 200 years, people think artists must be different from others. We like art that is new and surprising. We admire artists whose work was not liked 100 years ago. But today, we sometimes say an artist has gone too far and it is not art anymore. The media often say this, and we agree. We expect art to be new, so we do not see the old ideas in it. We think artists are special and different from us. In the past, people asked artists to make art for specific reasons. Now, artists work alone, and we get upset if they try to be like everyone else.
**Picture This**
I will describe a situation and ask a question. An artist picks a text from an art book. The text talks about different pictures and says, "There is no end to the number of different kinds of pictures." The artist asks someone to make a canvas and take it to a sign painter.
