The sign painter writes the text on the canvas in simple black letters. My question is: Is this a painting?
**Underground Encounters**
At the Mercury Gallery, London until 26th June
Artists usually stick to one style if it sells well. People like to see the same kind of art from an artist. But some artists try new things. Picasso and Hockney did this. Eric Rimmington is another artist trying something new. He is known for still life paintings but now paints the London Underground. He made drawings of railways in the 1980s and now paints the underground world. His show has 40 paintings and drawings of this hidden world.
**Extract from a Novel**
I have come to this island with a few books. The villagers say only a sick person would come here to rebuild. I am here to heal myself. Only an old woman from the village comes to clean the house. I am alone. I am not happy or sad. I think about memories. Art is not useless. It helps us see the important parts of life. Art is a way to deal with things that hurt us. It helps us use our imagination to understand life better. Otherwise, why do we hurt each other?

'Family Business'
"Look here, it's no good!" said my Dad. We were in the car going back to London. My father and my brother Maurice had just picked me up from my school. I had won two prizes: one for Latin and one for doing well in my exams. My father talked with my headteacher, and now we were going home for the holidays.
"What isn't good?" I asked, but I knew what he was thinking. My father usually talked a lot. "You can't fool me. You'll do what you want now," he said. "With all those certificates, I heard you will get a scholarship to Oxford."
"So?" I said, trying to be brave. "Mightn't that be useful?"
"I also heard," he continued, "that you want to be a barrister. A barrister of all things!" My father knew a lot about barristers and the law.
"I just said that," I replied. "I couldn't think of anything else to say!"
"And apparently," he went on, "you have the right personality - you can understand things quickly, you like talking, and you enjoy performing."
"I don't know about that," I said. "I only know what I see on TV."
"Anyway," he said, "I feel you won't want to join the family business now. You'll go to Oxford, and after that, I can't see you wanting it."
Like many children, I felt trapped by family expectations. I wanted to explore other jobs, but I didn't want to upset my father. I wasn't as scared of him as Maurice was - I was the favorite - but I found him strong.
"It's too soon to know," I said weakly.
"I tell you, you're not going to want to join us," my father said. "It's a pity because you have the gifts - the brains, the nerves, the vision."
"There's still Maurice," I said, unhappy. My father snorted. We both knew Maurice hated the business.
"You could always use me as a consultant," I added. My mother wasn't around to help - she died when I was young, and my father raised me and Maurice. Maurice was two years younger, and I often took care of him. I loved Maurice.
Because the business was successful, we lived well - a big house in London, good schools, nice clothes, parties, theatres, operas. My father knew many people - politicians, actors, businessmen - and our house was always lively.
"You can help us during holidays until you leave Oxford," my father said. "Then, if you decide to leave, you can. It will give you some pocket money and help me."
"OK," I said, happy to avoid making a decision now. My father would get upset if I opposed him. This was how he controlled us.
So it happened. In my last term at school and during university vacations, I helped out, never more than twice a year, and always on easy tasks. I became a smart student, with a little house, a small car, designer clothes, and a special dress for my final exams.
In my last term, my father visited me. He took me to a village for a meal and a chat. There were only a few weeks left. My tutor said I might get a First Class degree in Law. I felt confident and focused.
But my father told me he needed me for one last job. It was the most important work the family business had ever done, and he promised it would be worth it.
"But Dad," I said, "I have my final exams soon. I need to focus on them. It's really important."
I could tell my father didn't understand my pressure. Maybe he was jealous of my life away from him. He would see a refusal as a betrayal.
As he explained the job, I saw how focused and smart my father was. He was a kind of genius, and I respected that. It made my own plans seem less important.
"All right," I said. "I'll do it."

Simon Costello realized that buying the house in Pembroke Square was a mistake after living there for a year with his wife, Lois. They could only afford it by being very careful with money, which was not a good idea. At first, it seemed like a good decision because Simon had many successful cases, and Lois got a raise at her advertising job, making thirty-five thousand. Lois wanted to move because their flat was too small for a family, and they needed more space, a garden, and a place for an au pair. They could have found this in a cheaper area, but Lois wanted a better address for their careers. 
Lois decided that one of them should use public transport to save money. Since her job was far, Simon had to take the crowded tube, which made him unhappy. He often thought about his grandfather's house in Hampstead, where he was treated well after a long day. But times had changed, and Lois made it clear that her career was as important as his. They needed both their salaries to maintain their lifestyle.
Now, their life was at risk because of Venetia. She came to their office very upset after court. Someone had made her very angry. Simon wished he had left his room earlier to avoid her. Venetia accused him of knowing that a client, Brian Cartwright, bribed the jury four years ago and did nothing. She also said Cartwright gave shares to Simon's fiancée before the trial. Simon denied it, but he felt guilty and knew his denial was weak. He wished he had said something different. Venetia's anger confused him. He wondered why she cared so much and if she was right to threaten his career. If people heard about this, even as a rumor, it could ruin him.

I chose this place to live because I thought I could be anonymous. I believed people here wouldn't care if the houses were old and the gardens were messy. But I was wrong. People in the shops soon started to recognize me. The roses next door remind me that the gardens were once loved. Usually, I stay inside, but tonight I am watching birds fly between the trees and roofs. I cut back some plants to make space for a chair, and my arms are scratched. It is a small London garden where plants grow tall. 
My neighbor, Jaz, leans out of her window. She writes books that are not published, and sometimes I have to talk about them because I am an English teacher. I have her latest book now. "How's the work going, Jaz?" I ask. "In no other job do people ask you about your work all the time," she says. Then she offers to bring a drink. I don't want Jaz in the garden, and I see it looks messy. The only way to the garden is through my flat, and Jaz is knocking on my door. "You're on holiday now," she says. She sits on a chair while I put a cushion on the grass. "Cheers," she says. "I should have been a teacher. Writers don't have holidays. They say, those who can, do, those who can't, teach." 
She asks about my holiday plans. I feel worried about the school year ending. Empty days, hot streets, and loneliness. "I'm going to Stonebridge tomorrow. Can you feed the cats?" I ask. My heart races. "Of course," Jaz says. "If I'm around," knowing she will be. "Where will you stay?" she asks. "With my friend Ruby at the Rising Sun," I say. It's not true, but I often deal with fiction. "Going back to your roots. What do you think of my book?" Jaz asks. Her book, The Cruelty of Red Vans, is on my desk. I like the title and tell her. I decide to be honest. "Try writing about nice people," I suggest. "Teachers!" Jaz says, upset. "I keep a journal," I say. "I write something good about each day." "Keep a journal! Nice people! Get a life, Ann," Jaz replies. 
I have a life. I have my work, and I go out sometimes. When we go inside, my kitchen feels calm. Then I remember my school geography teacher, Miss Tarrantine, who would wink and say, "I've had my moments." We almost died laughing.

Heritage Heritage is important because it helps people feel connected to the past. We often know about our grandparents and their stories. But we also need to learn about our past to understand our future. Heritage gives us a sense of belonging and continuity. It is like inheriting genes; we also inherit culture from our ancestors. Even if there are parts of our heritage we don't like, it is still ours. Heritage teaches us a lot and is important for our well-being. It affects our customs and the things we use. In the past, we learned about our history through stories from our ancestors. But now, because of changes in society, many of these stories are lost. Instead, we learn from places and buildings. It is important to keep these links to remember our ancestors. The Fens I wrote a book called Waterland, which is set in a part of England called the Fens. People ask why I, a person from London, wrote about a place I don't know well. I chose the Fens because they seemed simple and empty, a good place for my story. But I found out that the Fens are not empty. They are very English but also strange. Many English people find the Fens foreign, even though they are in the middle of England. The Fens are both empty and full, wild and cultivated, open and mysterious. I did not visit many places in the Fens while writing my book. I like to imagine places rather than just describe them. The Fens are not just a place; they are a way of thinking. Museums Museums should make their collections easy to see and understand. In the past, museums just put things in cases with long labels. Now, they should make displays interesting and use techniques to catch people's attention. Museums should also reach out to the community. For example, they can lend objects to schools or use them to help elderly people with memory loss. Museums show real objects, not copies. They help people see and understand things from the past. This is what makes them different from theme parks or books. Museums that make their displays exciting and accessible will find that people want to see the real things they offer. Architecture and Environment People have always wanted to keep things from the past. But now, towns change quickly, and this affects everyone. Some people want to preserve everything, while others think about how towns should look in the future. People who have lived through big events, like wars, often want to keep things stable. If people need to preserve things, planners should consider this. Change is not bad if we know how to manage it. Changes in our towns show changes in our society, like how many people live there and what they need.

**Einstein**  
If you ask someone to name a scientist, they will probably say Albert Einstein. His face is used in ads for smart things like computers and encyclopedias. Many people don't know much about what Einstein did, except that he made some difficult theories called 'relativity'. These theories are famous for being hard to understand and for having strange ideas that are different from what we see every day. Einstein was part of a big change in science in the 20th century. Scientists were trying to understand the universe better by studying matter and forces. Einstein helped by looking at time, space, matter, and energy in a new way. Before, people thought like Isaac Newton, who said stars and planets moved in a fixed space and time. Einstein said time and space are not fixed but change depending on other things.
**Young Readers**  
When we were kids, Lydia and I didn't like books that won prizes because we thought they would be boring. Our mom didn't like that we thought this way, but our dad would give us small amounts of money to read these books. He would also give us some of these books as gifts, saying they were not just for learning. We thought most of these books were for boys, but sometimes we found some good short stories and poems.
**Language**  
In 1851, Jacob Grimm said that the start of human language is a big mystery. Many strange ideas have come from this mystery. In 1928, Charles Caller said early humans made sounds like "meuh" when they were scared. These sounds were sad, and languages kept some of these sounds, like the word "malaria" for fever or "mors" in Latin for death. Because of these strange ideas, many people didn't want to talk about how language started. But now, it is an important area of study. Language probably started in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. It was mainly used for friendly talking and was important in power struggles. Sharing information was not the main reason for language, even though philosopher John Locke thought language was for sharing knowledge.

'Writing Reviews Frank Kermode talks about how to write reviews. Most reviews are written quickly and do not last long. They have deadlines and are usually short. Once published, they are only read for a short time, like a day or a week. People often think reviews are not very important. Many writers do reviews because they need money or because they cannot work on big projects all the time. But writing reviews is a skill. It is different to write a short review for a newspaper than a long one for a journal. Reviewers must think about who will read their review. Some readers just skim, while others are very interested in the topic. A reviewer needs to know a lot about many things and write clearly. Reviewers often write other things too. For example, the American writer John Updike writes reviews between writing his novels. He collects his reviews in books. Some people think only famous writers should keep their reviews, but others believe anyone can if they want to. I feel this way about my own work. I am a professor, and my main job is academic writing. But in English-speaking countries, it is normal for professors to write reviews too. In the past, some people thought professors should not write reviews, but now it is common. There is more reviewing work now, so many people can do it. I think this is good for readers because they know the reviewer understands the topic. It is also good for professors because it helps them communicate better with people who are not professors. Writing reviews is a secondary job. You can only do it well if you are also doing something else well.'

Ralph opened the door to his apartment. It was dark and quiet inside. Even after three years, he sometimes felt unsure about owning it. When he first bought the apartment, he was excited to come home. He wondered what the apartment was like when he was not there. It felt like a safe place for him. He thought he should worry about things like burglars or broken pipes, but the apartment was always there waiting for him. Sometimes it was tidy, and sometimes it was messy.
Ralph started to see the apartment as part of himself. He wanted it to change, but it stayed the same. Sometimes there were letters by the door or messages on the answering machine. He was glad the windows were not broken and nothing was stolen. From his boring office on Holloway Road, Ralph looked forward to spending time alone at home. After leaving work, he felt more like himself on the bus ride home. But once he was home, he felt empty and lonely. He thought his job, which he did not like, had changed him.
Ralph often read or listened to music at night. But he wondered why he did these things. He felt lost and confused. He remembered a time when he felt stronger and thought he could have done something different with his life. After university, he wanted to improve himself but only wanted to survive quietly. He applied for jobs his friends talked about and followed their paths. He went to one job interview for a local newspaper. He was happy to have a nice conversation with Neil, his boss, and did not think much about the job itself. Neil offered him the job because Ralph was the only graduate who applied. Ralph took this as a compliment.

**Goat Racing**
I was going to see goat racing. It was Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. There were many ice-cream vans, lots of people, food stalls, and loud music. Everyone was moving towards the racecourse. I pushed through the crowd to find a good spot. They made a special area for the race. It was not like big racecourses, but people stood on both sides to watch. They tried to keep the goats in order. It was not easy because goats like to eat everything.
**Canoe Trip**
As the day ended, I thought about the night. I was scared. The canoe was too wet to sleep in, and there was no place to stop. We did not see any villages or huts since morning. In the moonlight, we used a torch to see the cliffs. The torch batteries were low, so we put in new ones, but they did not work. We could not find a camping place. A few miles later, Lesley saw a light, and we were happy. But it was just moonlight on the waves. We heard loud water, but we could not see it. Time felt slow, and we kept moving.
**How to be Good at Presentations**
I am not good at making presentations. But as a managing director, I have to present to my colleagues and big shareholders. How can I get better and feel more confident? 
You are not alone. Presenting is different from running a company. Many senior executives need to be good at it. If you want to convince people, you must believe in what you say. Show your passion and enthusiasm. Do your homework. Test your ideas before the presentation. Ask colleagues to think of tough questions the audience might ask. Start with something everyone agrees on and slowly build to your main point.

Some things take time and cannot be rushed. For example, if you add oil too quickly when making mayonnaise, it will not turn out right. If you pull too hard on a tangled fishing line, the knot will get tighter. Our minds also work at different speeds. Some things we can do quickly, like solving puzzles, but other things need more time. If we rush them, they might not work well.
There are three speeds at which our mind works. The first is very fast, faster than thinking. This is when we react quickly without thinking, like when a motorbike skids and we automatically know what to do to stay safe. This quick reaction is called our 'wits'.
The second speed is thinking itself. This is when we solve problems by thinking carefully, like a mechanic fixing an engine or a student doing homework. We call this 'intellect'. People who are good at this are often called 'bright' or 'clever'.
The third speed is slower and more relaxed. This is when we think in a dreamy or playful way, like when we are sitting by the sea and listening to the waves. This slow thinking is important too. It helps us understand complex problems that are not clear. Sometimes, when we have a difficult decision to make, like changing jobs, it is better to think slowly and carefully.
Scientists are now studying this slow way of thinking. They find that it can help us learn new things and solve difficult problems. This slow thinking is linked to creativity and wisdom. Poets and philosophers have always known about this way of thinking, and now scientists are learning more about it too.

**Surviving in a Foreign Land**
I am in a friendly place, but it is very far away from other places. There are about forty people here, like scientists and students. Everyone helps each other. I can speak a little French, but not very well. I cannot understand jokes or small talk. I feel nervous at mealtimes because I am not sure where to sit or what to say. I smile a lot and sometimes feel sad because I cannot talk like I used to. I miss being able to talk easily with people.
**Elliot**
When I first met Elliot, I was a new writer, and he did not pay much attention to me. He remembered faces, though, and would shake my hand when we met. If he was with important people, he sometimes pretended not to see me. But when I became a successful playwright, Elliot started to like me more. He invited me to lunch, and I thought he wanted to know me better. After my success, I saw him more often.
**Alfred Hitchcock**
Alfred Hitchcock was a famous film director. He said he did not care much about the story or acting in his films. He cared about the pictures and sounds. He believed that if a film was made well, people from different countries would feel the same emotions. Hitchcock was very smart and knew how to make people feel scared or excited. He focused on making films that made people react, no matter where they were from.

**Amateur Astronomy**
Astronomy has changed a lot in the last 50 years. About 30 years ago, there were not many charts or books about astronomy. Telescopes were not very good. Now, you can buy many different telescopes and equipment. Computers help make charts and analyze observations. This is a great time for amateur astronomers. But, some things are not as good. You might need to travel 80 km to see a clear sky, like in cities 50 years ago. Airplanes leave trails in the sky that can turn into clouds, making it hard to see the sun or stars.
**Too Much Choice**
Today, there are too many choices. There are many things to do and buy. New products come out very fast. This can make people feel tired and stressed. More choices mean more stress and less time. People are looking for simple things that make life better. But, it is hard to make life simple when there are so many things to choose from. There are more types of soap and cereal than we need, and many software updates and phone plans.
**McAndrews Hotel**
Every summer, we stay for two weeks at McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. It is a family tradition started by my grandmother. We do not let anything change this tradition. The people who stay at McAndrews are like us: old-fashioned and maybe a bit snobbish. I do not like rude shop assistants or waiters who act too friendly. I know most of the guests because they have been coming here since they were children. We greet each other politely but do not talk much. It is nice to have privacy and respect, which is hard to find in hotels today.

**Othello**
A special play called "Othello" by Shakespeare moved from Stratford to London. I want to say sorry for a bad review I wrote when the play first started last spring. I said Ray Fearon, who plays Othello, was too young. I was wrong about his acting. He is very good. The whole cast is great. There are many memorable scenes. One is when Cassio plays games with other officers, and it gets dangerous. Another is when Iago starts to lose control. A very moving scene is when Emilia helps Desdemona get ready for bed. The play is exciting and full of tension. You should see it.
**Lake Vostok**
In the middle of Antarctica, it is very quiet. There are many penguins, seals, and birds at the edges. But in the center, there is no life. Except for a big lake called Lake Vostok under 4 kilometers of ice. It is the coldest place on earth. The water has been without air and sunlight for up to 25 million years. Scientists are excited to explore it and find new organisms. Geologists and glaciologists also want to study it. For two years, researchers have been planning to uncover the lake's secrets. In the next few years, we will learn a lot about Lake Vostok.
**Scientists**
There was something interesting on the radio last week. Scientists are talking about why they want to be scientists. They want to know why we want to learn about everything, like atoms and black holes. They wonder why science cannot explain why we want to know things. It is important to know if what scientists do is right. Science is a tool, and we should decide how to use it.

**Food**
Food is very important and makes us happy. Many people like cooking and buy cookbooks. Sometimes, we think we need a special occasion to cook something nice, but that's not true. You can make a tasty soup by putting some chopped carrots, a leek, celery, and herbs in water. This is better than buying soup from a packet or a can. Instead of buying a chocolate mousse with many chemicals, you can make a delicious one in five minutes that everyone will love. Cooking is a way to show care and love. We often celebrate special events like birthdays and weddings with food. We don't usually have takeaway food for these events. Sharing food is important for people.
**In the Elevator**
This morning, Alistair tried to clean his office, but there was still a lot of paper everywhere. He had tax forms and other papers in drawers and boxes. He also had many books and journals near the new bookshelves. As he went up in the elevator, he knew Mallory would be on time for their meeting. She was always on time and liked things to be neat. He wondered what she would think of the mess. Maybe she would think someone had made a mess on purpose. Mrs. Wilson, the cleaning lady, came while he was trying to clean. He smiled at her, hoping she would help, but she didn't want to clean his office. She only cleaned his apartment.
**KAREN**
Karen wanted to be different from her mother. She made her own story about being strong. When she was twelve, her brother accidentally hit her in the eye with a golf club. She thought she was blind, but the doctor said she was okay. She only needed a few stitches. When she saw her mother in the doctor's office, she felt she was saved for a reason.
**Miss Fogerty**
Miss Fogerty was walking across the village green. She felt both happy and sad about what she had just seen. In a small village, it is exciting to know something first. But she was very sad about Dr. Bailey's condition. He had been her doctor for many years and helped her with her throat problems. Dr. Bailey was very kind and always listened to his patients. The village loved him because he gave his time, knowledge, and humor. People were very loyal and cared for him.

Joanna's Lessons
Joanna MacGregor is a busy concert pianist. She also writes books for young children learning the piano. Joanna is very talented and plays many types of music like classical, jazz, and blues. At a concert for kids, a boy asked her to play "Match of the Day." Joanna found it funny and played it, making the boy happy.
Joanna cares about how children learn the piano. She wrote a book called "Joanna MacGregor's Piano World" for beginners. Even though she is very busy, she thinks the first piano lessons are very important. She believes music should be for everyone, not just for those who want to be stars.
When Joanna was young, she saw many children learning piano at her home because her mother was a piano teacher. She learned that music should be fun and for everyone. Some kids learn fast, but others take their time. Joanna is interested in helping all children enjoy music.
Joanna thinks some parents push their kids too hard in music, like in sports. She wants kids to enjoy music without pressure. Her books have stories and CDs to make learning fun. She believes practice is important, but it should be enjoyable. Joanna says it's okay to make mistakes and mix easy and hard pieces when practicing.

**Writing by Hand and on Screen**
Dr. Johnson said that writing without effort is not enjoyable to read. This means good writing is hard to do. When I look at my old school essays, I see few mistakes. Today, I would rewrite them many times. I think this is because writing by hand is slow and makes you think carefully. It is hard to change or erase, so you write with care. But with computers, it is easy to be careless. Many writers spend as much time fixing computer drafts as they did writing by hand. Emails, unlike handwritten letters, can feel heavy with emotion. People say emails have brought back the love letter. Many love emails are sent now, which is good. But words on a screen can feel boring. Writers may not know the power of words and can exaggerate. Quick writing on a computer lacks the care of handwriting.
**The CD**
I put down my cup and looked at the CD. The case was not special, but the shiny disc was interesting. "Wonderful little things, aren't they?" Mr. Warriston said. I agreed and gave him the disc. "Amazing they hold seventy minutes of music," he said, turning on the music player. Lights came on, and he put the disc in. "Some say they sound sterile, but I think they..." "Do you have to turn them over, like records?" I asked. "No," he said. "You only play one side." "Why?" I asked. He didn't know. "You could have two lasers or turn it over by hand," he said. He smiled. "Good point." He showed me the best place to sit for the stereo sound. I was happy to ask a question he couldn't answer.
**Books versus Electronic Text**
Malcolm Bradbury said if matches came after lighters, we would think they are better. People say electronic text is like the invention of printing. But changes in how we think take a long time. In 1979, a book said books would disappear in the 1980s. That was wrong. Reading long texts on a screen is not fun, so people don't do it. Computers make people read bits of text. Some say this leads to new ways of storytelling. But reading parts of a book is not new. Many books, like religious texts and dictionaries, are not read from start to finish. Computers don't encourage reading everything in one go.
**The Office**
Charles walked into the office. It was neat and tidy. The carpet was clear, and the desk was dark wood. Files were in drawers, and journals were on shelves. Kathleen said, "You need to use computers, Charles. This is too much." "Hello, Kathleen. This is amazing," he said, looking at the room. He didn't think about computers. They had talked about this many times. She didn't understand why he didn't like technology, even though he was good with computers and wrote a paper about it. She inspired that paper. She could use software in creative ways.

"You don't take sugar, do you?" shouted his secretary. She wasn't really asking because she had been making Lancelot coffee for many months. She sometimes forgot because he wasn't supposed to be there often. But now, he was there all the time. He found out that if he stayed away, things would go wrong. He thought about how he went from being an important advisor, meeting authors and playwrights for lunch, to being very busy with no time to park his car in the morning. "This came," she yelled, waving a folder and putting it in front of him. "From that guy in Los Angeles. You said you wanted to see it." The label said: "A World History of the Short, by Ian Cuthbert." It also said "An Expanded Synopsis." Lancelot did not want to see another synopsis. He wanted to see a "First Draft." Ian Cuthbert had been given a lot of money for this book when Lancelot bought the company. Ian was an old friend, but he was not easy to work with. Lancelot read the synopsis and saw nothing new. He closed the folder and put it aside. Ian's manuscript seemed like it would never come. The synopsis was not brilliant, and it felt like Ian had lost interest. Lancelot remembered a story about a famous author who was paid little by little for his book. But Ian had already been paid a lot. Lancelot studied modern languages at Oxford and remembered when Ian was a promising talent at Cambridge. Ian's friends took over British theatre quickly, but Ian was even more talented. He wore his coat like a cape and talked about famous writers as if he knew them. But Ian's talent stayed hidden. While others succeeded, Ian became more difficult. He was supposed to edit an arts magazine, but it never came out. He had a contract with a fashion magazine, but he didn't produce much. At meetings, he was clever but critical. Ten years later, he was unreliable. Lancelot was starting to think that "A World History of the Short" was a mistake from the beginning.

'Breakfast in England
Health experts say breakfast is very important. But in history, breakfast is quite new in England. In medieval times, people did not talk much about breakfast. Sometimes, travelers ate early before long trips, and sick people had breakfast for health reasons. But most people did not eat breakfast unless they were kings or nobles.
In the sixteenth century, breakfast became normal for everyone. Some people think this is because there was more food available. But there were also big social changes. For example, people started working fixed hours and often began work very early. So, eating in the morning became necessary, not just for rich people.'

Photography When a photographer takes a picture, they choose what to show based on their skills, personal ideas, and experiences. They also think about what society and culture expect. In this book, we will learn how these things change the style and meaning of a photo. We will also see how people look at and feel about these photos. For example, when someone reads a newspaper, they might think they understand the photos. But we can ask if the photo shows the scene exactly as it was. Or does it show what the photographer thinks? Is the exact moment in the photo important, or is the photo a symbol of something bigger in the world?
More than a game Sport is more than just a game for me. The best people in sport believe in themselves completely. You need to focus only on your goal to be the best. Sport is tough, and no one will do it for you. You have to succeed or fail on your own. Sport has taught me to be disciplined and determined. It also shows how to work well in a team. My sport lets you be great alone, but it is also a team game. You have to balance these two things. It's like life - you can do well alone, but you must remember others are around you. Sport has given me a lot, not just money. It has opened new opportunities for me and let me see things around the world. But you also have to give up a lot for these benefits.
Tuning in Some experiences stay in our memory very clearly. For me, one special moment happened one night in California many years ago. I was awake, listening to a bird singing beautifully in a tree. I don't usually have trouble sleeping, but the bird's song was so amazing that I stayed awake. The bird's music reminded me of jazz and Indian classical music. It felt like the bird was giving a special performance with many surprising changes. I listened and enjoyed the music until I finally fell asleep.

People have always had strong feelings about birds. But what do these feelings say about us? Paul Evans writes about this. 
There is a noise coming from the greenhouse. A small brown bird is hitting the glass. It is a wren. Some people think wrens bring messages or signs. Is the wren trying to tell me something? Or is it just stuck in the greenhouse? Maybe both are true. 
Wrens have been part of British culture for a long time. In the past, people watched wrens to see if they would have good or bad luck. Today, we still see wrens in pictures and decorations in British homes. Even if old beliefs are forgotten, people still like wrens. A forest without wrens feels empty. 
Many birds are part of our stories and traditions. In the past, people needed to understand nature to survive. They created stories about birds to explain their importance. These stories can change over time. 
For example, the red kite was once common in London. People liked them because they cleaned the streets. But later, people thought they were pests, and they disappeared from most places except Wales. Now, red kites are protected and are a symbol of nature conservation in Britain. 
Our connection with birds is very old. Early humans watched birds to know about danger, weather, and food. Birds also connected them to their dreams. Birds are important to us because they represent things like flight, song, and freedom. 
Some people think our feelings about birds are old and not needed now. But losing these feelings is hard. Birds show us how the environment is changing. In Britain, 30 bird species are in danger. This is sad because we lose not only the birds but also their cultural stories. 
For example, the skylark, turtle dove, and lapwing are linked to love and magic in stories and poems. Losing these birds is a big loss. But birds not in stories are often ignored. 
Stories and legends about birds are important. They connect us to birds in a way that science cannot. These stories help us feel and understand birds better. 
Whether we watch birds on TV or in our gardens, the joy we feel is hard to explain with science. Birds are special, and the stories we tell about them help us understand their messages. The wren in the greenhouse is like a puzzle, connecting the past, present, and future.

'Maps A map shows how places and features on the earth are related to each other. This is shown by distance and direction. In the past, people often measured distance by time, like 'a few hours' walk' or 'a day's journey by river'. This told more about how easy it was to travel the land than the real distance. Direction was also important, but for most travelers, the main questions were 'Where do I go from here?' and 'How far is it?'. Because of this, written travel guides were popular for a long time. Even today, some maps, like train maps, do not show true directions. Early maps used signs to show important landmarks along a route. These signs could be realistic or simple and were different sizes to show their importance. The way maps were made changed depending on their purpose and where they were made. To understand old maps, it is important to know the map's style. The history of making maps is about making distance and direction more accurate and adding more information to maps. Map making has used other sciences to help. For example, instead of using shadows or stars to find direction, people used the magnetic compass. New tools helped measure angles accurately. As people learned more about the world, they tried to map it. Astronomers found out that the earth is not a perfect sphere but is slightly flat at the poles. This changed how large areas were mapped. Over time, different people needed maps for different reasons. Soldiers needed accurate maps for planning battles. Archaeologists, historians, and geographers also needed special maps. Today, map makers create maps showing many things, like weather, land use, and more. Maps are now important for understanding many sciences. The development of maps has not always been smooth. Sometimes, old ideas stayed even when new ones came. Map makers often knew how to improve maps but had to wait for better tools. Since it is easy to copy old maps, some map makers did not want to change. So, maps should not always be seen as perfect evidence of what people knew at the time. Many maps we have today show a lot of human work and thought. They are important for learning about the past. This makes studying old maps interesting and educational.'

'TIM RICE I was invited into a young man's living room. It was a nice and calm place, different from the messy rooms around it. Moving from the kitchen to his room felt like going from economy to business class on a plane. He had the largest collection of records I had ever seen and the first stereo record player I had come across. He also had Georgian wine glasses, pictures, and furniture. His name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had won a scholarship to Magdalen College, Oxford, to study history, and he had nine months before starting. During this time, he wanted to become England's answer to the composer Richard Rodgers. I also had big dreams. I wanted to be a pop star for reasons like women, money, and fame. The difference between Andrew and me was that my dreams were not as serious to me. But when Andrew suggested I try to become a famous lyricist like Oscar Hammerstein, I decided to give it a try. Andrew played me three tunes he had composed, and I could tell he was very good. He played more music from shows he had written at school, and it reminded me of the best show albums from my parents' collection. He needed a new lyricist for the outside world. I didn't have much to impress him with, except for praising his music and a single song I had written that an unknown pop group had recorded. We promised to meet again and write something together. I was still more interested in pop music than in theater, but I thought I had met someone with rare talent and determination. I didn't want to miss the chance to work with him. Even if we didn't succeed in musical theater, we could try to compete with famous bands like the Beatles and Rolling Stones later. The next day, back at my desk where I was training to become a lawyer, my excitement about a life in show business with Andrew had faded a bit. I would still look for groups needing a vocalist and write simple songs that suited my voice. But it seemed likely I would become a lawyer by the time I was twenty-five. My father thought I would stop liking pop music by the time I was twenty-one, which worried me. But I felt I had nothing to lose by seeing Andrew again. It would be fun to write musical lyrics instead of pop songs. Andrew was interesting and talked about good food and Victorian architecture. He also supported Leyton Orient football team. I wasn't sure about the musical idea he was working on, about Dr. Thomas Barnardo, who founded orphanages. The story was good but didn't excite me. It was too similar to the show Oliver. However, Andrew believed in his music, and his confidence was contagious. I didn't know much about musicals, but I thought we could be successful. I started writing lyrics with enthusiasm, especially for the funny songs. Andrew told me the plot, played the tunes, and sometimes gave me the title. I skipped a day at the office, pretending to be sick, to write my first theatrical lyrics. I didn't know it then, but I had changed my career.'

**Language**
Humans have a special ability. We can use language to share ideas with each other. Language is very important in our lives. It is hard to think about life without it. If you see two or more people together, they will probably start talking. When people are alone, they might talk to themselves, their pets, or even their plants. I think of language as an 'instinct'. This means people know how to talk naturally, like spiders know how to make webs. Spiders did not learn to make webs from school or special training.
**Climate and Weather**
Climate and weather are made by the air around us. They are very important for animals and plants. Climate can change how a place looks. For example, warm and wet places can have tropical jungles with many different plants and animals. Cold and windy places have fewer living things. Weather changes every day, and over time, it becomes the climate. Air moves because the earth spins, and the sun also makes the air move.
**Coffee**
I worked as a bar-person, serving drinks and making coffee. In Lygon Street, Melbourne, coffee is very important for restaurants. I had to learn a lot about making coffee and taking care of the espresso machine. I learned how to make a good cappuccino. At first, I thought making coffee was hard, and I might have to do easier jobs like cleaning ashtrays. But my boss was patient. He said, "Making coffee is both an art and a science, and you need time to learn it."

**Art on TV**
Why does TV often not do well with shows about art? Painting and sculpture should be easy for TV because the camera can show a whole artwork and then zoom in on details. But there are not many TV series that show both the fun and the complexity of looking at art. A good example is Robert Hughes's series about American art, called "American Visions." Hughes is a critic you can trust, and he has a strong personality. He had almost eight hours to show British viewers American art, which British galleries often ignore. I thought the series would focus on great artworks. Instead, it was about how American history and culture are shown in its art and buildings.
**Dealing in Metals**
For 20 years, I worked as a metals dealer and became known for taking risks. Metals are less controlled than other markets. With some luck, a willingness to take risks, and a good understanding of the market, you can make a lot of money. Risk-taking is a big part of this industry. This fits well with a free-market global economy. But now, the free-trade economists who said the market would keep metal prices high have found the opposite. More minerals are being taken out, and the cost of raw materials is going down. Considering inflation, most metal prices are about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to look into claims against a big company that benefits from these cheap raw materials.
**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**
Abaco and its small islands are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas. They stretch from Florida to Cuba. Each island is different and has something special. To get around Abaco and its islands, you need a boat. If your room doesn't come with a boat, don't worry. There are many ferries and water-taxis. You can also rent a boat if you want to go by yourself. Sailing is very popular here. Abaco is called 'The Sailing Capital of the World' because of its calm waters. These waters are great for fishing, diving, snorkeling, and swimming. The islands and their beaches stretch for 200 miles like a string of pearls. At night, the lights of the restaurants and cafes in Hope Town and Green Turtle Cay shine brightly.

Title: Build Your Own Bamboo Bike in the UK
At the Bamboo Bike Club in London, you can join a course to build your own bamboo bike. The club is run by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan. On a Saturday morning in Hackney Wick, east London, you can hear the sound of machines working at the Bamboo Bike Club. This is the only place in the UK where you can learn to build a bamboo bike.
Bamboo bikes are becoming popular again. Companies like Calfee Design in California and Bamboo Bikes in Yorkshire are making them. But these bikes are expensive, costing about $2,995 or £1,868. James and Ian wanted to make bamboo bikes cheaper and more fun to build. They spent years working on this idea in a shed in Wales.
Instead of just selling bikes, James and Ian wanted to share the joy of making them. So, they started the Bamboo Bike Club. They both have other jobs—James works with wind turbines and Ian is a civil engineer. But they love teaching people how to build bikes.
In the course, you learn how to choose strong bamboo and make strong joints. You start by building the front part of the bike with bamboo tubes. Metal tubes are used for parts that need extra strength, like the handlebars and wheel forks. James and Ian help you with every step, making sure everything is done right.
Most people who join the course enjoy building their own bike. Even if you make a mistake, you can try again with a new piece of bamboo. On the second day, you wrap the joints with hemp and glue them to make them strong. After adding a waterproof coating, the bike is ready for wheels, brakes, and other parts.
Bamboo bikes are strong and can last a long time. Ian has used his bike for over a year, and James has tested one off-road for three months. The bikes may look a bit different from professional ones, but they are unique. They are also light and smooth to ride.
The cost of building your own bamboo bike at the club is less than £500.

**Self-help Books**
Dione Reverend was an editor at Random House in New York. She found a book by Dr. John Gray, a pop psychologist. She thought the book would be a big hit, and she was right. Dr. Gray is now very rich, and Dione Reverend has her own company. Dr. Gray's book helps people understand how men and women can talk better to each other. This book is part of a big self-help industry in America. Many people want to improve their lives, and these books try to help them. The self-help industry is also important for book publishers in New York. In Britain, many self-help books are published, but not all are good. Many books are not published because they are too similar to others. When looking for new books, editors think about how well they can sell. They ask questions like, "Is the author interesting? Is the book idea good for many people?" Dione Reverend says a good title is very important.
**Autobiographies**
When someone writes an autobiography, they make a promise to tell the truth. But often, writers do not tell everything. They might feel too embarrassed to share some things. Or they might think some details are not important. Sometimes, writers change the truth to make their story better. They might even call their book an autobiography to make readers believe it is true, even if it is not. This is not always done to trick people.
**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**
Detective stories became popular in the late 1800s and early 1900s. These stories show the problems in society. A crime in the story shows human desires like greed. Solving the crime helps society work well again. In Hammett's stories, society is not perfect. The detective and the criminal are similar. The detective understands the criminal. He is both a good guy and a bit of a bad guy. The detective's job is sometimes hard because he feels close to the criminal.
**Science Writing**
Stephen Jay Gould is a famous science writer. I met him at a hotel to talk about writing. We both felt a bit out of place there. Gould says that to write well, you need to understand the culture you are writing about. Science is like its own world, and only scientists can explain it well. Gould believes you should not make things too simple for readers. You can use simple words, but the ideas should stay strong. If readers feel you are talking down to them, they will not like your writing.

**Air-conditioning**
At Cannons Gym in London, it feels very cold because they use a lot of air-conditioning. This summer is very hot, so the gym uses air-conditioning to keep cool. Sometimes, it feels as cold as the Arctic inside. Many places use air-conditioning too much. Instead, they could use other ways to stay cool. For example, they could use natural light and air, and have thicker walls to keep the heat out during the day and let it go at night. These ideas can help reduce the need for air-conditioning.
**Sundials**
Sundials are tools that tell time by the sun's position. People are interested in them again as we start a new millennium. A hundred years ago, sundials were important for keeping time. But when clocks and watches got better, sundials became just garden decorations. Now, people are using them again. David Harber, who makes sundials, says they are special because they connect us to the planets. When a sundial starts working, it feels magical. They are calm and remind us of our place in the universe.
**Paint Your Own China**
I once saw older women painting china at an arts and crafts show. They painted flowers on teacups with perfect brushstrokes. Their hands were steady, and the paint was perfect. I thought only very skilled people could do this. But when I visited a china-painting class, I found it was not scary. The students were there to have fun, and even the teacher did not want to paint quickly like a machine.

Title: The Wrong Country
Uncle found a holiday for Keith and Dawne. It was a good price. They would fly from Gatwick Airport and stay twelve nights in Venice at the Pensione Concordia. When they went to book the trip, the travel agent said they would be with a school group learning Italian. But something went wrong. Instead of Venice, Keith and Dawne ended up in Switzerland at the Edelweiss Hotel, Room 212.
At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She checked their tickets and said everything was fine. On the plane, they heard people speaking with North of England accents. Keith thought maybe the Italian class was on another plane. They ordered drinks and relaxed.
When they arrived, a woman with glasses told everyone to stay together. Keith thought it was just an overnight stop. But the next morning, they realized they were staying there for the whole holiday. The receptionist said they could enjoy the lake and take a boat to Interlaken. Keith told the receptionist there was a mistake. They were supposed to be in Venice. The receptionist said their group was booked for twelve nights in Switzerland.
Dawne described the travel agent who booked their trip. A woman named Mrs. Franks, who they saw at Gatwick, said there are many holidays with similar tickets. She laughed and said they couldn't end up in a wildlife park by mistake. Keith insisted they were not meant to be in Switzerland. Mrs. Franks left to check, and the receptionist was gone too.
An old couple, Mr. and Mrs. Nottage, talked to Keith and Dawne. They said they slept well because of the fresh air. Keith and Dawne realized they were on a holiday with elderly people. They wanted to escape the needs of the elderly, but now they were on a trip with them.

'HE WAS A PEOPLE PERSON American business leaders are learning from the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton. Eluned Price reports. Many people in Britain know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and what he did. In America, he is becoming popular now. The Wall Street Journal called Shackleton 'an Antarctic explorer whose achievements were mostly unnoticed for most of the 20th century.' But now, Americans are very interested in him. Books about Shackleton's journey on the Endurance are being written, and they are expected to sell quickly. The American Museum of Natural History is having a big exhibition, and Columbia Tristar is making a movie about Shackleton's life. Some American managers see Shackleton as a role model. They talk about his actions with admiration and learn lessons in leadership and communication from him. They even say they are 'speaking Shackleton.' Shackleton, who was determined and resourceful, is now a model for modern management consultants. Jim MacGregor, a manager in New York, has used Shackleton as a role model for years. His company helps with communication during business problems. For example, if a company's factory explodes or if many workers lose their jobs. Shackleton worked in public relations for a Glasgow steel company, but it might be hard to see how surviving in cold weather relates to managing a business crisis. 'Even if a company handles its problems well, it can still cause harm by not communicating well,' says MacGregor. 'Shackleton is a model for management because he was a good leader and communicator. He had strong values and was at his best when he and his team had a lot to lose, like their lives. One of Shackleton's most important decisions was to turn back when he was only 97 miles from the South Pole. This decision showed his credibility for the next expedition: the lives of his men were most important.' This refers to Shackleton's 1908 expedition to the South Pole. He was 97 miles away from the goal, but with delays and low supplies, he decided to turn back. In a crisis, people want to know someone is in charge. Today, managers often avoid responsibility, but Shackleton was ready to take it. His 1914 expedition became legendary. His ship, the Endurance, was stuck in ice for nine months and then crushed. When the ship sank, Shackleton told his men, 'We will all be safe if you keep doing your best and trust me.' From diaries and accounts, it is clear that Shackleton was always in charge. 'Shackleton thought everything through, planned for every situation, kept his men informed, and asked for their opinions,' says MacGregor. 'He was adaptable and ready to start fresh when needed. We have created a set of principles that Shackleton shows. Clients can relate to his story without feeling criticized.' Shackleton believed an explorer needs optimism, physical endurance, and patience. 'One of the hardest things to do in difficult times is to do nothing, especially in America, where people want quick solutions,' says MacGregor. 'If you buy bonds and the interest rates are wrong, you wait, and eventually, you'll get your money back. To "fix it" and sell would mean a big loss. Also, don't be afraid to change plans if they aren't working. If a new product is bad, don't keep selling it.' Shackleton led by example. On the way back from the Endurance, he saw Hurley, the expedition photographer, without gloves. He gave Hurley his own gloves, saying he would throw them overboard if Hurley didn't wear them. Someone else remembered him doing the same with a biscuit when they were starving in 1905: 'He said he'd leave it in the snow. Millions of pounds couldn't have bought that biscuit.' As Caroline Alexander, author of Endurance, says: 'People want to hear about heroic actions more and more. Shackleton shows that there is nothing heroic happening now. Everything else fades away, and he stands as the true example of the ideals we miss today.'

'Finding Food in Madagascar Forests
In the forests of Madagascar, there is a special animal called the aye-aye. It lives like a woodpecker. Both the woodpecker and the aye-aye look for insect larvae inside wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to make holes and its long tongue to get the insects. The aye-aye uses its sharp teeth to make holes and its long, thin third finger to reach and scoop the insects.
Scientists have known about the aye-aye's way of eating for over a hundred years. But they only recently learned how it finds insects inside the wood. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University studied the aye-aye's hunting skills. He worked with two male aye-ayes, Nosferatu and Poe, a female named Samantha, and her baby, Annabelle.
Dr. Erickson tested if the aye-ayes found insects by looking for signs on the wood. He gave them logs with small holes. Some holes had mealworms, and others were empty. The aye-ayes went straight to the holes with food, without needing to see the holes.
Maybe the aye-ayes used smell or sound to find the insects. But tests showed they did not use these clues. They could find mealworms even when they couldn't smell or hear them. Dr. Erickson found that aye-ayes could sense empty spaces in the wood. They tap the wood with their middle finger and listen with their big ears. This helps them find hollow spaces where insects might be.
The idea that aye-ayes are like woodpeckers in Madagascar is interesting. But there are also birds there that look for insects in wood. So, the aye-aye is not the only one doing this job. The aye-aye is special because it is like a woodpecker, a bat, and a squirrel. Its teeth grow like a squirrel's, and it can open nuts with its long finger to eat the inside.'

'Ordinary people, ordinary lives Many of us have photos of our grandparents, but do we know what their lives were like when they were young? Old diaries and family stories don't tell us everything. And what will our grandchildren know about us? We often want to write things down but never do it. We might leave videos, but they are still just pictures. Hannah Renier has an idea: she writes books about other people's lives. These books are not about famous people, but about ordinary people. She started this because she talked to her family and saw that many stories from the past were disappearing. "At first, I didn't take it very seriously," she says. "But then I met people with interesting lives. They do it for their children or the future, but they also enjoy it." People feel safe to be honest with her. A 62-year-old man shared his life story, including painful parts like his divorce. He did it for his family, hoping they could learn something. But he hasn't let his children read it yet because some details might hurt them. He thinks they should read it after he is gone. He also saw patterns from his childhood that made him repeat mistakes. Ms. Renier noticed this in others too. "Many people are influenced by their parents," she says. "Things from childhood affect them all their lives. They marry people their parents liked or do the opposite to rebel." "Many people still feel sad about things with their parents, even 60 years later. They try to impress a parent who wasn't impressed." Ms. Renier listens and writes their stories. "It's not for everyone to read, and I'm not nosy. People sometimes tell me things and then say, 'I'm not sure if that should be in.' I include it, but they can remove it later. People want to be honest." "It's not about showing off. Life is moving fast, and we forget the past. This gives us a connection to our ancestors. People want to be remembered." Each book takes about 30 hours of interviews. Ms. Renier writes the life story, organizes it, and makes it look nice. The book is not cheap, costing nearly £3,000, with extra copies at £25 each. She gets about 10 inquiries a week, but the cost stops many people. "I thought it would be cheaper," she says. "But the people I've worked with are usually wealthy, like readers of Harpers & Queen magazine. They are the kind of people who used to have their portraits painted for their family."'

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**
The Museum of Classical Archaeology has many copies of Greek and Roman sculptures. There are over six hundred pieces. Remember, none of the sculptures are real. They are all copies made from the originals, mostly in the late 1800s and early 1900s. The museum is in a special building with good natural light. The plaster copies have many benefits: sculptures that were originally together but are now in different museums can be seen together here. You can see almost all the famous Greek and Roman sculptures in one afternoon.
**B. Cambridge Darkroom**
Cambridge Darkroom is a place for photography. It has community darkrooms and a gallery with different photography exhibitions. They have courses and workshops for all ages and skill levels, like a Beginner's Course, a short Induction Course, and Master Classes with guest photographers. Members can use the darkrooms. They also have a program for young photographers aged 12 to 16, led by a resident photographer. They sell photography books, magazines, and materials.
**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**
The Sedgwick Museum has a great collection of fossils, rocks, and minerals from all over the world. It also has Britain's oldest geological collection from Dr. John Woodward (1665-1728), with nearly 10,000 rare items in old cabinets. Adam Sedgwick, a geology professor, added many items to the collection, making the museum outstanding. The collection is organized by geological age, showing changes in life on Earth over time. The new Whewell Gallery has beautiful minerals and gems, with labels explaining their nature and modern use.
**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**
This collection has over 400,000 air photographs taken by university staff over the past 45 years. The University has its own aircraft at Cambridge Airport and takes photos all over Great Britain. The photos show the landscape and human activity from prehistoric times to now. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the library staff can help with questions. You cannot borrow the photos, but you can buy copies, which usually take about a month to make.
**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**
The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is a unique tourist attraction. You can make wall hangings by rubbing one of over a hundred brass plates from medieval tombs. The centre makes resin copies to protect the originals, so everyone can enjoy brass rubbing. Brass plates were used as memorials on tombs and spread from Germany across medieval Europe and Scandinavia. Many were destroyed in revolutions, but most of the remaining ones are in Britain, and you can see many examples at the Cambridge Centre.

**From Here to Being a Father**
**A. The Theatre Director**
I have had small children in my life for 35 years, and I love it. This morning, I fed the baby, and that is what being a father means to me. My children and I enjoy the same things: opera, theatre, books, and music. This makes us close, especially now that they are older. I try to be there for them if they need me, but I let them call me first. I don't want them to feel guilty for not calling. My parents did that to me, and I don't want to do it to my children.
**B. The Advertising Executive**
I was about 25 when my children were born. It was hard to handle the responsibilities, but it also kept me young. As they grew up, they showed me new music and fashion, which helped me in my job. I missed some important events when they were young because I was busy with work. But now, I can take them on nice holidays. They like coming to parties and events with us. They think my job is interesting.
**C. The Politician**
My first child was born when I started my political career. My wife and I wanted to spend time with our children, but my work made it hard. I try to take my kids with me to weekend meetings so they know what I do. This way, they don't feel like I am gone all the time. More politicians are bringing their kids to work now, which is good.
**D. The Writer**
My first marriage ended when my children, Kate and Bonnie, were young. I tried hard to stay close to them. My ex-wife and I even lived next to each other for a while, but it was confusing for the kids. Kate says I was always there for her, but I think I treated them like adults too soon. I wish I had been more organized. I still worry about my children, even the older ones.
**E. The TV Presenter**
I was ready to have kids at 30. My wife and I had a nice house, and we decided to have a child instead of buying more things. Having my daughter Betty made me think about who I am. Being a parent is special, but it also makes you like other parents. Sometimes it is hard, but one smile from her makes everything better. A baby's smile is very powerful.

**THEATRE CHARLES SPENCER**
A. **Tamburlaine the Great**  
This play is about a powerful warrior. It is very exciting in Terry Hands' version. The play is shorter and faster. Antony Sher plays the main character very well. He does amazing things like jumping from a balcony and sliding down a rope. Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)
B. **Women Laughing**  
This play moved from Manchester to London. It starts with two married couples talking in a garden. Later, it shows how illness can change lives. The writer, Michael Wall, died young. Royal Court Theatre, London SW1 (0207 730 1745)
C. **Amphibians**  
Billy Roche, an Irish writer, tells a story about the fishing industry in Wexford. The play has strong characters and emotions. It is funny at times and ends with a big finish. Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)
D. **Murder by Misadventure**  
This is a classic thriller about a 'perfect murder'. Gerald Harper and William Gaunt play writers who want to kill each other. The story has many clever twists. Whitehall Theatre, London SW1 (0207 867 1119)
E. **The Alchemist**  
Sam Mendes directs this comedy about tricksters from the 17th century. The play was first shown in Stratford and is now in London. The actors play their roles very well. Barbican Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)
F. **The Madras House**  
This play is about fashion and women in Edwardian times. It was successful in Edinburgh and is now in London. The acting and staging are very good. Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith, London W6 (0208 741 2311)
G. **Dreams from a Summer House**  
This new musical is like Beauty and the Beast but set in London. It has beautiful music and is about romantic love. It is a happy show. Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough (01 723 370541)
H. **The Merry Wives of Windsor**  
This is a comedy by Shakespeare. The production is not very good, but some actors are funny. Ron Cook and Anton Lesser give great performances. Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)
I. **The Voysey Inheritance**  
This play is about a lawyer who leaves a bad financial situation to his son. It is a great story. Apollo Theatre, Oxford (01865 244544)

**Hide and Seek by Yvonne Coppard**  
Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game. They are watching a strange bookshop. Emma sees her Uncle Jim there. He tricks her into doing bad things and tries to make her leave her friends. When Emma is in danger, the story becomes very exciting. She is trapped in a basement, and it is very scary. This book shows family life, childhood friendship, and warns that adults are not always good.
**Backtrack by Peter Hunt**  
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, work together to find out about a train accident in 1915 where eight people died. They use maps, stories, and other documents to learn more. The story is clever and makes you think hard to understand what happened.
**Pigeon Summer by Ann Turnbull**  
Mary Dyer is a girl who loves her father's racing pigeons. When her father leaves to find work, Mary takes care of the pigeons and wins prizes. The story is set in 1930 and shows that there are different ways to be smart. It is a good story for thoughtful readers.
**Yaxley's Cat by Robert Westall**  
Rose rents a cottage with her two children to escape her old life. A scary cat and strange things in the house show why the last owner disappeared. The local people do not like Rose and her family, and they are in danger. The story is very exciting and shows how Rose's son is very determined.
**Someone's Mother is Missing by Harry Mazer**  
Sam is from a poor family and is impressed by his rich cousin, Lisa. When Lisa's life changes, Sam helps her. They both learn about family and reality. The story is a bit slow but has gentle humor and shows how Sam and Lisa become close.
**Stanley's Aquarium by Barry Faville**  
Robbie works in Stanley's garden. At first, she likes him, but then she finds out about his aquarium and his plans. The story becomes a thriller but still shows strong characters and relationships. It is set in New Zealand and is very interesting.
**Dodger by Libby Gleeson**  
Mick has problems at home and school. The story is told through flashbacks, letters, and notes. Mick learns to feel better about himself through a school play and a kind teacher. The story is sad but very good, especially at the end.

Title: 'Flying Without Gravity'
Journalist Tom Mumford joins students testing ideas in weightlessness. From the outside, the aircraft looked normal. The pilot told the young passengers it was a Boeing KC-135, built in 1964. But inside, it was different. It was a long white tunnel with lights on the walls. Most seats were gone, except a few at the back. The 13 students from Europe and America sat there, looking nervous. They had worked hard for a year to be on this flight. The European Space Agency asked students to suggest creative experiments for weightless conditions. The best ideas won a place on this special flight, like a wild roller-coaster ride.
For two hours, the Boeing flew like a big bird, going up and down. At the top of each curve, the pilot cut the engines at 3,000 meters. The plane went higher by itself before falling back to Earth. In those few seconds, everything inside became weightless. The students felt like they were closer to the moon than Earth.
The plane took off smoothly, but soon it climbed at a 45-degree angle for 20 seconds. The engines were loud, and we felt the blood leave our heads. Then the engines stopped, and we were weightless. For 20 seconds, we floated in silence. The floor felt like a trampoline, and one step sent us towards the ceiling. We floated without direction. Up, down, left, or right no longer mattered.
After ten seconds of falling, the pilot pulled the plane out of the dive. Gravity returned, and some students landed hard. We completed one curve, with 29 more to go. This meant ten minutes of 'space time' for experiments. Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to see how cats always land on their feet. They used a device to turn it belly-down with a remote control. But during one curve, a student accidentally landed on it.
Nearby, a German team studied how metal joins are affected by no gravity, thinking about future space stations. Another team from Utah State University tried to make solar sails from thin films in sunlight. They hoped these sails could use the sun's radiation like a yacht uses the wind.
After two hours of flying up and down, we felt a bit sick, but mostly excited. It was an experience we would remember for a long time. One student said, 'It was unforgettable. I wanted to be an astronaut before, but now I want it even more.'

**With the Trees, I Made a Connection to New Zealand**
Jonathon Porritt is the author of "Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology."
I had a strange time in my life when I didn't have any summers. I went to New Zealand every summer from here, which is winter in New Zealand. So, I had nine winters in a row. I liked it because I enjoy winter. My parents had an idea to buy a small piece of land for my brother, sister, and me to take care of. My mother said, "If you plant trees on it, you can have it." This way, we would always have a connection to New Zealand, which was nice because my father grew up there. They found land about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land wasn't very good, but it was okay for planting trees.
I have always liked land. I spent a year in Australia working on sheep farms and doing different farming jobs. So, planting trees sounded nice, and I was excited. My family got excited too as we started. I began planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, we had planted all 70 acres.
In 1968, it rained a lot in New Zealand. It rained almost every day we were planting. I was often wet and cold, but it was a happy time. Every morning, I got ready for planting. I came out of the Land Rover warm and dry, but it was raining, and my raincoat was still wet from the day before. My boots were wet, and my hands were cold.
In the first year, I worked with a man who knew how to plant trees. He helped me because I had never planted trees seriously before. You carry a bag with trees around your neck. When the bag is full, it's heavy, but it gets easier as it gets lighter. The hardest part was making straight lines. You decide how far apart to plant the trees, then use three poles to make a straight line. You plant along the line, turn around, and come back.
I like hard work, and it made me fit. After a while, you get used to planting, and it becomes easy. You dig a hole, put the tree in, cover it, and move on. While working, I thought a lot about life and nature. Many ideas that are important to me now started then.
I've been back to New Zealand four times to see the trees grow. It's nice to see them because I planted them. I worry when I read about bad weather in New Zealand, but the trees are now 20 years old and doing well.
In 1984, I took time off from teaching and went back to New Zealand alone for three months. I wrote my first book, "Seeing Green," there. I stayed in a small cabin with just a bed, table, and chair. I wrote in the mornings, pruned trees in the afternoons, and did research in the evenings. I still feel a strong connection to that place. It's where I feel most connected to the earth.

Title: Taking Care of Badgers
One day, a helper gave me a cardboard box. My husband Derek and I have a farm in Somerset. We take care of orphaned animals. Inside the box, I found three small badger cubs. They were grey, with black-and-white stripes on their heads. Their eyes were milky-colored. I had never seen badger cubs before. Usually, they stay underground when they are young. If they lose their mother, they often die because they cannot find food.
These cubs were found by builders. They accidentally destroyed the badger's home. The mother was dead, and the cubs were still with her. The cubs were healthy but cold and crying. I cleaned them and put them by the stove to keep warm. There were two females, Primrose and Bluebell, and one male, Willow. I fed them with a syringe at first. I also wiped them with a warm cloth to help them go to the bathroom. After a few days, they started drinking from a bottle.
After three weeks, Willow seemed tired. I did not know it was serious, and the next morning, he was dead. The vet said he had a lung infection. When feeding animals, it is important not to let them drink too fast. Willow drank too fast, and liquid went into his lungs, causing the infection.
I was sad but continued to care for the other cubs. Then, a local farmer brought me another male cub. He was cold and hungry. We named him Willow II. He was hard to feed, but eventually, he learned to drink from the bottle.
By the end of April, the females started eating solid food. Willow II was slower to learn but eventually ate sausages. At five months old, they all ate cereals, meat, vegetables, fruit, nuts, cheese, eggs, and seeds. Badgers usually eat earthworms, beetles, bugs, and small animals.
By August, the cubs became more active at night. We took them for walks in the evening. They played and chased each other. Sometimes they would nip us playfully. We had to be careful not to get bitten.
We saw other badgers in our field. Badgers are very territorial and can be aggressive. We were worried they might harm our cubs, so we made their pen safe.
The local press took pictures of us with the badgers. Many people wanted to help. We decided to build a home for the badgers on our farm. Our son Daniel made the plans. The new home had tunnels and chambers. It was expensive, but a local bus company and other businesses helped us.
The badgers moved into their new home. They were happy and settled in quickly. Now, I do not walk with them as often because they are active at night. Primrose has joined another group of badgers, but Bluebell and Willow II still come to say hello before going off into the night. This is their home now, and they are happy here.

'Looking for True North - and the Man Behind Halley's Comet
Dr. Toby Clark is a researcher at the British Geological Survey. He wants to follow the journey of Sir Edmund Halley, who studied compass directions. Anjana Ahuja reports.
Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. But he also did important work on compass directions. He traveled on a ship called the Paramore to study 'compass variations'. This is now called 'declination', which is the angle between magnetic north and true north. Sailors needed this to navigate the oceans correctly.
Halley was one of the few people paid to do scientific research at that time. He sailed to the Cape Verde Islands to study declination in the Atlantic Ocean. The first trip stopped because the crew did not follow orders, but Halley tried again. He traveled to places like Rio de Janeiro and Newfoundland. In 1701, he published a map showing compass variations in the oceans. This map helped sailors for over a hundred years.
Dr. Clark, who likes sailing, wants to celebrate Halley's work by following his route. He needs to raise £70,000 for the trip. Sir Vivian Fuchs, who led an expedition in Antarctica, is helping him. Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while working in Antarctica. He read about Halley's life and found it amazing. Halley was not only an astronomer but also did other scientific work. He even helped Sir Isaac Newton with his famous book, Principia Mathematica.
