Dr. Clark's trip will also have scientific value. He will take new measurements of the magnetic field with better tools. This is important because the Earth's magnetic field is always changing. The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments. A Danish satellite will also take similar measurements, and Dr. Clark's data will help fill any gaps.
Halley's journey was the first scientific sea expedition. He was the first civilian to be a naval captain for science. Dr. Clark has experience for this trip. He worked in Antarctica and has sailed from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the trip in four parts with different crews.
Dr. Clark is very dedicated to this project. He says, 'I am ready to spend eight months on this trip. Halley and his life give me a real sense of purpose.'

**Peacocks and Their Beautiful Tails**
Every summer, peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tails to the female peacocks, called hens. This display is a mystery that puzzled Charles Darwin. He wondered why peacocks have such big, fancy tails in a world where animals need to be strong and fast to survive.
Darwin thought animals change over time through evolution. He said the strongest and smartest animals survive and have babies. But the peacock's tail seemed to be a problem because it is big and heavy. Darwin suggested another idea called "sexual selection." He thought females liked beauty, so they chose males with beautiful tails.
Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, had a different idea. He believed that if hens chose peacocks with fancy tails, those peacocks must have something special that helps them survive. Wallace thought the tail was a sign of this special quality.
Today, scientists like Marion Petrie study peacocks at Whipsnade to find answers. They want to know if hens really choose males with the best tails and if these males have other good qualities. They found that hens like peacocks with many eye-spots on their tails. These peacocks get more mates.
Another scientist, William Hamilton, thinks that showy male birds might be healthier and have fewer parasites. But Petrie and her team have not tested this idea yet. They are now looking at the children of attractive and unattractive peacocks to see if the attractive ones have healthier babies.
There is another idea called "Fisher's Runaway." It suggests that if a female picks a male with a slightly better tail, their children will inherit these traits. Over time, this can lead to peacocks with very long tails. This idea supports Darwin's thought that females might choose beauty just for beauty's sake.

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**
Tom Cunliffe believes the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He did this with his boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is full of modern yachts with new technology. Most of these boats are from a design change that happened 25 years ago. My boat, however, is on a quiet creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but it looks like it is 100 years old. Some people might think I am a romantic person because of this. Maybe I am, but I think my boat is better because it uses both old and new boat design ideas.
Modern technology is important for building boats today, but it can sometimes make sailing too easy. Many people go to sea to experience the challenges of sailing. I think it is important for a boat to have some comforts, like a stove for warmth and a good place to sleep. But if everything on the boat is automatic, it takes away from the real experience of sailing. For example, setting and taking down sails should be part of a sailor's life.
When I bought my old boat, Hirta, I sailed around Britain for a TV show. The previous owner said she had every comfort but no luxury. Hirta had heavy sails and no modern conveniences like electricity or a fridge, but she was the best boat I ever sailed. However, old boats need a lot of care. After I hurt my back, I had to sell Hirta. I couldn't find a new boat I liked, so I decided to build one myself.
The Westerman, my new boat, has been great. The designer, Nigel Irens, first drew the boat on a napkin before using a computer. We made a model of the boat, like in the old days, and then used the computer to make changes. The final design was perfect. The Westerman has crossed the North Atlantic and won many races. She looks timeless and is very comfortable at sea. Her inside is made from old wood, which gives a peaceful feeling. She was designed as a sailing boat first, not as a place to live. This shows that you don't need to follow new trends to be happy. The Westerman is made from wood treated with a special glue, so she is waterproof like a modern boat but feels like a traditional one.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**
Many health farms and hotels with spa facilities are very popular now. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places.
**A. HENLOW GRANGE**
I was happy to visit Henlow Grange for six days because I was tired and needed to relax. My room in the big old house was very comfortable. On the first day, I rested and slept a lot. From the second day, I joined many classes like yoga and body conditioning. The teachers are very good. I felt more flexible each day. They offer many treatments like aromatherapy, seaweed baths, and facials. The staff is very friendly and professional. Henlow is planning to add a new swimming pool and a Light Diet Room. You can also ride bicycles or walk in the garden. I felt much better and full of energy after my stay. I want to visit again. This is a great place for a busy working woman. Save Room 5 for me! - Marcella D'Argy Smith
**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**
Shrubland Hall is a calm and relaxing place. It has a beautiful library and a nice conservatory. When you arrive, you get a medical check-up. They check your weight and blood pressure. I found out I had a shoulder problem, and they helped me with exercises. Each person gets a special diet. I lost weight but felt hungry and had a headache on the second day. My meals included grapefruit, salads, and fruit with yogurt. You can have a massage or water therapy every other day. The extra treatments are not too expensive. - Liz Gregory
**C. CAREYS MANOR**
Careys Manor is not a health farm, but it is a nice old manor with a cozy lounge. The food is very tasty, but not for people counting calories. They have a gym and a pool to help you stay fit. There is also a spa bath, sauna, and treatment rooms. They have a clinic for sports injuries. I got advice for my shoulder pain. Careys is comfortable and relaxing. You can also explore the countryside around it. - Beverly D'Silva
**D. CLIVEDEN**
Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel. It offers many activities like gym, swimming, tennis, and horse riding. The gardens and walks are beautiful. The restaurant, Waldo's, has amazing food. I enjoyed a delicious dinner and dessert. The next day, I used the gym and had a facial and massage. Cliveden has many fitness and beauty treatments if you want them. - Kay Letch
**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**
The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It is very tasty but has many calories. The aromatherapy massage is also great. I felt very relaxed and slept well. The place is modern and well-organized. They offer many treatments like facials and body treatments. The guests are a mix of people, from football teams to families and friends. I would like to visit here every month. - Eve Cameron

**Natural Talents**
Humans and chimpanzees are very similar. We are more than 98% the same in our genes. This means that the things that make us different from animals are new in our history. Our ability to make art and do other human things comes from a small part of our genes.
Scientists have found that many things we thought only humans could do, animals can do too. For example, chimpanzees use sticks as tools, and sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys have simple language with different sounds for different dangers like 'leopard' or 'snake'.
Art is one thing that seems to be special to humans. But our ancestors did not make art for a long time. The first clear human art, like cave paintings and statues, appeared about 35,000 years ago with the Cro-Magnons.
People say human art is different because it is not useful, it is made for beauty, and it is learned, not instinctive. Let's look at these ideas:
1. **Not Useful**: Human art does not help us survive or have children. For example, birds sing to find a mate or protect their home, which helps them pass on their genes. Human art is different because it is not for survival.
2. **Made for Beauty**: Humans make art for pleasure. We cannot ask birds if they sing for beauty, but they mostly sing during mating season, so it might not be just for fun. This makes human art seem special.
3. **Learned, Not Instinctive**: Human art styles are learned. People in different places have different art styles, like songs in Tokyo and Paris. These styles are not in our genes. Birds, however, are born knowing their songs.
Human art changes quickly. For example, paintings from the 20th century look different from older ones like the Mona Lisa. Experts can often tell when and who painted a piece of art.
Interestingly, chimpanzees like Congo and Betsy have made paintings that look like human abstract art. Congo even got upset when his pencil was taken away. Their art was shown in a London gallery in 1957, and many paintings were sold.
These chimpanzee paintings show that the line between human art and animal activities is not always clear. Like human art, the chimpanzee art was not for survival or communication but for their own satisfaction. Some human art, too, was made for personal pleasure and not to communicate with others.

Title: A Big Adventure
The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last places on earth that people have not explored. It is also very dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and survived to tell his story.
There are not many big adventures left and not many heroes. In the past, children's stories were about brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes looking far into the distance. Today, you don't find such people in stories or real life. But then I met Charles Blackmore.
Blackmore's big adventure was leading a team across the Taklamakan Desert in western China. The name means 'once entered you never come out', but local people call it the Desert of Death. He talked about the dangers and excitement of the journey at his home.
The team had four Britons (one was a doctor), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. The camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were truck drivers. This mistake could have been very dangerous.
The team wanted to cross 1,200 kilometers of the desert. Charles Blackmore wrote about their journey. At that time, he was leaving the Army after 14 years. He started the expedition for fun and to learn more about himself. 'I thought I would stay in the Army forever. I wanted to see who I was outside of it. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was worried because nobody had done that route before. We went into it without knowing what would happen. It took 59 days to cross, and the desert was kind to us.'
The team faced many problems: illness, hot and cold temperatures, thirst, and losing some of their water. 'But', Blackmore says, 'when we were very tired and the camels had no water for seven days, we found some. We didn't have the desert's big sandstorms. And we didn't face the very cold weather that could have stopped us. But we had many challenges. The sand got into everything, especially blisters and wounds. The high dunes were hard to climb for us and the camels, which sometimes fell on us.'
'What kept me going was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. No planes flew over us. Once we were in the desert, we were alone. I knew I was mentally strong, but I was scared about my physical strength. On the first day, we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot you couldn't breathe. I thought, "We have to do it now!" I was very scared.'
How did they feel at the end? 'After walking 1,000 kilometers, you don't give up. We were very thin but strong. My body was fit, and my legs were strong. I could walk over anything.'
In the book, Blackmore talks about lying in the desert, looking at the moon, and thinking of his family. He says, 'Inside me, there's someone trying to find peace. When I doubt myself, I think of the desert and how we did it. I am proud of that expedition. But my family and our happiness are more important.'
Has Charles Blackmore found peace? 'I miss the challenge and the open spaces. We had a purpose. Now, I find it hard to be part of modern life.'

Life was becoming too busy for Susan Harr, so she decided to stop using some of her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it gives us gadgets that make life easier and give us more free time. But Susan started to think that maybe we rely too much on technology. She had a bad experience with her broken word processor, which cost a lot to fix. This made her wonder if gadgets are really worth the trouble and money.
Susan began to let her household gadgets stop working as they got old. She questioned what "extra time" technology really gives us. Is it just time to buy more gadgets? She thinks that maybe we are being tricked by marketing experts. When her sewing machine started making strange noises, she decided to stop using it. Now, she sews by hand and enjoys it. She can take her sewing with her anywhere, and she doesn't have to worry about a noisy machine.
There are some gadgets Susan still likes, like the washing machine. But she found happiness in losing others. She returned her rented color TV and went back to a small black-and-white one. This made her family spend more time walking the dog, reading, talking, and doing hobbies. Susan enjoys sewing by hand now. Her old sewing machine is just a plant table. She finds sewing by hand relaxing and satisfying. She can listen to the radio or talk with family while sewing.
Susan realized that doing things by hand is not as bad as she thought. It is calming and gives her a sense of accomplishment. She doesn't have to rush from one activity to another. She also enjoys washing dishes by hand and daydreaming. Now, she looks around her house and wonders if she really needs things like the freezer, microwave, or electric lights. She thinks she could save a lot of money without them.

'The Cabinet-Maker Charles Hurst makes a living from making very good furniture. Joanna Watt meets him. Charles Hurst seems like a busy man. I visit his workshop in East London, under a railway arch. He greets me quickly and says, 'Well, let's start!' It's not clear if he is really in a hurry or just a bit shy. His workshop is full of half-made furniture and many pieces of wood in different colors. Hurst has been making furniture for ten years and is well-known for his work. He always has many orders, even though he doesn't advertise. People know that if you want a good cupboard, table, bookcase, or kitchen units, Hurst is the person to go to. There are many furniture-makers, but finding one who makes simple and beautiful furniture is harder. 'There are few real cabinet-makers now. People call themselves furniture-makers,' Hurst says. He is not happy with some modern furniture. 'I am surprised by what some furniture-makers do, and sad about what people accept.' He doesn't like cheap, badly made furniture. Hurst wants everything to be perfect, and he is very talented. He is confident about his skills. 'I have a huge natural ability,' he says. 'I have always been good at making things.' Hurst learned by himself. How did he learn? 'I asked the right questions and learned,' he says. Most of his work is for private people. 'I used to work for companies, but it was not fun.' Some clients come back many times. 'You end up doing the whole of their house. That is very satisfying.' But he admits that working with clients is not always easy. 'The most annoying clients are those who don't know what they want, and then decide they do when it's too late ... my favorite clients are the ones who know exactly what they want.' Hurst is happy with his work, but he also praises others. 'There are people far better than me. I can admire other people. After all, I wasn't trained at Parnham' (a top furniture design school). He is critical of craftsmen who 'try to be artists and take a year to make one piece.' He also doesn't like degree shows where students try to make fashion statements. 'A piece of furniture is not about making a statement. It has to be something that people really can use.' Hurst is confident and sometimes seems a bit rude, but he is not pretentious. As I leave, he says, 'After all, I am only making furniture,' showing he is humble about his work.'

'Why do we sleep? People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This means sleep is very important. But scientists are not sure why we need sleep. There are three main ideas. The first idea is that sleep helps our body stay healthy. When we sleep, our body fixes any problems and makes us strong again. The second idea is that sleep helps us learn. It says that when we sleep, our brain organizes the information we learned during the day. Without sleep, we might not learn well. The third idea is about energy. It says we need sleep to get more energy for the next day, like recharging a battery.'

**Eccentrics**
An eccentric is a person who acts differently from most people. They do not follow the usual rules of society. This makes us ask, "What is normal?" Many of us have small, unusual habits. For example, some people love entering newspaper contests, collecting beer mats, or writing letters to newspapers about many topics. Eccentricity means showing our unique self.
Inside us, there are two forces. One is called individualism, which means being different. The other is conformity, which means being like everyone else. Most people want to be accepted and loved, so they choose conformity. But some people have unusual hobbies or strong opinions. They like to meet others who share their interests. They form clubs and have meetings to talk about their hobbies. Being with others who understand them makes them feel better.
We all feel a pull between being different and being the same as others. Sometimes, we want to show we are unique. For example, a person might say, "I say what I think," or "You must take me as you find me." We can choose to be more individualistic and show our personality. Many successful people have done this, like Bob Dylan, an American singer. He said, "When you know what you are doing and keep doing it, people might not understand you."
But being different on purpose is not the same as being eccentric. For example, a pop singer might wear strange clothes to get attention. If they keep doing this until it becomes normal for them, they might be eccentric. Eccentrics do not try to be odd; they just are. They do not care about what others think. They do things because it is who they are.
Eccentrics are different from people who want to impress others or escape from society. These people are aware of the world around them. Eccentrics, however, just live their lives without worrying about what others think.

**Natural Books**
We asked four nature experts to tell us about the wildlife book that influenced them the most.
**A. Geoffrey Lean**
Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I have met many important people in this field. Barbara Ward, a small and frail woman, is the most important. She was at the center of environmental issues in Europe after the war. She combined her experiences into a strong philosophy. As a young journalist, she helped me understand everything. Choosing the book was harder. It could have been "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." But "The Home of Man" is her most important book for me. It talks about the fast growth of cities and the big themes she cared about. It is a strong message for what we now call 'sustainable human development.' I have not found a book like it since.
**B. Linda Bennett**
When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can hear the calls of herring gulls and remember the smell of the colony. This book explains animal communication very well with words and pictures. After reading it, watching a gull colony changes from chaos to an organized social structure. You can see which birds are partners and recognize families. Niko Tinbergen was a great behaviorist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. He worked with Eric Ennion, a talented wildlife artist, to create this book. Ennion's paintings show how one gull is aggressive and another is calm. This is the art of a true field naturalist.
**C. Lee Durrell**
"My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell is the book that influenced my life the most. It led me to a wonderful husband and a career in conservation. This book made me love the natural world. I was researching animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read it. I was having a hard time, but reading this book made me happy. It shows animals, people, joy, and beauty together. Many people say humans are bad because of what we do to other species. But I think of Gerald as a boy in the book, seeing the world as a family. We need to understand this idea.
**D. Bruce Pearson**
I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library in 1966. I loved the 48 color plates of birds by Eric Ennion. I already had other bird books and learned to identify birds during holidays. This book encouraged me to start sketching birds. It had more than just paintings; it had chapters on bird migration, history, and birds in music, literature, and art. This book helped me appreciate birds and nature in a broader way. It showed me that my emotional and creative response to nature is as important as a scientific one. Since I was better at art than math or physics, this book opened a new path for me.

Title: Do Reviews Help Sell Books?
We asked five important British publishers if book reviews help sell books. Here is what they said:
Publisher A: Reviews are very important for publishers. Many people buy books because of reviews more than ads or word of mouth. Authors and publishers both feel bad if there are no reviews. Publishers think any review, good or bad, can help sell books because people want to decide for themselves. Publishers like reviews that agree with their own thoughts about the book.
Publisher B: Publishers and newspapers both care about book reviews, but they want different things. Newspapers want to entertain readers, while publishers want their books reviewed positively. Book reviews are better now than 40 years ago, but paperbacks are often ignored. Reviews help make books and authors known. A good review from a trusted person can increase sales.
Publisher C: Reviews are very important for us because we publish books by less famous authors. We don't advertise much, so we need reviews. Good reviews are better than ads because they are honest. Reviews can help sell books, but they need help from other things like word of mouth and good marketing.
Publisher D: In the US, a review in the New York Times can make a book popular. In Britain, reviews don't always have the same effect. Sometimes, books with bad reviews sell well. It's hard to predict what will happen. Non-fiction reviews often talk more about the subject than the book.
Publisher E: Publishers and writers want good reviews, but do they sell books? I published a biography with great reviews, but it didn't sell well because people felt they didn't need to buy it after reading the reviews. The reviewer's name used to matter more, but now it's about the review's style and surprise.

'WEATHERVANE MAKER Making weathervanes is a very old skill, starting in ancient Egypt. Today, Graham Smith keeps this craft alive in his workshop. He is one of the few people in the country who make weathervanes by hand. Graham makes special designs for each customer. 'This way, I can make a unique item,' he says. 'Many of my customers are women buying gifts for their husbands. They want a special gift that shows the man's job or hobbies.' This is different from the usual cockerel design. Graham's first weathervane was not a cockerel but a witch on a broomstick. He made it as a surprise for his wife. Friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them. 'I saw that I could make many different designs,' he says. Graham decided to start a weathervane business. He was a precision engineer for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, changed roles. She went to work as an architectural assistant, and he stayed home to care for the children and grow the business. That was five years ago, and he is happy with his choice. 'My old job was not artistic, but this is fun and creative,' he says. 'I love designing.' Graham has made over 100 original designs. He works with great detail and always asks the customer to approve the design before cutting it by hand. Graham also keeps many traditional designs because they are popular. 'People like handmade things,' Graham says. 'They want something a little different.' Graham does not want to expand his business. He wants to keep it as a small craft. 'I have found my place in the market. People love the unique designs, and I enjoy turning a simple shape into something almost real,' he says. 'For many years, weathervanes have helped people know the weather by showing wind direction,' he explains. 'Now, more people are moving to the countryside, and they want a special touch for their homes. This helps crafts like mine.' Graham is very busy, sending flat-packed weathervanes to clients around the world. American and Danish buyers are especially interested. 'The price,' he says, 'depends on how detailed the design is.' His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. Whatever the occasion, Graham can make a special gift.'

Title: Beginner's Luck
Before it was published, "The Horse Whisperer" was already a very popular book. It is the first novel by British writer Nicholas Evans. He earned a lot of money from it. Here, he talks about his inspiration and success.
At the start of the year, things were not going well for Nicholas Evans. He is a screenwriter and producer. A movie he was working on, called "Life and Limb," was canceled suddenly. He was worried because he had not made money for two years, and the movie was his only hope to pay the bank.
Instead of finding a job, Evans made a surprising decision. He bought a ticket to America to research his first novel. He got the idea for the story from a man he met on Dartmoor. The man told him about a horse that became wild, but a gypsy calmed it by talking to it. These people are called "horse whisperers."
Evans wanted to write a screenplay about this, but after his movie project failed, he decided to write a book instead. He traveled across the US, learning about horses and the people who work with them. He felt alone and worried about his future.
By August, he had written half of the book. He showed it to a friend who was a literary agent. The agent thought Evans might get $30,000 for it, but Evans needed more money. He wrote a summary of the rest of the book and sent it to publishers.
In October, his agent called with good news. Publishers were very interested in the book. It was sold for a lot of money in the UK and the US. Hollywood studios also wanted to make a movie from it.
Evans was surprised by the success. He decided not to write the screenplay for "The Horse Whisperer" because he wanted to keep control of his work. He also got offers to work on "Life and Limb" again, but he thought it was better to write another novel.

'Young Chess Players
Bobby Fischer is trying to become a top chess player again, but he is older now. Chess is a game for young people. After 20 years away, Bobby Fischer is playing chess again against Boris Spassky. Bobby won the first game, and it was very good. But Bobby is not the same as in 1972. He is 49 years old and not in practice. Boris Spassky is even older. Chess has changed a lot in 20 years. Bobby Fischer made chess popular, and now it is more professional. Today, winning is the most important thing in chess. Players need strong nerves and stamina, not just intelligence. The game is very intense. Players use a chess clock to make sure they play in time. If they don't, they lose the game. Games are longer now, and there are no breaks. Young players have an advantage. In the last 30 years, each new world champion is younger than the last one. Eight of the top ten players in the world are under 30. 
Chess is also different because of computers. Players prepare a lot before a match. Computers can store many chess games and help players study their opponents. In some matches, players have teams to help them find mistakes in the other player's games. The start of a chess game is very important. Being well-prepared can help win the game. There are many good chess players today. Many grandmasters play for small prize money around the world. Chess needs both physical and mental effort. A game can last up to eight hours. Players must concentrate all the time. A small mistake can be very bad. The chess clock makes the game more tense. At the end of the game, players have to move quickly. They have only seconds to make moves. This is very stressful. Winning feels great, but losing is very hard. One win is not enough to win a tournament. Chess competitions last 9-11 days, with games every day. There are tournaments all year. World championship matches are even harder. In 1984, a match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in Moscow stopped because they were too tired. Karpov lost a lot of weight.
Can Bobby Fischer win again? He once said, "All I want to do is play chess." This made his leaving chess in 1972 surprising. But it made him famous. If he came back for money, he will earn a lot. If he came back to prove he is the best, losing could be very sad for him.'

**Fame and Success**
Imogen Edwards-Jones talks to some new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are becoming famous.
**A. Nick Grosso**
Nick Grosso is in his early 30s and has written three successful plays. He is now turning his first play, "Peaches," into a movie script. Nick had never seen or read a play before writing "Peaches." He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After finishing school, he joined the Young People's Theatre. He wanted to write for actors because he liked the sound of words being spoken.
**B. Simon Pegg**
Simon Pegg, 28, studied drama at Bristol University. He is writing a TV comedy series and recently toured with comedy star Steve Coogan. Simon always liked comedy more than acting. He started performing in comedy clubs while at university. He believes making people laugh is wonderful if you have courage and good material.
**C. Ciaran McMenamin**
Ciaran McMenamin, 24, became famous as the lead in the TV series "The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star." He can now choose his work, which he always wanted. Ciaran started acting in school and joined the Ulster Youth Theatre. He used acting to avoid homework but later realized he loved it. He wants respect for doing good work, not just fame.
**D. Neil Taylor**
Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix. They have a deal for three albums with Domino Records. Neil has worked hard for his success, starting in music at 16. He met Rick Brown, who had contacts at Domino, and they formed Matrix. Neil is happy if even a few people buy their music.
**E. Stephen Richards**
Stephen Richards, 27, is a poet and author with many awards. He is well-known in the poetry world and is publishing his first novel, "Hidden," in March. Stephen loved creative writing in school but didn't go to university right away. He later published a children's book. He wants to write good quality work and not just produce a lot without care.

A. Isabel is an art student who is 31 years old. She likes historical romance stories and is looking for the perfect man. She thinks her knees might stop her from finding him. But she always has hope, which helps her and others in the story. The book is fun and exciting, like an old silent movie. 
B. This story is about a local radio station in America. A smart child named Francis works there. The station was started by Roy and Ray Soderbjerg to help their sandwich shop. The radio plays music, talks, and shows. The story is funny and takes us back to the 1940s and 1950s, with old cars and radios.
C. In this story, a professor named Richard Vaisey falls in love with a Russian poet. He talks about it with his wife's first husband. The poet writes bad poems and wants Richard to help her brother, who is in jail. The story is funny and looks at relationships closely.
D. Two women and two men are best friends in London during the 1960s. One of them, James Hudson, starts a newspaper with his friend Richard Blake. They both loved a woman who died years ago. The story has murder, ambition, love, and jealousy. It is a long book where you can really get to know the characters.
E. This story is about Ian Bedloe, who takes care of his brother's three children after feeling guilty about something he did. Ian is 40 years old and lives alone. The story shows his special relationship with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a warm and funny book.

**Volunteer Tourism**
Four writers talk about international volunteer work.
**A.** Volunteer tourists often help build homes or schools. They pay a lot of money to do this work. If they gave this money directly to the local community, it could pay for more work than one volunteer can do. This is true for gap year students who do not need special skills. Some studies question if these volunteers really want to help or if they just want to improve their careers. But, these projects can help volunteers learn to act kindly in their future jobs and lives.
**B.** Volunteering can help people from different countries understand each other better. It can help solve problems and create global friendships. This is good for both volunteers and the communities they visit. But, if only rich people can volunteer, it helps them more than the communities. These volunteers might use the experience to get ahead in their careers.
**C.** Sometimes, international volunteering can be seen as charity from rich countries. It can also be a way for volunteers to gain skills and experience. At its best, volunteering helps both the volunteers and the communities. It can teach skills and create cultural exchanges. Volunteering can also make people aware of poverty and injustice, and encourage them to fight these problems.
**D.** Volunteer tourism is about helping others. It is a simple way to make a difference and does not involve big governments or businesses. But, it can also ignore the bigger problems of poor communities. Volunteering is a good act, but when it is seen as a big solution to development, it can miss the real issues of global poverty.

'Choosing a Clock Radio Stuart Harris reports Many people listen to the radio in the morning and need an alarm to wake up. That's why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one? Our team, including me, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five clock radios. One model has a 'dual alarm function'. This means you can set two different wake-up times, one for weekdays and one for weekends. But not everyone needs this. This model also has a cassette player, which is nice because you can listen to your own music. The radio quality is good, but the clock radio is big. Paul Bridges said he needs space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. He also books a wake-up call just in case the alarm doesn't work. This model was the best-looking and the overall winner. Paul Bridges loved it, but the clock sometimes got stuck at 16.00. I liked the digital display with grey numbers on a green background. The snooze button is easy to find. The clock has a backup power, so you don't have to reset it if the power goes out. But it was hard to set up. Tom Granger didn't like the model with a built-in lamp. The lamp was hard to use, and the clock was difficult to set. The radio was also hard to tune. The buzzer was very loud. This model is popular with young people because of its bright colors. Tom Granger and I liked it because it was easy to set up without reading the instructions. But the alarm can be 10 minutes early or late. Paul Bridges thought it was too complicated and not useful. The simplest and cheapest model was liked by Tom Granger because it was small and easy to use. It has old-fashioned dial tuning, which is easy to set up. But the tuning was not very precise. The buzzer worked well and woke me up quickly.'

Hedgehogs
A hedgehog is a small animal with sharp spines on its body. Hedgehogs live in many places around the world, but not in America or Australia. All hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when they are scared. This helps protect them because their spines stick out. How well this works depends on how many spines the hedgehog has. Some hedgehogs that live in the desert have fewer spines. They might try to run away from danger first and roll into a ball only if they have to. Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day. They sleep under bushes or in holes in the ground. All hedgehogs can hibernate, which means they sleep for a long time in winter. But not all hedgehogs hibernate; some stay awake all year if the weather is good.

**Great Sports Women on a Winning Streak**
Being good at sports is hard, especially for women. They have to work very hard and give up a lot of their normal life. But many women are doing great and breaking records. Here are some amazing British sportswomen:
**A. Jill, 27, Skier**
Jill loves skiing. She says it feels great to fly through the air, but it can be scary. Skiing takes a lot of time, so she doesn't have much time for friends. There are six men and three women in her team, and they all compete together.
**B. Caroline, 22, Cyclist**
Caroline started cycling two years ago and won her first race. She trains a lot, about four hours every day. Her boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands how much time she needs to train.
**C. Annabel, 26, Rower**
Annabel says rowing is hard for girls because not many schools offer it. She started when she was 19. Even though it's tough, she loves being fit and enjoys the social life.
**D. Ffyona, 24, Long Distance Walker**
Ffyona dreamed of walking around the world when she was 13. She walked across Australia, which was very hard. She walked 50 miles a day with little sleep. She did it to get a record and because she needed the money from sponsors.
**E. Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**
Lisa races cars. She says some men don't like it when she does well. Racing is hard, and she doesn't earn much money. But more women are starting to race, and she loves trying to make the perfect lap.
**F. Alison, 28, Triathlete**
Alison trains a lot, getting up early to swim. She sometimes falls asleep at work because of her training. She likes racing because it keeps her fit and is social. Men and women often race together, but the men's events get more attention. She is part of a group working to change this.

Title: The Day I Met Picasso
Richard Cork remembers meeting the famous artist Picasso when he was 18 years old. Richard was traveling around Europe and Morocco before starting university. He had run out of money and found a job painting boats in Cannes, France. One day, while eating at a restaurant, he saw Picasso having lunch with his wife and friends. Richard was surprised because Picasso was known to be a private person.
Richard's friend encouraged him to ask Picasso for his autograph. Nervously, Richard approached Picasso and offered his sketchbook. Picasso kindly signed his name and drew a little picture on the page. Richard was very happy and started a conversation with Picasso, even though they needed help from an American woman to translate.
After showing his friend the autograph, Richard's friend suggested he go back and draw Picasso's portrait. Richard returned to Picasso's table and started drawing him. Picasso made funny faces and gestures, making it hard for Richard to draw. But eventually, Picasso sat still, allowing Richard to finish the portrait.
When Richard showed Picasso the drawing, Picasso smiled and decided to draw Richard in return. In a few quick strokes, Picasso drew a playful picture of Richard. Richard was amazed and thanked Picasso, asking if he could sign the drawing. Picasso, through the American woman, said Richard already had his signature.
Richard felt very lucky to have met Picasso and to have received his attention. It was a special moment that meant a lot to him.

**Shopping Tricks**
Have you ever gone to a store and bought more than you planned? Stores use tricks to make you spend more money. Here are some of them:
A. **Fresh Look**
Supermarkets know people like fresh food. They put fruits and vegetables at the entrance to look fresh. They might also have a bakery with the smell of fresh bread. The store might use green colors because it makes people think of fresh things.
B. **Smart Display**
Where products are placed in the store is very important. Supermarkets use computers to know where people buy the most. They put expensive or fast-selling items there. Shelves at eye level are popular because people see them first. Special offers are put in big bins to attract people who love deals. Sometimes, they put things that go together, like salad dressing near salads.
C. **Staples Spread Out**
Supermarkets put basic items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, you see other things you might want to buy. Stores put popular items far away too, so you walk past other products.
D. **Less is More**
Some stores show fewer items to make them look special. Next stores do this with clothes. They look like boutiques, even though the clothes are not unique. This makes people think the clothes are special.
E. **Price Tricks**
People care more about the total bill than each item's price. Supermarkets mix cheap and expensive items. They might sell some things very cheap to get you in the store. They buy in large amounts to get discounts.
F. **Price Tags**
In chain stores, people notice prices more. Pricing something at $14.99 instead of $15 makes a difference. It also helps reduce theft because staff must ring up the sale to give change.
G. **Lighting**
Stores use special lighting. Chain stores want natural light so clothes look the same outside. Supermarkets use lights to make food look better.
H. **Walking Paths**
Stores use different carpets to guide you. One type is for walking paths, and another is for sales areas. Some stores use wood or marble for paths to make you walk on the carpet in sales areas.
I. **In-Store Ads**
When you enter a supermarket, you see big pictures of tasty food. In the U.S., some supermarkets use video screens on shopping carts. These show ads for products as you shop. They are for people who buy on impulse and can increase sales by 30%.

Chris Bonnington, a 58-year-old mountaineer, is famous for climbing Mount Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing paths in Britain and the Alps and written books like "Quest for Adventure" and "Everest the Hard Way." Robin Knox-Johnston, 53, started his sea career in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-9, he was the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He also set a record by sailing from New York to the Lizard in 10 days. Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland, and they wrote about it in their book "Sea, Ice and Rock."
In 1979, Chris was working on a book about adventure after the war. He called Robin for an interview, and Robin invited him to sail. Chris could teach Robin some climbing, and Robin could teach Chris about sailing. It was Chris's first time on a yacht. They sailed, anchored, and then went to shore to climb. Chris was impressed by Robin's calmness while climbing. Robin had never climbed before, so Chris showed him how. Robin wanted to climb down using his arms, like on his boat, but Chris wanted him to use his legs. Robin managed to climb down safely.
During their trip to Skye, Chris and Robin became good friends. Robin suggested they combine their skills for a trip to Greenland. Chris admired Robin as a leader because he asked for everyone's opinion before making decisions. Chris found sailing boring and difficult because he preferred being on land. Robin, however, enjoyed fixing things on the boat. Chris sometimes felt useless because Robin didn't need much help.
The yacht was small, with six people on board, but it was only meant for four. In Greenland, Chris led the climbing part of the trip. He was worried about Robin's safety because if Robin fell, he could pull Chris down too. Climbing Greenland's highest mountain, the Cathedral, was harder than Chris expected. Robin wasn't a natural climber, but he did well. They tried to reach the top for 24 hours but had to turn back. Robin trusted Chris and followed his lead.
On the way home, there was a small problem. Chris was supposed to take a turn watching the boat at 4 am, but Robin didn't wake him up. Chris felt Robin didn't trust him, but Robin reassured him it was a misunderstanding. By the end of the Greenland trip, Chris learned that Robin was a kind and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**
**Early Apples (8,000 BC)**
People have been eating apples for a very long time. In ancient times, people in Britain and around Swiss and Italian lakes ate wild apples. These apples were small and not like the ones we eat today. In Switzerland, people even saved apple halves for winter.
**Apples in Britain (1000 AD)**
The French learned how to grow fruit from the Romans. They brought this knowledge to Britain. The Normans, who came after the Romans, introduced new apple types that grew better in Britain. Monks in Britain worked on creating new apple varieties, which are the ancestors of many apples we have today.
**Popular Apples (1200)**
In the 1200s, some apples became very popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain was a favorite dessert apple. The Costard was used for cooking. However, during hard times like droughts and wars, fewer apples were grown, and more were imported. In the 1500s, King Henry VIII sent Richard Harris to France to learn more about growing apples. Harris brought back new apple types and started a modern orchard in Kent.
**Apples Around the World (1750)**
By the 1600s, apples were so loved in Britain that settlers took them to new places like Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia, and the Pilgrim Fathers took them to America. In America, Johnny Appleseed was famous for planting apple trees.
**Modern Apples (1850)**
In Iowa, a farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a new apple tree. The apple was so tasty that it was named 'Delicious' and became very popular. In Australia, Maria Anne Smith found a new green apple tree. This apple became known as the 'Granny Smith' and is famous worldwide.
**Today's Apples (1950)**
Today, apples are grown everywhere, from India to Africa. Most apples come from just a few types, chosen for their looks and ability to travel well, not for taste. Many old apple varieties have been lost, especially in the US. People now want more variety in apples. It's important to protect different types of apples for the future.

**Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures**
Explore Worldwide offers exciting travel for people who want more than just a beach holiday. We focus on new and unusual places with interesting plans. Our brochure has over 100 adventures like tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions in more than 60 countries. Most trips last 1-4 weeks.
**Small Groups**
Our groups are small, usually 16 people. This helps you learn more about the places we visit. You get to know the local people and culture better. It's a fun experience for everyone.
**Different Ways to Travel**
We use many types of transport, sometimes on the same trip. We travel by bus, train, minibus, boat, canoe, camel, plane, and often on foot. Each trip matches the local area.
**Who Travels with Explore?**
Our travelers are interesting people who like new experiences. They come from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Our trips are for people who are healthy, fit, and adaptable. Most are aged 25-55. About half are couples, and the rest travel alone.
**Activities and Interests**
Each trip is unique. We have 8 categories of adventures, each with special highlights. These include unique places, meeting local people, and learning about different cultures.
**Cultural/Adventure Trips**
Many trips focus on local cultures and history. We visit places like Egypt, India, China, and Peru. We often take short walks to see special sites.
**Wildlife and Natural History**
Our safaris visit famous parks to see animals in the wild. In Africa, you can walk in the wild, track gorillas, or ride a canoe. We camp or stay in hotels and lodges.
**Ethnic Encounters**
Meet local tribes like the Tuareg in the Sahara or the Maya in Mexico. We travel in small groups to respect their culture and environment.
**Easy/Moderate Hiking**
Some trips include easy walks in the countryside. We stay in hotels or village houses. Your main luggage is transported for you.
**Major Treks**
For strong walkers, we offer treks in mountains like the Himalayas and Andes. We stay with local people or camp.
**Wilderness Experience**
Explore remote areas like the Amazon Rainforest or the Sahara Desert. These are exciting adventures.
**Sailtreks/Seatreks**
Relax on a boat trip. We use local boats in places like Egypt and Turkey. Explore islands in Indonesia or the Galapagos.
**Raft and River Journeys**
River trips can be a few hours or several days. You can paddle yourself or enjoy whitewater rafting. No experience is needed, and safety is important. Our trips in India, Africa, and the Amazon show you beautiful nature.

Richard Nerurkar is a long-distance runner from Britain. He is one of the top 10,000-meter runners. Richard visited a special training camp in Kenya. This camp is in a place called Nanyuki, near Mount Kenya. Mount Kenya is a very high mountain with snow on top. Richard has been coming to this place for three years to train in the winter. But he never trained with Kenyan runners before. On his fourth trip, he decided to change that. He ran his first race in Kenya and stayed at the national team training camp. This camp is where the best Kenyan runners get ready for big races. Richard was invited by the Kenyan coach because he did well in a big race, finishing fifth.
Training at high places like this camp helps runners because it makes their bodies better at using oxygen. Many Kenyan runners have been very successful because of this. Richard's first race in Africa was in Nairobi. It was the first international cross-country race in Africa. Richard found it very challenging. Many Kenyan runners finished before him, but he still felt he did well.
Kenyan runners are known for their simple way of running and living. They enjoy running and competing. Richard wanted to know how they train. At the camp, he found out. The camp is at St Mark's College, high up on Mount Kenya. It is a simple place with not many comforts. The runners live with college students, six people in one room. They train three times a day: an easy run in the morning, harder training in the middle of the day, and another run in the afternoon. They run about 40 kilometers every day, except on Sundays when they run 20 kilometers.
Life at the camp is simple. In the morning, they wash their face and brush their teeth. Breakfast is tea, bread, and boiled eggs. Lunch and dinner are similar: a maize dish called ugali, stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After running, they go to a stream to wash.
Richard learned a lot from his time at the camp. He thinks Kenyan runners are successful not just because of their genes or the high altitude. He believes their simple lifestyle, hard training, and love for running are the real reasons for their success.

**Hit and Miss of Mass Marketing**
Advertising is having problems. It's not just because of the recession. Advertising started to go down in 1989, before the recession got bad. The problem is bigger and affects the whole world. Advertising has not changed with the economy. Advertisers think about big markets and big media, but now there are many brands and media, and markets are smaller. Big brands should focus on small groups, but they often don't. This is where advertising is going wrong.
Think about your shopping. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30 to 50 items. Many of these are not advertised brands. You might buy a few advertised brands from the 15,000 items in the store. In a year, you probably buy only a few hundred brands. For things like cars, you might buy one every three years. You don't buy many clothes either, and most are not advertised brands. Even with candy, medicine, and other services, you probably buy less than 400 different brands a year.
There are 32,500 branded goods and services advertised. Let's focus on the 9,500 brands that spend more on advertising. Mr. and Mrs. Average buy 400 of these, and not all because of ads. That's about 4%. So, 96% of advertising might be wasted, but nobody knows which part. When you watch TV, count how many ads are for brands you buy or might buy. For most people, it's about 1 in 16 (6%). The other 15 (94%) are wasted.
You might think ads don't affect you, but they do. Most people don't buy most brands they see advertised. Waste is part of advertising. Not everyone who sees an ad will buy the product. People notice only a few ads and ignore the rest. But advertising can still be cost-effective. It reaches many people to find the few who will buy. Even with smart targeting, advertisers can't know exactly who will respond.
Face-to-face selling is different. A salesperson might succeed with every client. This can't happen with media. If advertisers knew who would respond, they wouldn't need media. They could talk to people directly. This is true for all ads, from soft drinks to important notices. If an ad gets one million new customers (2% of adults), it's doing well. For soap powder, the top brands would be happy with a million new customers. Any ad campaign that wins over 2% of people is very successful. To succeed, advertising needs to target its message better.

'Charles Clover visits Britain's most environmentally-friendly home. Southwell in Nottinghamshire has two surprises. The first is Southwell Minster, an old cathedral with 'green' men carved into it. The second is the 'autonomous house', built by Robert and Brenda Vale. The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle their waste into garden compost, and heat their house with heat from electrical appliances and their own body heat, along with their three children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. The house looks traditional with a clay roof and is 300 yards from the Minster. It matches the town's old buildings and was approved by planners even though it is in a protected area. The house is very quiet because it is super-insulated with special windows. Inside, you must take off your shoes. The house is very quiet and still. On a sunny day, the conservatory warms the air before it goes into the house. Robert opens windows to let in air because the house is very airtight. Even the cats have their own small door. The Vales, who teach architecture, cared about the environment before it was popular. They wrote a book on green architecture in the 1970s. They designed a house that does not use carbon dioxide and does not need mains water. They use composting toilets, rainwater tanks, and copper gutters to keep the water clean. Water from washing goes into the garden. They do not have a dishwasher because they do not want to use strong detergents. They wanted to show that it is possible to have an environmentally-friendly house without living in the dark. The house looks old in style, but it is modern. The Vales do not pay water bills. Last winter, they used only a small amount of electricity, costing about 70p a day. Soon, they will use even less with new solar panels. The house will make extra electricity, enough to charge an electric car. The only heating is a small wood stove, used only in very cold weather. In winter, the house is warm enough without extra heating. The house is low-tech and easy to fix. Most materials came from local builders, making it cheap to build. Commercial builders do not like this idea.'

'The camera never lies Arthur Conan Doyle, who created the Sherlock Holmes stories, thought he was a logical man, like a scientist. But in 1920, when he saw photos of fairies in a garden, he believed they were real. He published the photos with an article he wrote, saying fairies were amazing supernatural things. In 1939, the two women who took the photos said they were fake. They had cut out pictures of fairies from a book and put them among flowers. The photos are very pretty. But this simple trick shows that the camera can lie. Today, we know we can change our digital photos with computer software. It is not true that photography was always honest. From the start, photos could be changed.'

**Blacksmiths**
Iron has always been important to people, and blacksmiths, the people who work with iron, have been seen as special. Before machines were common, blacksmiths were as important as doctors because they made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also seen as artists. In the 1700s, blacksmiths made beautiful ironwork for places like St Paul's Cathedral. The fancy metalwork in French and Belgian buildings was also made by skilled blacksmiths.
By the late 1960s, there were not many blacksmiths left in Britain. Big factories did not need them anymore, and new buildings did not use pretty ironwork. But in the last 10 years, blacksmithing has become popular again because people are more interested in decorative buildings and new interior designs. Still, many ironworks look old-fashioned, like 'classical' or 'Victorian-style' gates and balconies. In many design stores, you see rusty candlesticks with decorations.
Luckily, there are new ideas, and some events are happening to show blacksmiths' work. One event is an exhibition by the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA) at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, says we might be starting a new Iron Age. Power tools help blacksmiths work more easily, allowing them to create art with metal.
About 250 pieces are in the show, from bookends to a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and go much higher. Most money goes to the makers, but some helps promote good ironwork. Dawson made an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. He says his style is like drawing with metal.
Many artists love working with iron. Unlike other metals, iron is hard to shape when cold but soft when hot. Susan May, a jeweler, says it's magical because it changes from soft to hard. Ann Catrin Evans makes door-knockers and handles inspired by castles in horror films. She likes that steel feels strong and lasting.
Iron has given people visual pleasure and a feeling of safety. It will likely be used decoratively for many years, as long as we avoid more rusty candlesticks.

Title: The Day I Stopped Smoking
I thought everyone would be happy when I stopped smoking, but one of my coworkers was very angry. She said, "If it was so easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I couldn't really explain how I went from smoking a pack a day to not smoking at all in just four hours. It was strange to me too.
I went to a stop-smoking session that was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy. This happened two months and three weeks ago. I didn't plan to stop smoking, and I didn't really want to. I didn't like the pressure from people who wanted everyone to stop smoking. Also, I was healthy and didn't feel sick from smoking. I didn't cough and got over colds quickly, unlike some of my healthier friends.
On a normal Thursday afternoon, I went to a session called "The Easy Way to Stop Smoking" in Birmingham. I was there to write an article about other people trying to quit smoking. I told them, "I won't try to stop myself because I'm here to write, not to quit." I thought I was being fair. I actually enjoyed smoking; it made me happy.
The counselor seemed to understand something I didn't. We were allowed to smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was full of smoke. But when they told us to smoke, I didn't really want to, and neither did the others. The messages about stopping smoking made sense to me. The idea of not smoking started to feel good. It was a personal feeling, just for me.
Stopping smoking was easier than I thought. The cravings for nicotine, which felt like hunger, went away after a minute or two. I only felt them for four or five days. I thought working without cigarettes would be hard, but it wasn't a problem at all. I was surprised that being at home on weekend mornings was the hardest part, and it still is. I think smoking was something I did when I was bored.
I do miss smoking, but not too much. I have to get used to doing things without smoking, like eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, or during a theater break. These were times when I used to smoke.

Margaret and Her Special Talent
Margaret Wilkins has a special talent. She can find water underground using a simple tool called a fork of hazel wood. Many farmers ask for her help when their wells dry up. Margaret and her husband have a business that drills wells. They use machines like drilling rigs and hammers. But to find water, Margaret only needs her special stick.
People say Margaret has a "sixth sense." This means she can do something that seems like magic. She can find water, minerals, and lost things underground. Some people think this is because everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more than other things. Margaret can feel these vibrations. She says she can even smell water.
In recent years, there has been less rain, so Margaret has been very busy. Many farmers need her help because their wells are dry. She also helps people who have holiday homes far from water pipes. Some golf course builders also need her help to find water.
Margaret looks for water that is deep underground, between 50 and 70 meters. She makes sure the water is clean and not mixed with waste. The water is in small cracks in hard rock. It is important to have electricity nearby to pump the water up.
To find water, Margaret starts with a map and a pendulum. She moves the pendulum over the map, and it swings when there is water. Then, she walks on the land with her special stick. When she is over water, she feels something strange and uses the stick to find the exact spot to drill. The stick moves up when it is over water.
Margaret's husband also checks the spot. They must agree on where to drill. If they don't agree, they keep looking.
Many people are interested in how Margaret finds water. She calls it "feeling the environment." This is how she and her family make a living with their well-drilling business. Without her special talent, they could not do this work.

**We changed lives for a day!**
Have you ever thought about living someone else's life for a day? Maybe you think it would be fun to try something different. We helped four people do this. Here is what happened.
**Amanda's Story**
Amanda is 23 years old and has two daughters. She swapped lives with her friend Cindy, who is 30 and works as a waitress in a busy London restaurant.
Amanda had never been in a place like the restaurant before. It was dark, noisy, and full of people. She had to learn how to carry a tray of drinks with one hand. It was hard, and she dropped the drinks on the floor. The other waitresses laughed and said everyone makes mistakes at first.
By 11:30 am, there was a line of people waiting to come in. Amanda was nervous about remembering orders, but everything was done by computer. After a few hours, her feet hurt, and the loud music was hard to get used to. She had to ask customers to repeat themselves, which was embarrassing. By 5 pm, she was very tired and wanted to rest her feet. She was surprised to hear it was a "quiet" day. Amanda realized waitressing is hard work and not well-paid. She was happy to go back to her children.
**Cindy's Story**
Cindy was nervous but excited to be a "mum" for the day. She thought she could handle Amanda's cheeky daughters, but it was harder than she expected. After taking Sophie to school and Katie to nursery, Cindy thought she would have some free time. But Amanda left a note with chores to do.
In the afternoon, Cindy picked up the girls. They were full of energy, jumping on the sofa and screaming. Cindy tried to stay calm, thinking they would get tired, but they didn't. She finally got them to bed by 8 pm, but they kept asking for water to stay up and watch TV. Cindy found it tiring to look after two small children. She didn't have time for herself and felt a big sense of responsibility. Still, she enjoyed the day.
**Rosemary's Story**
Rosemary is 42 and runs a dairy farm. She swapped with Hilary, a 30-year-old primary school teacher.
On the farm, Rosemary wakes up at 5:30 am, so sleeping until 7 am felt like a treat. She was nervous about what to wear to school. At assembly, she saw about 400 students and hoped she blended in.
Rosemary helped with a math class and a nature project about snails. By lunchtime, she was tired but found out teachers only have a short break. She attended a meeting and helped with sports trials. After lunch, there was a reading lesson and a French lesson. The children wanted to practice French with her, which was fun but showed her rusty skills. By the end of the day, she was exhausted. Rosemary found teaching hard, especially speaking in front of the class. She decided she preferred farming.
**Hilary's Story**
Hilary arrived at the farm at 8:30 am and found out Rosemary had been working for three hours already. The farm has 100 cows, 15 calves, and about 800 sheep. Rosemary also makes ice cream, yogurt, and cream.
Hilary spent the morning in the ice cream shop, bottling milk and packing ice cream. At lunchtime, she checked the sheep and helped a fallen ewe. She learned that sheep need to be checked every day. After feeding the calves, she started milking the cows, which took two and a half hours. Rosemary does this twice a day, every day of the year.
Hilary found the farm work lonely and missed the children from school. She realized farming is hard because you can't take time off. Rosemary only gets about three days of holiday a year. Hilary thought farming seemed romantic, but the reality is different. The income is not steady, and the weather can be a big problem.

'A trumpet isn't just for Christmas... Many musicians come from homes without music. Hakan Hardenberger is one of them. He is from southern Sweden and is now a famous trumpet player. He is 30 years old. His parents did not play music, but they gave him a trumpet as a Christmas present when he was eight. His father liked Louis Armstrong and wanted to give his son a real trumpet, not a toy. Hakan loved the gift and played it all the time. His mother found a teacher for him, Bo Nilsson, who was a trumpet player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra. Bo saw that Hakan had talent and helped him a lot. Hakan learned to work with the trumpet's imperfections and developed his own sound. He always wanted to be a solo artist, not play in an orchestra. He admired Maurice Andre, a French trumpeter, and listened to all his records. Hakan's parents supported his dream to be a trumpet player. At 16, he went to Paris to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud also thought playing in an orchestra was not for Hakan. At 17, Hakan entered a competition in Paris. He did not win first prize, but he realized he could connect with people through his music. Hakan does not like to explain why he can communicate so well with music because he thinks it might ruin the magic. He believes music can always move people.'

**A.** The story of Tristan Smith takes place in a made-up country called Efica. It is a special story about human power, history, and humor. The author has created a world with its own history and traditions. The book is funny and shows the author's special way of seeing things. It is a difficult book to read, but it is worth it.
**B.** Harriet is a middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. She usually would not meet someone like Sheila, who is from a working-class background. Sheila takes care of her old father and her grandson, Leo. Their lives change when Leo attacks Harriet's son, Joe. After the court case, both boys do not want to talk about it. Leo was a good student and never fought before, but he won't say why he did it. Joe gets better physically but becomes quiet. Harriet is very worried about her son, and it takes over her life. Sheila feels very guilty and asks to meet Harriet. They become friends. The author is good at showing how people deal with big changes in their lives.
**C.** This book was nominated for the Booker prize. It tells the story of a small island in Scotland and its people over a long time. The story includes important moments in Scottish history. The main character, Throfinn Ragnarson, dreams about these moments. He disappears at one point but comes back after World War II. He learns to appreciate the simple life of his ancestors.
**D.** After a successful book, the author wrote a sequel with the same gentle humor and observations about family life. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway is almost seventy. She has a lively friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora is charming and kind, and Rosie helps her with her life. By the end of the book, Aurora realizes that time has passed and a new generation is important. The author shows the sadness in everyday life and how random events can be.
**E.** Six different people are brought together by a rich man named Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful language to describe how each person learns about themselves during the trip. They return home with new energy and understanding. The author uses strong images to show themes of memory and awareness. These images are both strange and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**
Rebecca Cripps talks to five women about their jobs. They share the good and bad parts and what a normal workday looks like.
**A. The Brain Surgeon**
- **Name:** Anne
- **Age:** 34
**Anne's Day:**
Anne wakes up at 6:30 am, goes to the gym at 7 am, and starts work at 8 am. She begins surgery at 8:30 am. She operates all day on Monday and Wednesday, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most surgeries take three hours, but some can last all day. Anne sometimes works for ten hours without eating or taking a break. Deciding when and how to operate can be stressful. She feels good when surgeries are successful. From 10 am to 1 pm, she talks to patients about their operations. She leaves work between 6 pm and 8 pm. Sometimes she is on call at night and on weekends. On holidays, she worries about her patients and dreams about work.
**B. The Senior Designer**
- **Name:** Marita
- **Age:** 31
**Marita's Day:**
Marita wakes up at 7:45 am, leaves home by 8:20 am, and arrives at work by 9:15 am. On Monday at 10:30 am, her team meets to discuss work. Her team has three senior designers, a company partner, and a junior designer. Marita spends three to four weeks designing and developing projects. She talks to clients and manages budgets. She also works with photographers and illustrators. Marita manages many tasks at once, which can be stressful. She has lunch at 1 pm for an hour. She gets home at 7:30 pm or later and finds it hard to relax.
**C. The Chauffeur**
- **Name:** Linda
- **Age:** 42
**Linda's Day:**
Linda usually wakes up at 7 am, but on some days she gets up between 4:30 am and 5 am to meet flights. She exercises to stay healthy. Linda knows a lot about restaurants and shops because clients ask for recommendations. Most jobs are booked in advance, so she can plan her routes. Some passengers are rude, but most are nice. Linda works seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day. She tries to sleep by 11 pm.
**D. The Landscape Gardener**
- **Name:** Tracy
- **Age:** 27
**Tracy's Day:**
Tracy wakes up at 7 am and starts work at 7:30 am. She and her assistant maintain gardens. They work in private gardens and spend about an hour and a half at each place. They have breakfast at 11 am. In summer, Tracy works until 10 pm; in winter, until 4:30 pm. She listens to messages and calls clients in the evening. Tracy uses old materials to make gardens look old. She finds it hard to relax because she can hear the business phone. She sleeps well because her job is very physical.
**E. The Civil Engineer**
- **Name:** Zena
- **Age:** 27
**Zena's Day:**
Zena arrives at the construction site by 8:30 am. She helps build bridges and a wall to keep cars safe. She checks that workers follow the plan and safety rules. Zena talks to the site professionals and solves problems. She eats lunch quickly between 2 pm and 2:30 pm. Zena checks the workers' progress and keeps a good relationship with them. She leaves the site at about 6 pm and is always on call.

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Typical Working Day**
**A. Credit Card Executive**
I wake up at 6 am and get to the office by 7:30 am. I work with customer programs for our credit card users. I also manage the Membership Rewards program in Europe. I talk to current card users, find new ones, and work with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes planning my day and answering emails. I handle advertising for the membership program, so I meet with marketing staff and advertising agencies. I have meetings most of the day, but I keep my door open for questions. I travel to different markets in Europe once or twice a week. When I'm in London, I leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.
**B. Record Company Executive**
I start work at 10:00 am and check the mail, which includes demo tapes, letters, and invoices. The phone starts ringing at 10:30 am with calls from producers and publishers. I have meetings about campaigns or projects for artists. When I listen to demo tapes, I try to be helpful. I know if the sound is right for our label. After signing a band, we work on the first album. I share my ideas for the album with the company for marketing. I also manage budgets. I leave work at 7:00 pm and often go to concerts, sometimes seeing up to five new groups a night. I might visit an artist in the studio after a concert. I usually get home at 1:00 am and listen to music to relax.
**C. Sales Director**
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving at 9:30 am. I check the mail and diary to see if we have clients visiting. I enjoy showing people around the showroom and selling furniture. We sell antiques and buy from various places. Some items need fixing, so I work with restorers. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette to stay updated and visit the Victoria and Albert Museum to compare furniture. I do the accounts once a month and tax returns every three months. I go home at 5:30 pm and take about an hour to relax.
**D. Air Traffic Controller**
I work in shifts. On early shifts, I leave home at 6:00 am and start work at 7:00 am. I take over one of the four control positions in the tower. We work in a team to control aircraft movements. In winter, we handle about 1,000 movements a day, more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, and I can read about new air traffic rules. It's important to be alert, so I take sick leave if needed. The job is stressful, and it takes time to relax after a shift. I hope to become a watch manager and maybe a general manager one day.
**E. Shop Manager**
On early shifts, I leave home by 8:00 am. I start the electronic sales system and make sure someone is at the till. I help customers find and order books. I enjoy serving customers, even if it can be annoying when they bring reviews and expect me to find many books. Between 2:00 pm and 4:00 pm, publishers' reps visit, and I discuss new books. I decide how many copies to order. I ensure new titles arrive on time. The early shift ends at 5:45 pm. I work late shifts twice a week, closing the shop and going home.
**F. Financial Analyst**
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then take a taxi to work, arriving at 8:45 am. I contact freelance reporters to learn about my region. I assess financial risks for companies abroad. I provide three services: an online newsflash, a security forecast, and a travel security guide. I meet with editors from 9:15 am to 9:30 am to discuss stories. My first newsflash is due by 10:00 am, and the second by 11:00 am. I write, send, and edit stories before they go online. I travel to Africa three times a year to report on events. I leave work around 6:00 pm, but I often stay awake until 1:00 am.

**Career Power: How to Be a Good Leader**
A. **What is a Good Leader?**
A good leader is someone who inspires others and helps them change. A leader shows the way forward. Leadership is not about being tall or very smart. Pat Dixon, who wrote a book about men and women at work, says leadership is about making things happen with people who are as excited as you are. A good leader should speak clearly and with confidence. They should say "I believe" instead of "I think."
B. **Can Anyone Be a Leader?**
John van Maurik, who teaches about leadership, says many people can be leaders, but they don't know it. We all have some leadership skills. We just need the right time and place to use them. We often see leaders like Mahatma Gandhi or Richard Branson, but leadership is also important in our own jobs.
C. **Think About Your Bosses**
Think about the best and worst boss you had. Both might have been good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But the best boss motivated you and supported you. The worst boss made you feel unimportant and blamed you when things went wrong. The first boss was a good leader; the second was not.
D. **Leaders vs. Managers**
Leaders and managers are different. Managers like to work within rules. Leaders create new ideas. A good manager can keep a company running. A good leader can change a company for the better.
E. **Improve Your Leadership Skills**
Whether you are the boss or not, you can learn to be a better leader. Here are some tips:
- Find out what you are passionate about and use that energy to lead.
- Think of yourself as a leader. Believe in your ability to lead.
- Sometimes you need to be firm. Try different ways to lead and see what works best.
- Set goals and try to beat them. Look at your job and see where you can be a leader.
F. **Keep Learning**
- Leadership takes practice. You need to take risks and learn from mistakes.
- Learn how to motivate and organize people. Praise them when they do well.
- Your way of leading might not work for everyone. Keep improving your communication skills.
