- Be visible and easy to talk to. But remember, you don't have to lead all the time. Know when your help is needed and help others become leaders too.

**Films on Video: Reviews by Nick James**
**A. Abyss**  
Before making Titanic, director James Cameron created this exciting Cold War movie. It is about oil workers and navy experts trying to save a submarine deep underwater. The main character, Bud, and his team are brave and funny. The special effects are very good, but the story is simple.
**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This movie is based on a book about the battle for Guadalcanal. It is directed by Andrew Marton. The movie focuses on one soldier and his tough sergeant. It is different from Terrence Malick's new film, which is more poetic. Marton's version is simpler but has strong moments, like a dream about the soldier's wife.
**C. On Guard**  
This movie is based on a novel from 1875. It is a fun adventure with swords and heroes. Fabrice Luchini plays a clever villain, and Vincent Perez is a lively hero. The movie has many costume-drama clichés, but it is entertaining.
**D. Character**  
This story takes place in old Rotterdam. The film looks like a museum piece because of its detailed costumes and sets. Jan Decleir plays a strict bailiff named Dreverhaven. The story is about his difficult relationship with his son. The film focuses a lot on the historical details.
**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This is a new version of the classic movie. The sound is very clear, and the music is exciting. The story is about three men, the good (Clint Eastwood), the bad (Lee van Cleef), and the ugly (Eli Wallach), who are all looking for treasure. They are all tough and not very nice.
**F. The Longest Day**  
This is a long war movie with many stars and extras. It shows the planning of a big invasion. The movie is impressive but feels too long. It is better to watch on a big screen because the video version is not as good.

**BOOK A**  
"Compelling Evidence" by Steve Martin is a very interesting book. The story is about a lawyer who starts a new job after leaving a big law firm. He has to defend his boss's wife in a murder trial. The trial is exciting, and the ending is surprising. This is a great first book in a popular genre.
**BOOK B**  
"Curtains for the Cardinal" is an exciting story. It is about Sigismondo, who helps rich people in Italy during the Renaissance. He deals with politics, church secrets, and murder. The story is a bit complicated and long, but it is still very good.
**BOOK C**  
"File Under: Deceased" is a new detective story by Sarah Lacey. The main character, Leah Hunter, is a tax inspector. She starts investigating when a man dies near her. Leah is brave and smart, and she does not give up, even when people are against her. This makes her a great character.
**BOOK D**  
"Double Deuce" by Robert B. Parker is about a private investigator named Spenser. He helps his friend Hawk to stop drug dealers in a poor area of Boston. The story has fast conversations and some action. It is very entertaining.
**BOOK E**  
"False Prophet" by Faye Kellermann is about detectives Pete Decker and Marge Dunn. They investigate a crime at the home of a famous actress's daughter. The author writes in an easy way and shows interesting human behavior, making the mystery fun to read.
**BOOK F**  
"Blood Red, Snow White" is written by Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock. It is about a lawyer and his female client. The story happens outside the courtroom, and the lawyer becomes a victim. The book has romance, money, and violence, making it a thrilling story.
**BOOK G**  
"Dead for a Ducat" by Simon Shaw is about actor Philip Fletcher. He is in danger while filming a Robin Hood story. The book has funny characters, but it is not as good as Shaw's other books.
**BOOK H**  
"Fall Down Easy" by Lawrence Gough is a great book. It is about Canadian police chasing a smart bank robber who targets female bank workers. The story builds tension slowly and is better than most detective stories.

Tim Pozzi is 34 years old. He left his good job to go backpacking. He wants to travel in South East Asia for a year. Tim is nervous because he is older now. After university, he traveled in North and South America for two years. He wanted to travel again, but he got a job, fell in love, and bought a house. He realized he was not happy with just earning money. When he quit his job, he felt free. Many of his friends are married with children. They have responsibilities, but Tim does not. He is not in a relationship and has no big career plans. He wants to enjoy his freedom.
Tim is nervous about making plans. He worries about renting his home and choosing where to go. He is also worried about living simply again and meeting young backpackers. But he found out that many people in their late twenties and thirties want to travel. They want to take a break from their lives. Jennifer Cox from Lonely Planet says people now know they can have adventures if they are brave and organized.
Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, are traveling for a year before settling down. Danny says he is okay with leaving his job for the trip. Matt, who was in the Army, traveled for a year to change his way of thinking. Many people travel to think about their lives and what they want.
Some companies let people take breaks from work. Dan Hiscocks from Travellerseye says many people in their thirties are thinking about their lives. They know jobs are not forever, and travel helps them think about what they want. Jennifer Cox says people now want a balanced life, not just to pay bills. Ben, a 32-year-old, is going to Central America. He is excited but also nervous about leaving his routine.
Tim is also nervous about leaving his comfortable life. But he is excited about the next year. He wants to enjoy life and feels happy about his decision. Many people like Tim are choosing to travel and find new adventures.

'Using Technology at Home
Georgina McGuiness took a long break from her job in journalism. She felt she didn't know much about new technology. Here, she tells how she changed her home into a good place to work.
Two Christmases ago, I turned 37. I realized I needed to restart my career in journalism. My skills were old. I used to work with a typewriter and carbon paper. Now, jobs wanted people with computer skills, like desktop publishing, which I didn't know. I was afraid of technology. Even simple things like calculators were hard for me. I didn't know how to use the video timer. I needed to learn quickly.
I entered a competition in a local newspaper. My family and I won a computer package. We got a laptop for my husband and a personal computer for the family. We started learning about the Internet and new words like cyberspace and surfing. We talked to people around the world online. The children stopped watching TV. I made a small office in the kitchen with a phone, fax machine, CD-ROM, and modem. I could work from home and still take the kids to school.
The children were good with computers because they learned at school. I was scared I would lose my work if I pressed the wrong button. But I learned the basic skills. It was easy and logical. I learned more every day. Now, I write two articles a month for a magazine. I feel happy because I can work and be with my family.
The computer helped me be organized. I used to lose important papers. Now, I use spreadsheets to track money and invoices. The Internet helps me research stories and talk to other journalists. But working from home can be lonely. There are distractions, like house chores, and the kids want to use the computer too.
Many people now buy computers for education and fun. In my neighborhood, people work from home to avoid traveling to the city. A report says the average computer user is 38 years old and well-educated. Most have a personal computer, and many have a CD-ROM and modem. I am ahead of this trend. Maybe one day, I will send my work to a newspaper in Melbourne or start my own magazine from home. The possibilities are endless.'

**The Tartan Museum**
The new Museum of Scotland in Edinburgh looks very different from the old buildings around it. It has big, yellow stone towers and buildings shaped like cheese wedges. Some people like the modern design, while others do not. Inside, the museum is almost ready to open, and the displays are interesting.
The museum tells many stories about Scotland's history. It has important things like Mary Queen of Scots' jewels. The museum is not just for experts; it is for everyone, even if they do not know much about history. Dr. David Clarke, who is in charge of the exhibitions, wants visitors to have a good experience. He believes in showing the truth about history, not just imagined scenes.
The museum uses explanation panels and some computers to tell the stories of the objects. When you walk inside, you see many different rooms with pale walls and big display cases. There is a lot of light coming in, and you can take your time to look at everything.
There is also a Discovery Centre for children, thanks to a group of kids from all over Scotland. They wanted to ride through the displays, but instead, they got a special hands-on area for kids.
On the top floor, there is a gallery about the twentieth century. It has things chosen by Scottish people that were important in the last century, like an electric guitar and televisions. This part will change every three years.
Dr. Clarke believes that objects help us understand the past. The modern building looks good from the inside, but some people are not sure if it fits with the old city around it.

'The end of print may take some time Peter Preston Transition. Transition means change. Change can be scary for some people. But transition is moving from now to the future. Newspapers are trying to move to the online world. This is not easy. Many people think it will happen because print newspaper sales are going down, and visits to newspaper websites are going up. For example, The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have fewer print sales, but more people visit their websites. However, this is not true everywhere. In some places, print sales are still strong. The World Association of Newspapers says global newspaper sales went up by 1.1% last year. Sales in the West went down, but in Asia, they went up. News magazines also did well, with a 5.4% increase. Books are similar. E-readers like Kindle are popular, but physical book sales only went down by 0.4%. People still read newspapers. Nearly 5,000,000 young people in the UK read national newspapers. In Europe, the situation is different in each country. In Britain, print sales dropped by 10.8%, but in Germany, the drop was only 7%. In France, it was just 3.1%. These differences show that the change to digital is not simple. In the US, online ads were supposed to help newspapers, but now they are not doing as well. Many US newspapers have paywalls, where people pay to read online. The best way to get people to pay is to offer both print and online access together. Print is still important for selling online subscriptions. Print ads make more money than online ads. This is not easy for newspaper companies because running both print and online is hard and expensive. But print still helps newspapers be noticed.'

**Photographing People**
Taking pictures of people is very interesting. Photos with people in them are usually more exciting than those without. But, taking good pictures of people can be hard. You need to think about how people move and their facial expressions. Sometimes, people act differently when they see a camera.
**A. Grouping People**
When taking pictures of a group, don't make them stand in straight lines. Ask them to stand at different angles or levels. Some can sit or kneel in front so you can see all faces. You can also take the picture from a higher place.
**B. Posing for Pictures**
People often feel stiff in front of a camera. Help them relax by finding a comfortable position. They can fold their hands or put them in their pockets.
**C. The Right Approach**
Don't pretend you are not taking a picture. This can make people feel tense. Most people will agree to have their picture taken. They might feel shy at first, but they usually like it. You might need to guide them a bit. Make sure they are not looking away from the camera.
**D. Eye Contact**
A picture is more powerful if the person looks at the camera. Ask them to look into the lens. They don't have to smile. Remind them to look just before you take the picture. You can also say something funny to get a real reaction.
**E. Candid Concentration**
Instead of looking at the camera, the person can focus on something else in the picture. This can make the picture feel more natural. It looks like you are watching them without them knowing.
**F. Expressions and Gestures**
Expressions and gestures tell us a lot about a person. A laughing child makes us smile, while a sad face makes us feel sad too. Look for common expressions like winks, tears, or thumbs-up. They are easy to understand.
**G. Situation Interest**
A person's background can make a picture more interesting. Make sure the background is not too busy. Focus on the person. Use a wide-angle lens to make the person look bigger compared to the background.
**H. Interaction**
When people are talking, joking, or working together, you can take great pictures. Look for eye contact or physical contact, like a handshake. Capture how one person reacts to another.
**I. People and Places**
Many pictures are taken on holidays to show where people have been. Use a wide-angle lens to include the background. Ask people to stand close to the camera. This way, you can see both the people and the place clearly.
**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**
Decide why you want to take the picture. If you want to remember someone, ask them to pose with a nice background. Family pictures can be more fun if they are not posed. Candid pictures of real moments are more lively and memorable.

Title: 'Under Sarah's Spell'
Sarah Janson is an artist who makes trompe-l'oeil paintings. These paintings trick the eye and look very real. Sarah does not usually sign her work unless someone asks her to. She believes the art is more important than the artist. Sarah is very humble and sometimes acts like her paintings make themselves. She does not like to talk about herself and feels shy about being photographed.
Sarah has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. She studied drawing for two years at art school, got a degree in graphic illustration, and worked at a publishing house. But she did not enjoy illustration much. She then worked with a decorator named Jim Smart, who asked her to make a trompe-l'oeil painting. She loved it and decided to start her own business.
Sarah is very good at observing details, which is important for trompe-l'oeil art. She says you cannot learn trompe-l'oeil from a school; you learn it from life by observing. She believes she is still learning and says, "The moment you think you've mastered something, you should stop."
Sarah is honest about her weaknesses. She says she cannot paint bread well because it looks like grey concrete. She also finds math difficult. When she had to paint a big ceiling at Lulworth Castle, she got confused with the measurements. She often questions herself and sometimes talks about her work as if someone else did it.
Sarah's work is very special and better than many others who try to do trompe-l'oeil. She has done many big projects for companies and private clients. Her art is often inspired by buildings. For example, she painted a dining room to look like a Venetian palace and a corridor that looks like it leads to more rooms.
Trompe-l'oeil art must do two things: it must trick you and then keep your interest. Sarah believes the art should also be personal to the client. She enjoys working with clients and getting ideas from them. Many clients become her friends because she spends a lot of time with them while working.
Sarah appreciates her clients and is thankful for those who let her paint on their walls. She is always busy because her clients are happy with her work, even though she does not like to talk about her talent. She says, "I don't like to shout about myself. Like my work, I am very quiet. You get bored with things that shout." But you could never get bored with Sarah or her art. Her work deserves to be more famous.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**
**A** The way we work is changing. We are not only judged by how smart we are or our skills, but also by how we handle ourselves and others. This is important for getting jobs and promotions. These new rules help decide who will do well at work. They focus on social skills and personal qualities like initiative, empathy, adaptability, and persuasiveness. These are called emotional intelligence. Doing well in exams is not enough anymore. We need to have good people skills.
**B** Today, job security is not guaranteed, so personal qualities are important at work. Emotional intelligence is about understanding and managing our own and others' feelings. It includes self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy, and social skills. It is not just about being nice. Sometimes, it means telling the truth even if it is hard. Emotional intelligence helps people work well together.
**C** Many businesses see emotional intelligence as important for success. It is especially important in jobs that are not simple. People with good emotional intelligence can work better with others. As work becomes more complex, teamwork and customer focus are important. Emotional intelligence is needed for success in every job around the world.
**D** Unlike IQ, emotional intelligence can grow as we learn from life. We can get better at handling emotions, motivating ourselves, and understanding others. This growth is called maturity. We can learn emotional intelligence skills to help us in life. It is important because jobs are not always stable. Emotional intelligence is not a magic solution, but it helps make everything work better.

'Should the media make money from content they don't own? Digital cameras and phones make it easy to take pictures of important events. Social media has changed how people share these pictures. Now, news often starts on social media, and some journalists use these pictures for their stories. Sometimes, they use these pictures without asking for permission. There are rules that say it's okay to use these pictures without asking if it's very important for the public. But people still talk about whether this is right or wrong. Research shows that about one in ten people would take pictures or videos of a news event. This means that pictures from regular people are important for the media. To keep a good relationship with the public, the media should make sure people get credit and ask for permission before using their pictures.'

**Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West**
**Acupuncture: An Old Practice**
Acupuncture is a very old practice, about two thousand years old. It comes from China and is part of traditional Chinese medicine. This includes using herbs, massage, diet, and exercise. Acupuncture is used to help with many health problems, but it is most known in the West for helping with pain. Some doctors, midwives, and physiotherapists use it to help people feel less pain.
**How Does It Work?**
In traditional Chinese medicine, being healthy means your mind, body, and spirit are in balance. They believe energy, called Qi (pronounced "chee"), moves through the body along lines called meridians. There are twelve main meridians, each connected to an organ. If the Qi is blocked or weak, you might feel weak or get sick. An acupuncturist will check your wrist pulse, look at your tongue, and ask about your health, mood, and habits to find where the Qi is not balanced. They use thin needles on the skin to help Qi flow better. Sometimes, they also use heat or pressure.
**Acupuncture Points**
There are over three hundred points on the meridians where needles can be placed. These points might not be near where you feel pain. People often feel a dull ache or tingling when the needle is used. This feeling shows the needle has reached the Qi. 
**Scientific View**
Even if they don't believe in traditional Chinese ideas, some doctors think acupuncture can help with pain. They have scientific reasons for this. For example, acupuncture might block pain signals from reaching the brain or release natural painkillers in the body.
**Types of Pain Treated**
Many people with long-term pain try acupuncture. It is used for back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, and pain after surgery. Acupuncturists also say it can help with menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain in very sick people.
**Modern Use**
Acupuncture has been used in China for over 2,000 years. In the 1950s, it started being used instead of anesthesia during surgery. This helped some doctors outside China see that acupuncture could be more than just a mind trick. In China, it is used in many surgeries, like tonsil removal and heart surgery. Needles can be used alone or with electricity or medicine. It is said to reduce pain, but it depends on the person. Acupuncture does not have the side effects of regular anesthesia, like feeling sick, and people recover faster.
**Effectiveness**
It is hard to test acupuncture in clinical trials, but some trials show that 50 to 80 percent of people find it helps with long-term pain. Acupuncturists agree with these numbers. They know it does not work for everyone. For long-term pain, it usually takes six or seven visits to feel better, but some improvement should be felt after two or three visits.
**Different Views on Pain**
Western and Chinese medicine see pain differently. Acupuncturists look at the whole person, not just the symptoms. They spend time finding out what might be causing the pain, like if it is worse in cold or damp weather. This helps them decide how to use acupuncture. Regular doctors might not consider these things.
**Choosing an Acupuncturist**
Some medical professionals have traditional acupuncture training. Others, like many general practitioners, use scientific explanations instead of traditional Chinese ideas. Traditional acupuncturists believe their way can lead to longer-lasting cures. It is important to choose a good acupuncturist, and they should send you to a doctor if needed.

P.D. James is a famous crime writer. Her full name is Phyllis Dorothy James. She looks like a calm and strong person. Some people think she could have been a headmistress at a girls' school. But she is actually a bit shy. She says that her detective character, Adam Dalgliesh, is like her. He likes to solve crimes alone, just like she likes to write alone. She needs privacy to write. P.D. James is very popular, but she is modest and does not call herself the best crime writer in Britain. She likes reading books by her friend Ruth Rendell, who also writes as Barbara Vine. She enjoys books by women writers like Iris Murdoch and Anita Brookner, but also reads male authors like Graham Greene.
P.D. James became successful later in life. She was 42 when her first book, "Cover Her Face," was published. She was born in Oxford and grew up in Cambridge. She met her husband, Connor Bantry White, in Cambridge. He was a student there. Her life was not easy. Her husband came back from World War II very sick. She had to work hard to support him and their two daughters, Clare and Jane. Her husband's parents helped take care of the children.
P.D. James worked for the National Health Service and later for the Home Office. She worked in the Police Department and the Criminal Law section. She saw many things related to crime, but she was more interested in writing stories. She liked the challenge of writing detective stories. She wanted to be a serious writer and thought detective stories were a good start. Writing these stories helped her bring order to chaos. She believes solving a crime shows the importance of life. She says nobody really likes violence.

'Handwriting Can Show Your Personality In some countries, when you apply for a job, you might need to give a sample of your handwriting. Your handwriting can help decide if you are right for the job. Handwriting analysis, called graphology, is seen as a real science in many places. Experts say it can help find some illnesses like heart disease and cancer. It can also show how a person feels and thinks. Many big companies use graphologists to look at the handwriting of people who want important jobs. But many doctors and psychiatrists do not believe in graphology. Patricia Marne, a graphologist for over 20 years, thinks they should take it seriously. She says handwriting can show if a person is smart, what job they might be good at, and if they are honest or tricky. Ms. Marne believes graphology can help find people who might commit crimes. She says criminals often have messy handwriting. She can tell if someone is honest, a good worker, or if they might be violent. Handwriting can also show if someone is very stressed or might have health problems. If a person's handwriting changes a lot, it might mean something serious is happening. Ms. Marne says it takes six years to learn how to analyze handwriting well. She thinks more research is needed to make graphology a real science. Some people do not agree with her. They say handwriting is just about how you learned to write and does not show anything else.'

'Is your office working well? Fresh air and good chairs are important for a happy and healthy workplace, says a new survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they are. Our expert team included a building health consultant, an ergonomist (who studies people's working conditions), and an occupational psychologist. Here are their opinions.
Office A: Advertising Agency
Building Health Consultant: This office is very simple. There is no central heating or mechanical ventilation, and the windows open to the street. The team of seven people seems happy and adapts to the seasons by opening doors and using electric heaters, like at home. They have created a friendly work environment without much outside control.
Ergonomist: The furniture is mixed and old, with many broken chairs that are not adjustable. However, the team has different tasks, like meeting clients and making presentations, which helps prevent tiredness and boredom.
Occupational Psychologist: The staff enjoys the variety of work and the flexible office space. They like the office size, which is small enough to know what others are doing but big enough for personal work. The office feels efficient and creative.
Office B: News Service
Building Health Consultant: The office is comfortable and the air quality is good, helped by a No Smoking policy.
Ergonomist: The chairs, lighting, and computer equipment are good, but the office is plain with grey walls. The layout could be better.
Occupational Psychologist: The walls are bare except for a few posters. Most staff have been there for over five years, and relationships are okay. The office could improve by making it easier to share information.
Office C: Bank
Building Health Consultant: The office feels like a glass case. Even with smokers, the air is not stale.
Ergonomist: The office is standard and not inspiring. Desks are just okay, and some chairs are not suitable for computer work. Computer screens are on small desks, which is not ideal.
Occupational Psychologist: Staff support each other and use technology well. The office is busy, but the wood panels and brown carpet make it look a bit dull.
Office D: Newspaper
Building Health Consultant: The air conditioning is poor, causing temperature changes. The office is cluttered and dusty.
Ergonomist: The furniture is old and not suitable for computer work. Many chairs are not adjustable and have armrests that make it hard to sit close to the desk.
Occupational Psychologist: The office is dirty with old chairs and carpets. It needs cleaning and better air conditioning. Few people were talking, and everyone seemed stressed. The company should encourage teamwork.'

Chewing gum is very popular, and Americans chew 12 million pieces every day. It has less than ten calories per piece and is considered a food, so it must meet the rules of the American Food and Drug Administration. Today, most gum is made from synthetic materials with added pine resins and softeners to keep the flavor and make it feel nice to chew.
A long time ago, the ancient Greeks chewed a resin from the mastic tree, found in Greece and Turkey. Greek women liked it to clean their teeth and freshen their breath. In America, early settlers learned from Native Americans to chew resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, people in the eastern United States could buy spruce gum, making it the first commercial chewing gum there.
Modern chewing gum started in the late 1860s with chicle, a milky substance from the sapodilla tree in Central America. This gum was smoother and more elastic, leading to a big industry. However, growing sapodilla trees for chicle has not worked well, so synthetic alternatives are now used.
Today, a few people called chicleros still collect chicle, but it is hard and dangerous work. They walk long distances in hot, humid forests with poisonous snakes and insects. They climb trees to collect the sap, which they carry to a camp to boil and make into bricks. Life at the camp is tough, with simple food and local alcohol.
The chicleros worry about their jobs because the U.S. used to buy a lot of chicle, but now it buys much less. As gum sales have increased, companies use synthetic materials to save money and meet demand.
Gum is marketed in many ways. It is said to help you relax, give you energy, and reduce stress. During both world wars, soldiers were given gum. Gum is also claimed to reduce tooth decay by increasing saliva, which helps protect teeth. New textures and flavors are being developed, with most flavors being artificial. However, some natural flavors are still used. In America, a large area is used to grow mint for the two most popular chewing gums.

**Remote Hotels**
**A. India - Ghaneraoa Hotel, Rajasthan**  
Ghaneraoa Hotel is in a small village in the hills of Rajasthan. It is a quiet place with a mix of English and Indian styles. The Ghaneraoa family has lived here for 400 years. Now, they welcome guests. The hotel is simple, with hot water in buckets, but this makes it special.
**B. New Zealand - Hermitage Hotel, Mount Cook**  
The Hermitage Hotel is on New Zealand's South Island. It is in a beautiful, wild area. After climbing a mountain, you can rest here in luxury. It is a surprise to find such a nice hotel in the middle of nature.
**C. Mauritius - Beach Comber Paradis Hotel**  
The Paradis Hotel is on a quiet part of Mauritius. It is on its own piece of land by the sea. You can enjoy water sports or find peace on the long private beach. In the evening, the beach is calm and feels far from everything.
**D. St. Lucia - Ladera Hotel**  
The Ladera Hotel is high up in St. Lucia. It has a great view of the sea and mountains. The rooms are open and have nice wooden furniture. It is a quiet place to enjoy the morning view.
**E. Turkey - The Splendid Hotel, Istanbul**  
This hotel is on an island near Istanbul. It is a nice place to escape the city's noise. You can reach it by boat. There are no cars, only horse carriages. The hotel is old but charming, with white and red colors.
**F. France - Chateau d'Etoges, Eperney**  
In the village of Etoges, there is a beautiful old castle. It has a water moat and swans. The castle has 20 different rooms. Some have special beds. You can enjoy a weekend with breakfast, dinner, and champagne.
**G. Kenya - The Fairview Hotel, Nairobi**  
The Fairview Hotel is a comfortable place in Nairobi. It is a good stop for travelers. The hotel has nice gardens and rooms. Many guests decide to stay longer. It is a quiet place to enjoy the sunset and a good dinner.
**H. Italy - Hotel Splendido, Portofino**  
The Hotel Splendido was once a monastery. Now, it is a famous hotel. Many famous people have stayed here. It is a nice place for a weekend. The hotel has good food and beautiful rugs.

'Sue Brown is a hotel inspector. She checks hotels to see if they are good. Christopher Middleton watched her work. When Sue visits the Globe Hotel, things start badly. The receptionist is talking on the phone and does not notice Sue. Sue says, 'Very poor.' This is a common mistake she sees in hotels. The Globe Hotel has three red stars, which means it is one of the best hotels. But Sue is not happy. The entrance from the car park is not nice. There is a long, empty corridor. Sue says, 'Not what I expected.' Things get worse. The receptionist cannot find Sue's booking. Most rooms are empty, but the room Sue gets is not nice. It is stuffy, and there is a big hole in the wall. Sue is known for being tough. People called her 'The Woman in Black,' but she says she is not too tough. The next morning, Sue tells the hotel manager, Robin Greaves, who she is. He is surprised and sorry for the bad smell in the lounge. Sue suggests fixing the smell and not taking guests there. Greaves agrees and takes notes. He has been at the hotel for five months. Sue says her feedback will help the hotel. Not everything is bad. Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, the waitress, are doing a good job. Dinner is good, too. Greaves asks how to get a better food rating. Sue says, 'Don't serve a pudding that collapses.' Sue's job is to say what is wrong in hotels. Sometimes people get upset. Once, a woman said Sue got her son fired because he served apple pie with his fingers. Sue writes a report for the hotel. They pay for her advice. The Globe Hotel will keep its red stars, but another inspector will come in two months to check again. Greaves says, 'Good,' but he does not look happy.'

Title: Climbing the Seven Summits
Introduction: Doug Scott, a famous mountaineer, talks about his journey to climb the highest mountain on each continent, known as the Seven Summits.
A. Mount Everest, Asia (8,848 meters)
- Doug and his partner, Dougal, stayed in a snow cave near the top.
- They talked about sleeping bags, even though only they were there.
- Doug was worried about frostbite in his feet.
- They reached the top by finding a good rhythm.
B. Mount McKinley, North America (6,194 meters)
- Known as a very dangerous mountain.
- Doug and Dougal carried their own equipment.
- They climbed a new path and faced strong winds.
- The low air pressure made it feel like they were higher than they were.
C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895 meters)
- Doug and his friend got lost in the jungle.
- They found a path with arrows and rubbish that led them to water.
- They chose a safer route to reach the top.
D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960 meters)
- Doug and his wife, Sharu, joined a group to climb a less crowded path.
- They avoided a dangerous glacier due to time limits.
- They reached the top before nightfall.
E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897 meters)
- Doug realized he could climb this mountain by guiding others.
- They faced strong winds and cold temperatures.
- They reached the top in 8 hours.
F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633 meters)
- The team started from a high point using a cable car.
- They faced strong winds and icy paths.
- They thought they reached the top but had to walk further.
G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883 meters)
- Doug wanted to make a new path and meet local people.
- They were warned about dangers but continued.
- They reached the top and celebrated their success.
Conclusion: Doug Scott successfully climbed all Seven Summits, achieving his goal.

**Style Merchants**
Style is important in our lives. It affects our clothes, home decoration, and accessories. Jo Foley talks about fashion trends for this year.
**Ned Ingham: Dress Designer**
Ned Ingham makes beautiful wedding dresses. He says people should choose simple styles instead of traditional, fancy dresses. Ned started drawing wedding dresses when he was a schoolboy. At 16, he went to fashion school to learn how to make clothes. He also designs long evening dresses with new colors and fabrics. For those who like classic styles, he has a navy-blue suit that looks modern.
**Sally Quail: Jeweller**
Sally Quail used to work for an art dealer but did not study jewelry formally. She started designing jewelry when she couldn't find an engagement ring she liked. In 1990, she became a jewelry designer. Many famous people like her work. She uses large stones in gold for necklaces, bracelets, and rings. Recently, she started using diamonds because she feels ready for them at 36 years old.
**Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer**
Lily Grimson started her fashion business four years ago. She only took a basic art and design course. Two of her handbags were chosen for a big design show. Her bags are handmade in the UK and are very stylish. They are made from fine materials like calfskin and silk.
**Peter Little: Hairdresser**
Peter Little has been a hairdresser for over 20 years. Many famous people have had their hair styled by him. He believes women want hair that looks natural and is easy to manage. His haircuts cost £250, and there is a long waiting list. Peter also sells his own hairdryers and styling tools so people can style their hair at home.
**Penny Pratt: Florist**
Penny Pratt runs a small flower shop and works with supermarkets and restaurants. She used to be a teacher but changed careers 10 years ago. Her simple and modern flower designs have won many prizes. She also started a flower school in London. Penny gives lectures in Japan and the USA. She says flower arrangements should be simple and strong, with not too many leaves. For wedding bouquets, use flowers of the same kind.

'Luxury and Modern Technology at the Merrion Hotel The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It took almost two years to change four old houses into this hotel. The hotel has the latest technology for both staff and guests. The General Manager, Peter MacCann, wants his staff to know guests by name. For other details, he uses a computer system. This system helps give special service to guests who come back. It cost a lot of money, but MacCann says it will save money in the long run. The system remembers what guests like. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs, they will have them ready next time. Guests often complain about room temperature. The hotel has a system to control this. Guests can change the temperature a little, or the front desk can change it more. Business guests will like the technology in the rooms. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine, and video-conferencing. The hotel is ready for future technology changes. They rent TVs so they can get new ones easily. DVD players can also be updated. Even with all this technology, the rooms are comfortable and welcoming. The hotel has 145 large rooms, a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a nice garden. The food must be excellent. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the hotel. This is good for both him and the hotel. He has a new kitchen and better parking. The hotel offers a popular place to eat without financial risk. With technology and good staff, the Merrion Hotel is likely to do well.'

'Susan Shepherd is an artist who paints flowers. She is famous for her flower paintings. Susan has a big garden around her house. She gets many ideas for her paintings from this garden. Her garden has many flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow everywhere in the garden. The garden looks nice because of the colors and shapes of the flowers. The people who lived there before Susan loved gardening and left many plants for her. Susan also got a gardener named Danny from them. She says, 'It was really his garden.' At first, Danny did not like some of Susan's ideas, but when she explained she wanted to paint them, he understood. Susan likes to paint one flower at a time. She sometimes paints a group of flowers, but usually, she picks one flower and takes it to her studio. She paints it for a few days, then adds another flower to the painting. Sometimes, it takes her a couple of years to finish a painting. Spring and early summer are her busiest times because the tulips and poppies bloom then. Susan finds it interesting how flowers change over time. For example, tulips change shape when you put them in water. Susan has always liked plants. She studied botany in school and collected wild flowers. She did not like garden flowers before because they looked fake to her. She liked wild flowers because they grew in difficult places. Now, her garden has plants from other countries, but they grow well in her garden. Susan is busy with two art shows, so she does not have much time for gardening. She has another gardener to help her, but she still likes to work in the garden to stay connected to her flowers.'

Many trees in the Brackham area fell down during the big storms in March. The town lost two big lime trees from the old market square. This changed how the town looked, and some people were not happy about it. One of these people was Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, the head of the local police. But during the storm, Pelham was very sick with bronchitis, so he did not notice the changes. 
Pelham was usually healthy, but he got very sick for the first time. He had a headache and chest pain. His wife, Molly, wanted him to see a doctor, but Pelham thought he was too important at work to take a break. He kept working, but this made him forgetful and angry. Finally, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor. Pelham was too weak to argue. The doctor gave him medicine, and Molly took him home to rest.
On Thursday morning, Molly told Pelham that the walnut tree in their garden had fallen. Pelham was too sick to understand. By Saturday, after taking his medicine, he felt better and got out of bed. He was surprised to see that the living room looked different without the tree. 
The Pelhams' house was big and had a nice garden. Pelham liked the privacy the garden gave them. Before, the walnut tree made nice patterns of light and shade in the living room. It also hid the old furniture. Now, without the tree, the room was very bright, and the old furniture looked shabby. The view from the window was not nice anymore. The house next door, which was hidden by the tree, was now visible. It had ugly purple bricks and many windows that seemed to watch the Pelhams.
Pelham said to Molly, "Doesn't it look terrible?" But Molly was happy. She said, "I've been telling you we need a new sofa, no matter the cost."

Living in the Valley
We had been living in our valley for sixteen months when we first understood the dangers in the hills around us. It was the year when the storms came early, even before November ended. Before that, we felt safe in our valley below the hills. Soon, snow began to fall. In one day, it was about 15 centimeters deep. It almost blocked our road and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. But on the hills, the snow was much deeper and stayed longer. Up there, the wind was very strong. In our valley, we only felt sudden strong winds; trees moved, but the branches stayed strong. Still, we knew we had a reason to worry. The snow and wind were a problem, but they did not worry us too much. It was the river, the Ryburn, which was usually calm, that worried us the most. It reminded us of what could happen if the water from the hills was not controlled by dams built many years ago.
Soon, the snow started to melt. Every day, we saw dark clouds over the hills to the west. They moved and changed, warning us of what was coming. We watched the river, which was getting fuller and wilder every day. The snow was washed away as more rain came from the clouds, but high in the hills, the reservoir was filling up and getting dangerous. Then it happened - for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. It was like a big waterfall as the water went over the dam and into the stream below. The river was wild as the water rushed down. Near our cottage, the stream was deeper than we had ever seen it, hitting its banks hard. For three days, we hoped it would stay below its wall. Luckily, our hopes came true as the dam held and the water started to go down.
In the past, before the dam was built, the river often flooded the nearby villages. Now, the dam controls the river, and usually, everything is fine. The water from the hills, from snow and heavy rain, stays behind the dam with only a little overflow sometimes. Because of this protection, we can enjoy the big clouds over the valley and feel excited by the river's power. Thanks to this, we feel our home in the valley is safe.

'Film Critic Mark Adams talks about his last ten years working as a film critic for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing about films for The Front Page was my first real job. Before that, I wrote reviews for novels, films, and radio. That's how I met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page. He hired me. Tom wanted a team of critics to write about books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. We would have a weekly lunch to choose what to cover, and there would be guests to make it fun. It felt like a dream: a new newspaper, and I was part of it. I couldn't believe a new paper could start in a busy market. I even thought a millionaire was pretending to hire me. I had little confidence. The first time I saw someone reading my review on the London Underground, I felt shy. Tom's idea for a team of critics didn't work out. We didn't meet as planned, so we talked by phone. People liked reviewers to focus on one subject, so I chose film. Thanks to Tom, I now write a long piece each week, usually about one film. This way of working is perfect for me. I wouldn't like the usual film critic's job, which means reviewing every film. That would make me bored quickly. I would soon be thinking, 'What boring film must I watch now?' But what is my job for the public? I think people choose films because of the stars, the ads, or the director. People are loyal to certain types of films. It's rare for someone who hates westerns to watch one after reading a review. So, if a film review isn't a guide, what is it? I don't feel I have to be 'right' about a movie. I just need to share my opinion. I'm not a judge, and I don't want to be one.'

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km? Because "it's fun." Teenager Melanie Sears loves endurance sports. She is looking for a training partner who loves sports too, preferably a girl. This person should like running long distances (15km), swimming in cold rivers, and cycling long distances (100km). They must be able to do all three without stopping. 
The triathlon is becoming a popular Olympic sport. Many people watch athletes swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and run 10km without stopping. It is exciting to watch, but why do athletes do it? Melanie, a 17-year-old with good school grades, loves the challenge. She says, "You swim 1500m, then get on your bike while still wet. You feel cold. After cycling 40km, you run 10km, which is hard when you are tired. But it's fun and worth it."
Melanie did her first triathlon at 14 and won the junior section because she was the only junior. She felt confident and entered the National Championships. She was fast in swimming and running but got lost while cycling and went 20km too far. She cried during the run but did not give up. She is determined to keep going. 
Steve Trew, the sport's coaching director, admires her determination. He says she worked so hard on a running machine that it threw her off. Melanie was the top junior in this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. She is working hard to improve her cycling. Her parents are paying for her trip to New Zealand for the World Championships, and she wants a new bike to help her compete in more races.
Melanie's training is tough, and she doesn't have much of a social life. She says, "I'm not a party person. After swimming on Friday nights, I just want to sleep. But I talk to other girls in the team about their race times." Melanie has tried other events, like the triathlon "sprint," which is shorter. She wants to try even harder events. She wishes she had someone her age to train with.

'The Collectors Amanda Roy talks about the things she collects and why many people like this hobby. I have always loved collecting, and one in three adults enjoys this hobby. It is a world of passion and happiness. But remember, if you do not love an object, do not collect it. Since ancient times, people have wanted to collect things. Early humans collected pebbles and wore them as necklaces. They liked the shapes and colors. Today, children still collect stones and seashells for their beauty. I have been collecting all my life. I collect many things, like flowers, pottery, and paintings. My first collection was stones from my parents' garden. When I was six, I went to a school in a remote part of England. It was cold and windy, with many hills. My parents took me to a local museum full of old objects. I loved these objects. Many adults also love collecting. People collect for different reasons. Some like to have control over something. For me, it's just fun. A famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France. He had a 'room of wonders' with many interesting things. Catherine the Great of Russia collected over 4,000 paintings. You do not need to be rich to start a collection. I have collected tulip bulbs and china cups. I remember getting a special tulip from another collector. I planted it, but one day it was stolen. I also collected 350 American rag dolls. I searched all over the USA for them. But my collection was destroyed in a house fire. The next day, I saw the remains of my furniture and collection. I was very sad. I am interested in how collections change hands. A silver spoon that belonged to a king or poet is valuable. As small objects become popular, their price goes up. Toys from the 1950s are now an investment if you kept the original boxes. (I threw mine away.)'

**My Job**
Four people talk about their jobs.
**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**
I organize temporary exhibitions at the Science Museum. I plan and design the exhibition and tell people about it. I read about the exhibition topic and talk to experts. I decide what objects and pictures to show. I make sure visitors understand the exhibition by planning interactive displays, workshops, and theatre. I also work with engineers and electricians to keep the exhibition safe. Before it opens, I help create brochures and leaflets to inform people.
**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**
I start work at 7.30 a.m. by checking the accounts. I prepare new maps and documents for students to learn taxi routes for the London taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are learning the routes. They find the best way using one-way streets and turns. I help when there is a disagreement, like if a right turn is possible at a junction. Before the test, I give them a route and then change it to make them think of another way.
**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**
I live by the sea and work from home. I answer phone calls, create educational materials, and set up training courses. Sometimes, I go to the main office, but mostly I am by the coast. I work with schools and run courses for people who make decisions about the sea. I take them on boat trips to show them sea life. This often changes their views. I love my job because conservation is my hobby. But, I work for a charity, so we always need more money.
**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**
My job is varied. I make sure our publishing matches what people want and keep stocks of about 300 books. We have high standards for information. We get letters from readers about things like international boundaries, and I answer them carefully. I talk about future projects and sales with co-publishers. I work with a great team, which makes the job fun. The downside is there is too much paperwork, leaving less time for interesting tasks like product development and design.

'Our Holiday in Ireland We always went to Ireland in June. Since we started going on holidays together, we spent the first two weeks of June at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It's a big house by the sea, near the village of Ardbeag. An English couple, the Malseeds, bought the house and made it bigger, but they did it very nicely. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds still needed to advertise. 'How about this?' he said one evening and read the details. The summer before, we went to a hotel our friends recommended, but it wasn't good because the food was terrible. The four of us, Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and I, have played cards together for a long time. They call me Milly, but my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school. He and Strafe went to school together, so we call Strafe by his last name, like the teachers did. We are all about the same age and live near the town where the Malseeds lived before moving from England to Ireland. We think it's a funny coincidence. 'How very nice,' Mrs. Malseed said, smiling when we arrived this year. She always seems to know when guests are coming because she's usually waiting in the big hall that smells like flowers. 'Arthur, take the luggage up,' she told the old porter. 'Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium.' These are the names of the rooms for us. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of using numbers. In winter, when not many people come to Glencorn Lodge, she does things like that; her husband does repairs. 'Well, well, well,' Mr. Malseed said, coming in from the kitchen. 'A hundred thousand welcomes,' he greeted us in the Irish way. He smiled with his dark brown eyes twinkling, making us feel special. Everyone smiled, and I felt like our holiday had really started. Nothing changed at Glencorn, everything was good. Kitty from the dining room came to greet us. 'You look younger every year, all four of you,' she said, making everyone laugh. Arthur took our luggage to the rooms, carrying as much as he could and coming back for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while but not too long because we were tired from the trip. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other people at dinner because in June Glencorn Lodge is always full. From where we sat by the window, we could see some people walking on the lawns, others going down the cliff path to the seashore. In the morning, we would do the same: walk along the sands to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, back in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. I knew this because we always did the same things. Since we first came here, we all loved the beautiful landscape.'

Title: Keeping Holiday Guests Happy
Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a 24-year-old from West Sussex. She works as a chalet girl in Val d'Isere, France. This is her second year doing this job. She cooks and cleans for people who come to ski and stay in chalets, which are wooden houses. Sarah studied French and History of Art at Oxford Brookes University. She says being a chalet girl is not a career, but it's fun for a year or two before starting a serious job. She meets many successful people every week.
Sarah does not live at the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks to the chalet, which can have up to 18 guests each week. She eats her breakfast first, then makes breakfast for the guests. They have porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, Sarah cleans up and either makes afternoon tea or cleans the rooms. She says cleaning the rooms is the hardest part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to go skiing. She skis as much as she can until about 4.30 p.m.
Sarah goes back to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower but does not sleep because it makes her too tired. Dinner is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans up and fills the dishwasher. Sometimes she talks with the guests, and other times they want to be alone. Good guests make the week fun, but some weeks are not as good.
Sarah meets her friends at the chalet where she lives and they go out around 11 p.m. They visit places like Bananas, G Jay's, and Dick's T-Bar. But she does not stay out late on Saturday because Sunday is her busiest day. She starts work early on Sunday because breakfast for leaving guests must be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, she cleans everything quickly. If she did not shop on Saturday, she does it now. At 3 p.m., she prepares tea for new guests who arrive around 4.30 p.m. She helps them with questions and takes them to get ski equipment if needed. Then she prepares dinner again. Sometimes she has a drink after dinner, but if she is too tired, she goes to bed early.

Miss Rita Cohen was a small, pale girl who looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie. But she said she was six years older. One day, she came to Seymour's factory. She wore overalls and big shoes, and her curly hair surrounded her pretty face. She was so small and young that Seymour found it hard to believe she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania. She was doing research on the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree.
A few times a year, someone would call or write to Seymour to ask if they could see his factory. Sometimes, he would help a student by answering questions on the phone or giving a short tour if they seemed serious. Rita Cohen was almost as small as the children from Marie's third-year class. Years ago, these children came from their school 50 kilometers away to see how Marie's dad made gloves. They especially liked the laying-off table, where workers shaped and pressed each glove over hot brass hands. Marie called them 'pancake hands' because they looked flat.
Rita asked Seymour, 'How many pieces come in a shipment?' He replied, 'Between twenty and twenty-five thousand.' She took notes and asked more questions. Seymour liked that she was interested in every detail. He explained that the tannery, a place where leather is made, was a contractor. They bought the material and made it ready for work. Seymour's grandfather and father worked in the tannery, and so did he for six months. He asked Rita if she had ever been inside a tannery. She said, 'Not yet.' Seymour offered to arrange a visit for her, saying tanneries are old places with little change over the years.
Seymour told Rita that his father was the real leather expert and could talk about gloves for days. He asked if she had ever seen anything being made. Rita said she hadn't, except for watching her mother bake a cake as a child. Seymour laughed and found her eager to learn. Rita reminded him of his daughter Marie, who was always full of what she learned at school.
Seymour decided to show Rita the whole process of making gloves. He said, 'We're going to make you a pair of gloves, and you're going to watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?'

'Is it a dream job? Chris Arnot talks to four people with jobs that seem amazing. Are they really as great as they look? A. Raquel Graham Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She can't meet me tomorrow because her boss wants her in Los Angeles. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she travels a lot. Raquel loves her job and gets along well with her boss. But there's one small problem - she doesn't like flying. 'On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to calm down,' she says. Her worst flight was on Concorde. 'It felt so closed in with those tiny windows.' When she's not flying, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She does paperwork, organizes the diary, attends meetings, and makes travel plans. She didn't apply for the job. She met a pop group manager by chance, which led to a job offer. She also took secretarial classes at night. Five years later, she was in the right place when her boss needed a PA. B. David Brown David Brown has been an accountant and a golf caddy, which means he carries a golfer's bags. He liked being a caddy more because he loves golf. But there are downsides. He gets a small fee and a part of the winnings. He earns between £25,000 and £35,000, but spends a lot on travel and hotels. He was 31 when he first worked for golfer Greg Norman. 'You're not just carrying bags. You give advice and try to understand the golf course.' His accountancy skills were noticed by European Tour Productions, and now he works as a statistical data administrator. He collects and analyzes golf statistics, which are used by TV commentators, magazines, and golfers. C. Martin Fern Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a newspaper. One of his easier tasks is to try food at top restaurants. What does he think about expensive restaurants? 'If people can afford it, it's their choice,' he says. 'I'd rather spend £120 on a memorable meal than buy a microwave.' His cooking talent led to a food column offer from a friend who edited a Saturday Review. At the time, Martin was a creative director at an advertising agency, and the column was extra income. He was 42 when another newspaper offered him a full-time job. 'It meant earning 50% less,' he says. 'But it was a chance to turn my passion into a job.' He still cooks at home and tries to stay fit by cycling to the nearest tube station. D. Dick Prince 'I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago,' says Dick Prince, a popular children's writer in Britain. 'Before that, I loved words and wrote poems. Then I had an idea for a story. I was a farmer and knew about chickens being killed by a fox. So I wrote a story called The Fox Busters, which was my first published children's story.' Where do his ideas come from? 'It's not easy, I have to work on them,' he says. 'I usually do this in the mornings. I'm not an early riser. After lunch, I spend a couple of hours typing my morning notes with one finger on an old typewriter, not a laptop. I get 50 to 100 letters a week, and I enjoy this part of being a writer. I try to answer them all, but now I have some help.'

In the lumberyard by the lake, workers cut trees into boards for building. There was an old two-story brick building there, and around it were big piles of soft sawdust. These piles looked like golden mountains and went all the way to the blue lake. One afternoon, Michael and his friends were bored, so they climbed a ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and he jumped off the roof onto the sawdust, laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all scared," he said, trying to get them to jump too. They looked down, scared, but then one by one, they jumped and felt happy. In the hot sun, they lay on the sawdust, telling jokes. Then one friend said, "Let's go up and jump again." They weren't very excited, but they went up and jumped again until only Michael was left on the roof. The others were below, calling, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong?" Michael wanted to jump but stayed on the roof, nervous and smiling awkwardly. He tried to count to ten and jump, but he couldn't. The others started laughing and got tired of waiting. They shouted, "Come on, you're scared. Are we going to wait all night?" When he didn't move, they walked away, still shouting. Michael stayed on the roof, looking sadly at the ground. He was alone for almost an hour as the sun set. His clothes were wet from sweat. Finally, he closed his eyes, slipped off the roof, and fell onto the sawdust. He lay there for a long time. The yard was quiet because the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he couldn't jump before. Then he got up slowly and walked home, feeling ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone. He was late for dinner, and his stepmother said, "You're old enough to come home on time. If you can't, you should stay in tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin, a little grey in her hair, and a patient smile. She spoke seriously, but Michael, feeling sad, didn't really hear her. He was still thinking about his friends laughing at him.

Title: Careers Advice
Are you unhappy with your job and don't know how to change it? Kitty Doherty has some advice. Many people who want to change jobs go to a careers adviser. You will write a short history about yourself and take some tests called 'psychometrics'. After the tests, you get a report with career suggestions and possible retraining options.
I tried Career Analysts, a big company that gives career advice. The test felt like a science exam. I was with about ten people, answering questions quickly. The tests included finding mistakes in lists and matching shapes. After the test, I talked with an adviser who gave me a report with his thoughts and suggestions. I agreed with most of it, but I was surprised to learn I did poorly in scientific and technical tests. I was happy to hear I made the right choice with journalism.
Changing your career doesn't always mean a big change. Last March, Donna Laney, 25, lost her job as a marketing manager. Her friends told her to try Career Analysts. She wanted to look at her skills and interests again. She found out she was good at design but had to think about the cost of retraining. Other ideas included working in the Far East for a year. She decided to use her skills in a new job as a Public Relations officer. She is happy with the help she got and recommended it to friends.
Some people feel they couldn't have changed without help. Juliet Greene, 26, worked at a bank for six years and wanted a new challenge. She went to Career Counselling Services and took tests that showed she liked sciences. After four meetings with an adviser, she decided to study geology. She thinks the advice was worth the cost and feels happier now.
However, careers advice doesn't work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, 24, a sales representative, didn't find it helpful. She wanted new ideas but didn't like the options because they meant less money or more training. She felt a friend could have given similar advice.

'Fun at the Dentist's? If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in Glasgow, you will see bright paintings on the wall and a nice blue couch for patients. Jerome says, 'Half of the people only go to the dentist when they have pain. They are scared.' To help with this, he tries to make a place where people are not afraid. He does not wear a white coat because it makes people think of pain. He believes dental visits should be relaxing and even fun. This is surprising because many people think of dental visits as painful or very serious. Jerome says, 'If people are relaxed and happy, they will forget bad experiences.' He uses virtual-reality headsets to help people relax. 'We were the first in Britain to use them, and people like them. During the first check-up, patients sit on the blue couch and watch a film about sea animals while I check their teeth. Then, they see a video tour of their mouth.' Many patients enjoy this. The office smells nice, like oranges, not like a dentist's. Jerome says, 'I want people to know it's different from a regular dentist's. Smell is important. The usual dentist smell can make people scared.' I liked the nice smell. Jerome is known as a fashionable dentist, but he is serious about his work. Relaxation is important, but good treatment is most important. He uses a tool that sprays warm water to clean teeth, not scraping them. It feels strange at first, but it is not painful if you are relaxed. Five years ago, Jerome went to the USA to learn about dental techniques. 'I learned that if you make it easy for the patient, it is easy for you too,' he says. He thinks this is the start of a change in British dentistry. A patient arrives, and Jerome offers him tea and asks what video he wants to watch. The patient seems to enjoy this special treatment. The office feels more like a beauty salon than a regular dentist's office.'

Title: Chocolate's Journey from South America to the World
Chocolate comes from South America and is now a big business around the world. In the UK, people spend over £230 million on chocolate at Easter. This is when 8% of all chocolate is bought. Only at Christmas do people eat more chocolate.
The cacao plant, which gives us chocolate, was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan people in Central America over 3,000 years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and South-East Asia. Its fruit is the size of a melon and has 20-40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English, they are often called cocoa beans because of a spelling mistake from the 17th century.
The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and to make a drink called xocoatl, meaning 'bitter water' in their language. They added spices to the drink for special events. The Spanish liked it better with cinnamon and sugar, but it took another 100 years to become popular in Europe. In the late 1600s, chocolate houses opened in Europe's big cities where people drank chocolate.
In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands made chocolate powder by taking out most of the cocoa butter from the beans. In 1847, Fry and Sons in Bristol made the first chocolate bar by mixing cocoa butter, chocolate liquor, and sugar. Later, a Swiss company added milk to make milk chocolate.
At the start of the 1900s, French companies led the British chocolate market. In 1879, Cadbury named their factory Bournville, hoping to add some French style. But in 1905, Cadbury's Dairy Milk bar became popular because it was linked to healthy English milk.
Today, people in Britain eat about four chocolate bars each week. To keep customers interested, companies now make chocolate bars into ice creams, drinks, and desserts. Meanwhile, cacao farmers are still affected by low cocoa bean prices from the 1980s. Many small farmers had to stop their work. So, next time you eat a chocolate bar, think about the farmers who grow the cacao.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**
Peter Cooke is 83 years old and very good at making art with shells. He wants to try other things like making paper and working with feathers, but for now, he is happy making beautiful things with shells. He has been doing this for ten years.
Peter shows me his work in his apartment. He is very excited about his art, and it is easy to see why. His work is charming and beautiful. He points to some shell ornaments above his fireplace and says he likes them so much that he doesn't mind if they don't sell. He never planned to sell his work, but friends encouraged him to have an exhibition. Five years ago, he had his first exhibition in London, and 70% of his pieces sold. His second exhibition just opened.
The pieces are expensive, with some costing around £2,000. There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell-flower in a crystal vase. Peter says he doesn't set the prices, but he is happy people like his work. He believes no one else makes art like his, and the gallery owner told him that one day everyone will want his pieces because he will stop making them.
Peter wishes he started this art earlier in life because he feels he could have made even more wonderful things. He still has many ideas, but he finds it harder to work now than when he was younger. His work is very different from the shell crafts you find in seaside shops. He makes boxes with tiny shells, pictures from shells, and baskets of flowers that look real.
Peter has his own way of working. He uses cardboard from laundered shirts for his flower bases, a special glue from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. He says he has an idea of what he wants to do, and it just happens, but his work shows a lot of care and detail.
Peter looks for beautiful and tiny shells not just in Norfolk, but also in places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He only collects dead shells and does not harm living creatures. He says that people walking on the beach break more shells than he collects, and the sea also breaks them. He believes it is okay to collect shells once the creatures have left them. His work is often more beautiful than the shells alone, making his argument convincing.

'The Schoolgirl Model When 15-year-old Kira Langer is not traveling to exciting places and appearing on magazine covers, she is probably studying for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw finds out more. 'I'm afraid Kira will be a little late,' the receptionist at the agency told me. 'Oh, fine,' I said, 'no problem.' I was trying to forget all the bad things I had read about models, like being difficult, vain, and unintelligent. And now she was going to be late. How late? An hour? Three hours? Maybe she wouldn't come at all. What if she decided to go to the hairdresser instead of talking to me? If she was late, she might be in a bad mood and not want to answer my questions. But when Kira, the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition, walked in, she was smiling, relaxed, and said sorry for being late. She was with her mother. Kira was not wearing expensive designer clothes but a simple black dress and trainers. She was very friendly, very tall, and very pretty. All models under 16 must have an adult with them when they work, she explained. Her mother looked like a normal mum, very proud of her successful daughter. Kira seems a bit surprised by her new fame, which makes sense because it was not planned. Her older sister decided she should enter the model competition. 'She saw the competition and said I should try it,' Kira remembers. 'I said no, but she sent some photos anyway.' When they called to say she was a finalist, she was at school. Being chosen for the final made Kira confident, and she did very well. She won easily, and the Select model agency in London offered her work right away. Kira now finds it hard to manage her two lives. But her friends and teachers are used to having a star among them. 'They're really proud of me,' she says. However, some unkind people at her school are rude about her success. 'They say I think too much of myself.' This must be hard for Kira because she is not self-important. But she says, 'They think that because I'm a model now, I can't stay the same. But the only thing that's changed is I'm more confident - not in a bad way, but I can stand up for myself more.' As a busy model, her social life is affected. The Select agency can call anytime and tell her she has a job the next day. 'If my friends are going out, I can't say I'll come because I don't know what I'm doing the next day. I can't really make plans, and if I do, they sometimes get canceled, but my friends are good about it. They don't say, "Oh, you're always going off modeling now, you never have time for us".' Kira has the looks, ability, and support to have a great career ahead of her. Not many people can say that before they finish school. I am about to finish the interview with the girl who has it all, and I ask what she would like to do if she wasn't a model. She pauses and replies: 'I'd like to do what you're doing.'

Title: Father and Son Search for Gold
Terence and Chris Madden are a father and son team. They have traveled from cold Canada to hot Africa to find gold. Terence is an explorer, and Chris is a mineral expert. They think their mine on a Welsh mountain has a lot of gold, maybe 10,000 ounces. After ten years of digging, they believe they are close to finding gold worth five million dollars. Terence, who is 68 and from Liverpool, says they are finding more gold as they dig. They just need to dig a little more to find where the gold is concentrated.
Their search for gold started when Terence read about gold in the 'Dolgellau gold belt' in Wales. They read old mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library. They picked the best area to look for gold. They cleared the land, found some gold in rocks, and spent ten years getting permission to dig. They also took earth samples and removed old cars and rubbish. They dug out 150 tonnes of rock to make a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft. Now, they are running out of money. They need someone to give them PS50,000 to dig a little more to find the gold. Chris says it is hard to find someone to help, but they have some people they can ask.
People in the area are talking about the dig. Dolgellau is a town that needs tourists, and people hope the gold will bring more visitors. Peter Woolven, who manages the Royal Ship Hotel, says it would be good if more people come, but he hopes not too many people will dig up the hillside.
The Welsh gold industry was big in the late 1880s, with many mines and workers. But now, it is not as big. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, closed a month ago. But some people are still looking for gold. George Hall, another gold seeker, wants to dig a tunnel on the other side of the hill from the Maddens. Hall, who is 70, says searching for gold is exciting and like finding hidden treasure. He hopes to be lucky this time.

'IN HOT WATER Rachel Mills is a scientist who studies the sea. She works at Southampton University and teaches about the ocean. Rachel also goes on special trips to the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She uses a small underwater vehicle, like a tiny car, to go down three kilometers to study underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, there is not much space. Rachel can touch the two pilots sitting next to her. They cannot stand up or move much, and they must stay inside until someone opens the door from outside. A dive can last 16 hours - three hours to go down, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up. If there is a problem, they can press a panic button. This makes a small escape vessel go up quickly to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has used it yet, but it might not be a fun ride. Rachel was nervous the first time she went in the vehicle. She was on a ship and got in with a teacher who showed her what to do in an emergency. Now, Rachel has done six dives. Last year, she went with a Russian team to a place near the Canary Islands. There are many underwater volcanoes there. The Russian team was putting equipment there to study the volcanoes. When Rachel is not at sea, she is in her office at the university. She spends most of her time teaching, but she loves researching the "black smokers." These are underwater volcanoes that release hot water that looks like black smoke. The water comes out very fast and is very hot. Rachel was scared once when she was with an American team. They heard a loud bang and thought something bad happened. But they were okay. Rachel loves the adventure of diving deep into the ocean. She feels amazed every time she sees the underwater volcanoes. She studied them for three years, and seeing them in real life was incredible for her.'

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a bit suntanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was tired, and my mind was tired of foreign timetables, money, and languages.
