"Never again," I said when I got home. But I said the same thing the next year. And the year after that. I just needed to buy one train ticket, and because I was under twenty-five, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month. Sleeping in a train corridor is different from sleeping in a bed. The train's movement helps you sleep deeply. Carrying everything in a backpack makes you travel simply. Sometimes, I even burned socks that smelled bad and threw away books after reading them. This is the Inter-Rail spirit, where you can forget about common sense. All you need is a ticket. This train ticket lets young people travel to many countries quickly. On my first trip, my friends and I thought it was just a cheap way to get to our camp-site in southern France. But we wanted to travel more because there was always another country nearby. And it didn't cost us extra. We were not very interested in culture. This was our first holiday without parents, like many other Inter-Railers. We only saw the most obvious sights. We wanted to escape guided tours and do something different. I was proud that sometimes I only saw the view from the train station. We were there to have fun. We shared train floors, food, water, money, and music with other Inter-Railers. The excitement of travel comes from seeing a place that was just a name before. A city feels real when the train arrives, and you see it with your own eyes. You can only understand Europe by seeing it yourself. Everyone knows what is there, but it means nothing until you see it. This is why other people's holiday photos are boring. The train trip won't show you new things in the world, but it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is big, and Inter-Rail helps you see this, even if it takes time.

'It is very disappointing to arrive at an airport in another country and find out that your bags are not there. You might have to wear the same clothes for hours or days until the airline finds your bags. Sometimes, you might be in a place with a different climate and have to wear clothes that are not right for the weather. Airlines do not often say how many bags they lose, but it happens to people who travel a lot. Even the best airlines make mistakes, and they cannot promise that your bags will be on the same flight as you, especially if you have to change planes. 
Airlines ask you to check in early so there is enough time for your bags to go through the airport and onto the plane. The shortest time to change between flights is called Minimum Connecting Time (MCT), and it is also longer to help with bag transfers. Usually, this system works well. But extra security checks and air traffic problems can delay flights and cause the baggage system to fail. Sometimes, human mistakes or accidents, like a torn label, can also cause problems. These issues are worse at big airports, called 'hubs', because they handle many bags. For example, last year, London's Heathrow airport had over 41 million passengers, and nine million of them changed planes. British Airways had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, with many moving between Terminal 1 and Terminal 4. Even good airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich have bad days. 
The chance of losing bags is higher at some airports. In the United States, Miami airport is known for losing bags when passengers connect to flights to Latin America. To avoid losing your bags, choose direct flights if you can and check in early. If you must change planes, try to fly with the same airline and allow more time between flights. Label your bags inside and out with your home and holiday addresses, and include flight numbers. If your bags still go missing, talk to the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.'

'The Kingfisher Wildlife photographer Charlie James knows a lot about the kingfisher. This bird is blue-green and lives near streams and rivers. It eats fish. Old trees hang over the stream, making some parts of the water dark. The main colors are soft greens, browns, and yellows from the sunlight. The kingfisher flies very fast and straight, like a flash of light. It is small, but very powerful. Charlie James loved kingfishers from a young age. He cannot say exactly why he likes them so much. There are many stories about kingfishers. One Greek story says a moon goddess became a kingfisher. Another story says the kingfisher flew so high that its top became blue like the sky, and its bottom was burned by the sun. This story has some truth. Kingfishers do not have blue color in their feathers. The feathers reflect light, which makes them look blue. Sometimes they look green when the light changes. Many photographers love kingfishers because of their colors. Kingfishers are shy, but you can watch them from a hidden place. Charlie James first hid under an old blanket to watch them. The bird came very close to him. It took him four years to take a good picture. He spent a lot of time by streams with kingfishers. He missed school to watch them and did not do well in his studies. But people noticed his interest in kingfishers. At 16, he worked for a nature magazine. Later, he became a wildlife film cameraman. Now, he wants to make a film about kingfishers with no talking, just beautiful pictures. He loves the simple beauty of the kingfisher's wings. His photos show his feelings, but there is more to his love for kingfishers than his work can show.'

Title: Conducting an Orchestra
Giving directions to an orchestra is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work.
A. ANNE MANSON
Anne Manson, 30, got a chance to help famous conductor Claudio Abbado in Vienna. She was not nervous and enjoyed working with the orchestra. Anne is from America and works with a London opera company. She is becoming known in Europe with help from the British Arts Council. She has worked with Abbado on many projects.
B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE
Andrew Constantine, 31, says the hardest part of being a conductor is getting the right opportunities. He won a big competition in 1991 after trying twice before. The win gave him many chances to perform and work with a famous conductor. He hopes people will remember him for more than just the competition. The English Chamber Orchestra invites him back, which is a good sign for his career.
C. WASFI KANI
Wasfi Kani started Pimlico Opera and loves the long practice time for operas. She began conducting in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London until Pimlico Opera became professional. Learning from Sian Edwards was important for her. She likes the challenges of opera and working with singers.
D. ROGER VIGNOLES
Roger Vignoles, 48, is surprised by his new career in conducting. He started as a musician in an opera house and worked with good conductors. Last year, he directed Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival. He found it easier than expected because he knew the music well. He is learning from all his experiences and is open to new opportunities.
E. WAYNE MARSHALL
In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed Wayne Marshall, now 32, and helped him get a job conducting a musical in London. It was a tough start, but Wayne was firm with the musicians. He has not formally studied conducting but is confident and knows what he likes. People have been supportive of him.

**Theme Park Visits**
If you want to take children to a theme park in Britain, there are many to choose from. We asked five families to try the best ones.
**Fun Island - The Burns Family**
Last year, we visited a big theme park in the US, so we thought Fun Island might be boring. But we were surprised! The park is good for young children, so our three-year-old had fun too. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older kids, there are scarier rides like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were tired, but the kids wanted to stay longer because they were having so much fun. The park could look nicer, but the staff are very helpful, and it is clean and safe.
**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**
We had never been to a theme park before, so we didn't know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and Little Land, with small models of famous buildings. The older kids liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a road. We stayed for six hours and liked that there were places to rest. The park looks beautiful, and the staff are friendly. There is something for everyone, even adults.
**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**
After seven hours, we still had more to see. The kids loved the Big Top Circus with a great trapeze act. We went on the Terror Line, and even though the girls were scared, they liked it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you'll get wet, but you don't. Toy Land is fun for younger kids. The kids wanted to try the new ride, Fear Factor, but they were too small. The park is well designed, so waiting in line isn't too boring. It's very clean, and the staff are nice. On one ride, a staff member helped by sitting with one of my girls.
**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**
We arrived at 1 p.m. and were sad that the park closed at 5 p.m. This park is great for younger kids because the rides aren't too scary. I am usually scared, but I had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slow and then gets exciting. We waited 30 minutes for Lightning River, and it was over quickly! I didn't try the Big Leap, but it looked fun. If the kids were older, they might find it a bit boring, but they loved it.
**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**
The park says there is 'No Limit to the Fun,' and we agree. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, is very scary, but Ben loved it. Jennie thought the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was scarier! There are many rides, and the older kids went on them many times. Sarah was too small for some rides but liked the Long Slide. The staff were sometimes nice, but not always. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We couldn't tell the kids we were leaving early!

**Running a Business in the Countryside: Five Women's Stories**
A. Christine Hogan runs a computer-aided design business. She makes over £200,000 a year and has four full-time workers. Christine and her husband moved from London to the countryside when their children were young. She wanted a job she could do from home. Christine had worked with computers before, so her husband suggested starting a computer-aided design business. It was hard at first and needed a lot of money. Christine was careful with money and talked to the bank manager if she spent too much. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evenings. Her business is small, and local people usually come to pick up their work.
B. Maggy Sasanow is a designer of greeting cards and works from home. She studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum, but there were no such jobs in the countryside. So, she started her own business and makes 50 different greeting cards, which she sells to museums. Maggy works in a big room at home. The downside of working from home is that there are always chores to do, like mowing the lawn. She gets business through word of mouth and doesn't advertise. People send her work from London because she is cheaper. Maggy misses sharing ideas with others but finds more good things than bad in her work.
C. Delia Turner has a curtain-making business. She started it eight years ago. At first, her business grew quickly, and she managed six full-time workers. But when the economy got worse, she had to let them go, which was hard because jobs are scarce in her area. Now, Delia makes curtains at home with her husband's help and other women who work from their homes. She has to lower her prices sometimes and look for new opportunities.
D. Tessa Strickland runs a children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago because London was too expensive and she loves the country. Tessa likes working when she wants. Most of her money comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so she takes calls at odd hours. The hard part is closing the office door and stopping work. Tessa publishes children's books from different cultures and works with authors and artists. She felt lonely at first because all her work experience was in London.
E. Meg Rivers runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop. She makes £250,000 a year and employs six people, some part-time. Meg started ten years ago at home. She is interested in health, so she began making fruit cakes with good flour and eggs. Friends and family liked them, and soon she was sending cakes all over the country. Seven years ago, she rented a small building where everything is made. She has a baker, an assistant, and a professional cake decorator. Meg doesn't bake now; she manages the business side. Her biggest problem has been money because she didn't have much to start with.

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**
The Watkins family is special because they all love music. The sons, Paul and Huw, are musicians and composers. Their dad, John, makes musical instruments. 
When Paul was ten years old, he needed a cello. But cellos were very expensive. So, John decided to make one himself. He went to the Welsh School of Instrument Making for evening classes for three years. After making some violins and violas, he made his first cello for Paul. It was very good, and Paul used it for many years.
John stopped teaching to make instruments full-time. He makes about twelve violins a year. He even sold one to a famous American musician, Jaime Laredo.
Paul and Huw started playing music when they were young. Paul first played the piano, then he wanted to play the cello. He liked the person who played the cello in his dad's music group. So, he started learning the cello and became very good at it. Huw also plays music but chose the piano and became a composer.
Paul won a big music competition with the cello his dad made. He became the main cellist for the BBC Symphony Orchestra when he was only 20 years old. Now, he plays a very old and special cello from the Royal Academy of Music.
Paul will play on TV soon, but he can't watch it because he has a concert the same night. Huw also has a big event that night. Their parents, John and Hetty, will be busy trying to see both of their sons' performances.

Title: Taking Care of the Countryside
THE NATIONAL TRUST
The National Trust is a group that helps protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden who works for the Trust. 
Gareth says a warden needs common sense and must be good with people. He talks to farmers, visitors, and builders. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his family's farm. Many people wanted the warden job, but Gareth got it because he knows the area well and has farming experience, even though he didn't have special training.
Gareth still helps on his parents' farm, which helps him understand farmers' problems. He is also strong enough for the job, which includes building fences, planting trees, and making walls. Working with the Trust, Gareth learned more about nature conservation. He remembers collecting flowers and bird nests as a child and now sees how farming has changed the countryside. He says it's not the farmers' fault; they were following government advice.
At first, farmers and conservationists did not agree, but now they talk and understand each other better. Gareth's job includes conservation, letting people visit Trust land, planting trees, and meeting farmers. He makes sure work is done well and cheaply. He likes finishing projects, but he also spends time on paperwork.
Gareth loves his job, even though he is always working. He enjoys talking to people, but some visitors can be rude. They act like they own the place, which annoys him. But, as Gareth says, it's all about common sense. If you have common sense and like working outside, you might want to be a warden like Gareth. But don't expect a job on the Lleyn Peninsula soon!

'The Netball Captain In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain. Kendra Slowinski is the captain of England's netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day. She taught at a local school and then trained in a supermarket car park. 'Don't people look at you strangely?' I asked her. 'I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice,' she said. 'I might see cars slow down, but that's all.' 'My whole life is about being my best for the Championships,' says Kendra. 'I have a strict plan to be very fit.' These are her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries. 'We will have support from people here, which is special,' she says. 'It's important to make netball more popular in this country. There will be more pressure because people expect us to play well.' Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. 'We have always beaten them, but they are good players,' she says. The England team is ranked fourth in the world. But the World Championships will be hard. 'You have to play every day, with no rest. You only have one chance to win,' says Kendra. In the fifteen years she has played at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive. 'You train to win,' says Kendra. 'But after the game, we are all friendly.' Netball now uses more science for fitness. 'We must think and train like world-class players,' says Kendra. 'As captain, I need a strong mind and must lead by example. I support and encourage my team.' 'From the start, my netball career was planned,' she says. 'I decided this competition would be my last as a player.' She might coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye.'

**Specialist Music Schools**
What can you do if your child is very good at music? It can be hard to know how to help them. Some parents might not see their child's need until the child becomes upset or difficult. Most schools can help children who are good at subjects like math or English, but musically talented children need special help. Regular schools might not have this help, especially if music is not important there. 
Children who are very good at music might do well at a specialist music school. In Britain, there are five music schools for children aged seven to eighteen. These schools help children improve their music skills with the help of professional musicians. At these schools, children spend a lot of time on music activities like lessons, playing in groups, singing, and learning music theory. They also practice a lot in special rooms. The rest of their time is for important subjects like English, math, science, and languages. 
These music schools are private, and classes are small. Most children live at the school, which means they spend a lot of time with other children who love music. 
There are some problems with these schools. They are expensive, costing between £12,000 and £17,000 a year. But schools try to help with scholarships and financial aid. Also, not all parents want their young children to live away from home. Some school directors think it might not be good for very young children to be in such a strict environment. They want to make sure children grow up to be well-rounded people. 
Being in a music school can be stressful. Some children might lose interest in music as they grow older. The pressure to be the best can make them feel like they failed. But schools watch each child's progress and help if needed. 
Some students feel they learned a lot about music at these schools, but they worry about not learning enough in other subjects. Many musically talented children are also smart and want to learn more academically. 
For these reasons, it might be better to wait until the child is older and can decide for themselves about going to a music school. Children who are good at both music and academics might do well in a regular school with a good music program. They can also take music lessons on weekends at music colleges, but this is only possible for families near big cities like London.

'Susan Shepherd is an artist who paints flowers. She is famous for her flower paintings. Her house has a big garden with many flowers. She likes tulips and poppies the most. Some plants grow everywhere in the garden. The garden has many colors and shapes. The people who lived there before Susan loved gardening. They left many plants for her. Susan also has a gardener named Danny. She says, "It was really his garden." At first, Danny did not like some of Susan's ideas, but he understood when she said she wanted to paint them. Susan likes to paint one flower at a time. She picks flowers and takes them to her studio. She paints one flower, which can take a few days, and then adds another. Sometimes, it takes years to finish a painting. Spring and early summer are her busiest times because tulips and poppies bloom then. Susan likes to watch flowers change. Tulips, for example, change shape in water. Susan has always liked plants. She studied botany in school and collected wild flowers. She did not like garden flowers before because they looked fake to her. Now, her garden has plants from other countries, like China and the Himalayas. Susan lets her garden grow freely, like a kind aunt with children. She is busy with two art shows and has a new gardener to help. But she knows she must work in the garden to stay connected to her art.'

Title: A Day in the Life of a Chalet Girl
Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a 24-year-old from West Sussex. She works as a chalet girl in Val d'Isère, France. This is her second year doing this job. Sarah cooks and cleans for people who come to ski and stay in chalets, which are wooden houses. She studied French and History of Art at Oxford Brookes University. Sarah says being a chalet girl is not a career, but it's fun for a year or two before starting a serious job. She meets many successful people every week.
Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks to the chalet, which can have up to 18 guests each week. She eats her breakfast first, then makes breakfast for the guests. They have porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, Sarah cleans up and prepares afternoon tea or cleans the rooms. She says cleaning is the hardest part of the job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to go skiing. She skis until about 4:30 p.m.
Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower but does not sleep because it makes her too tired. Dinner is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans up and fills the dishwasher. Sometimes she talks with the guests, and other times they want to be alone. Good guests make the week fun, but sometimes things don't go well.
Sarah meets her friends at her chalet and they go out at 11 p.m. They visit places like Bananas, G Jay's, and Dick's T-Bar. She does not stay out too late on Saturday because Sunday is her busiest day. On Sunday, she starts work early because breakfast must be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, she cleans everything quickly. If she hasn't shopped on Saturday, she does it now. At 3 p.m., she prepares tea for new guests who arrive around 4:30 p.m. She helps them with questions and takes them to get ski equipment if needed. Then it's time for dinner again. Sometimes she chats with friends, but if she's tired, she goes to bed early.

**Changing Lives with a Stranger**
**Mandie Currie, Zoo-Keeper:**
Mandie works at a zoo. She spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. She usually wears a uniform, so choosing clothes was hard. She visited a photo studio and press events. The zoo is calm, but the magazine office was busy. Some fashion team members were stressed, but Mandie's job is not stressful. At a fashion shoot, she thought it was funny because she usually cleans cages or handles rats. She likes seeing how magazines work but loves her zoo job and wants to stay there.
**Alice Cutler, Fashion Assistant:**
Alice works at Marie Claire. She spent a day at London Zoo. She wore leather boots and blue trousers, but the zoo gave her a green shirt because she got dirty. She touched an elephant and thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By the end of the day, she was dirty but happy. She thinks she might work with elephants in Africa when she stops working in fashion.
**Karen Hodson, Nurse:**
Karen is a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital. She spent a day with the TV gardening show Ground Force. She was excited to meet the team and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter. She liked being outside because she sometimes doesn't see daylight due to her shifts. The work was hard but fun. She thought gardening was romantic but didn't know it was hard work. She doesn't plan to leave her nursing job.
**Charlie Dimmock, Landscape Gardener:**
Charlie works on the TV show Ground Force. She spent a day at Hammersmith Hospital. She made beds and gave out medicine. She thought she might faint but was okay. The nurses were friendly, and it felt different from her usual work with men. She thinks her job is less important than nursing. Her day at the hospital was not fun, but she felt satisfied.
**Lucy Harvey, Personal Trainer:**
Lucy is a personal trainer. She spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. She wore a uniform and felt different. Before the flight, she learned about safety and heart attacks, which she knew from her training. She gave out magazines on a flight to Paris. She felt shy because everyone looked at her. On the way back, there were 80 schoolchildren who wouldn't sit still. She wished she was back in the gym.
**Sonia McDermott, Air Hostess:**
Sonia works for Ryanair. She spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. She was worried because she doesn't exercise. She was surprised by how much attention trainers give to one person. In her job, she meets many passengers. She was surprised that trainers didn't always eat healthily but drank a lot of water. She doesn't want to change jobs but wants to join a gym to be healthier.

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Memories**
**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I love the south of France and visit often. There is a train from Cannes that goes along the coast and into Italy. The views of the sea are amazing, no matter the weather or time of year. You can also see beautiful gardens and homes. The people on the train are interesting, with both tourists and locals enjoying the trip.
**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have taken many train trips, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express in northern Sudan. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip to the Kruger National Park because I was too young. My first real train station was London Waterloo, and it amazed me.
**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
The Blue Train is special to me because it took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. I heard pink is good for the brain, so I wear it often. The journey through France and up the Nile was a perfect way to relax after our wedding.
**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
For a work trip, we had to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express train. The schedule was not fixed, and the driver would wait for people. Many people climbed onto the train, even on the roof. At night, the train passed through beautiful landscapes, like a dream.
**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I did not see many trains. As a teenager, I made a film in Yorkshire with a railway. The old train line was kept by volunteers. I fell in love with steam trains there. When I visited last year, everything looked the same, even the gas lights on the station platform!

'Do you want to get your story published? Our expert, Margaret Stubbs, can help you. Many people ask, 'I wrote a story or book. Who should I send it to?' First, you need to learn about publishers and practice writing. Selling your writing needs knowledge about the 'writing world'. No matter what you write, you need to know about the markets you want to reach. The best way to learn is by reading a lot. Visit your local library, bookshops, and newsagents. Reading will show you what publishers want. Remember, things change often. New magazines come out, editors change jobs, and magazines change direction. Publishers always want new writers, so we must give them what they want. If you want to write short love stories, find out which magazines publish them. Get recent copies and see what kind of stories they like. Know who the readers are because the editor wants to please them. Writers often ask me, 'My story was rejected three times. Am I wasting my time?' I never discourage anyone, but maybe the work is not ready to be published. Many new writers send their work too soon. If you have only written one story, it is not likely to be published. Success usually comes after years in publishing or journalism. When you send your work, keep writing more stories. Write ten or even twenty more. Each story will be better, and you will feel more like a writer. Don't throw any stories away—improve them. I suggest not showing your work to others at first. Remember, every successful writer faced many rejections. Do everything you can to become a better writer. Look for a creative writing course or join a local writers' group. This will help you get ideas and confidence. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if you can.'

'No Title On the last day of a bad year, I was waiting at the Baltimore train station to catch the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people than I thought there would be. The station didn't feel as nice and clean as usual. Older couples with matching bags sat on the benches, and many college students sat on the floor with their bags. A man with grey hair was talking to different people. He looked rich: tanned skin, nice sweater, and a soft, beige coat. He asked a woman sitting alone a question. Then he talked to a girl near me. She had long blond hair, and I thought I might like to talk to her too. The man asked, 'Are you going to Philadelphia?' 'Well, I'm going north,' she said. 'But to Philadelphia?' 'No, New York, but I'll be ...' 'Thanks, anyway,' he said, and moved to the next bench. Now I was interested. 'Ma'am,' he asked an old lady, 'are you going to Philadelphia?' When she said, 'Wilmington,' he didn't say anything and went to another couple. I moved closer, pretending to look at the train platform. I was going to Philadelphia. He could have asked me. I knew why he didn't. I probably looked unreliable. He just glanced at me and went to the other end of the waiting area. He looked stressed. 'Please!' he said to a woman reading a book. 'Tell me you're going to Philadelphia!' She put her book down. She was about thirty-five, older than me. She looked like a teacher. 'Philadelphia?' she said. 'Yes, I am.' 'Could I ask you a favor?' I stopped a few feet away and looked at my wrist as if I had a watch. (I don't have a watch.) Even without looking, I could tell she was cautious. The man must have noticed too, because he said, 'Nothing too difficult, I promise!' They announced my train. People started moving to Gate E, the older couples pulling their bags like big pets. I heard the man talking. 'My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad, leaving from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, then went for groceries, and came home to find my wife upset. My daughter forgot her passport. She called from the station in Philadelphia; she didn't know what to do.' The woman made a sympathetic sound. I would have stayed quiet to see what he wanted. 'So I told her to stay there. I said I would find someone here to take her passport.' A likely story! Why didn't he go himself if it was so important? 'Why don't you go yourself?' the woman asked. 'I can't leave my wife alone for that long. She's in a wheelchair.' This seemed like a weak excuse to me. Also, it seemed like too much bad luck for one family. I looked at them. The man was holding a packet, not a plain envelope, but a padded one the size of a small book. Aha! Padded! So you couldn't feel what was inside! And it looked stapled shut. Be careful, lady, I thought.'

Title: Gary and Me
John Moore, a restaurant owner, talks about his son Gary, who is a famous TV chef.
I think everyone gets a chance in life. My son, Gary, got his chance with cooking, and my chance was to run a restaurant. When I found out about the restaurant, I went quickly to see it. It was in bad shape, but it was just what I wanted. Starting this business made me remember my childhood. I remember my mom going to work in a factory, and I was sad because I was alone. So, I thought, 'We need time for family.' My wife took care of the kids and did my accounts, while I ran the restaurant. We lived above the restaurant, and we always made sure to eat meals together. This was good for our children, Gary and Joe. They are both very confident. From a young age, they would talk to our regular customers. This helped them a lot in life.
Gary was a lively child. When he was about seven, he jumped into a bath like it was a swimming pool and hurt himself. When he was older, he worked for pocket money. He started with small jobs and by ten, he was in the kitchen every weekend, so he always had money at school. He was disciplined. He would wake up even before me. In a family business, everyone helps, and it was nice to see him helping. Gary wasn't very good at school, but he was great in the kitchen. By 15, he was as good as the adults working there, and sometimes he was in charge. He could make over a hundred meals, and I knew he would work in catering because he was talented. When he needed work experience for school, I sent him to a friend's restaurant.
Gary recently started playing the drums and now has a band. I wonder what will happen to his cooking if his music becomes successful. I told Gary, 'If you try to do two things, you might not succeed in either, so focus on what you know you can do.' He understood when I said, 'Gary, if you want to succeed, do it by 30. After that, it might be too late.' Gary went to catering college at 17. On his first day, he finished a morning's work in an hour. That's my son! He even helped others. We can't believe how successful Gary's TV cooking show is. I'm very proud of him. I always told him that if you want something, you have to work hard for it. He saw his chance and took it. When you talk to your kids, if they remember even a little, you should be happy. The things Gary says and does show he listened sometimes.

Finding a good flat in Dublin that you can afford is very difficult. The best way is to know someone who knows someone leaving a place. But if you are new in Dublin, like Jo, you don't have any contacts. You have to stay in a hostel and search for a flat. For Jo, Dublin was a big unknown place. She felt like she was going into the unknown when she took the train to work there. Everyone at her school thought she would go to Dublin. No one wanted to stay in their small town. Some of her classmates went to towns like Ennis or Limerick, where they had family. But Jo was the only one going to Dublin alone.
Jo's mother thought it would be good if she stayed in the hostel run by nuns, as it was safe. Her father hoped the hostel was warm because hostels are often cold. Jo's sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy to stay in a hostel for a week. Jo didn't know they were all talking about her as she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was close to the post office where she worked and seemed perfect. Jo hoped it was nice, that they would like her, and that it wasn't too expensive.
There wasn't a long line for this flat because it was more like "Third Girl Wanted" than "Flat to Let." The "own television" part made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked normal. It was a red-brick terraced house with a basement, but the flat was upstairs. A cheerful girl with a college scarf, who didn't get the flat, was coming down the stairs. She said to Jo, "Desperate place. They're both awful. Common as dirt." Jo continued up the stairs.
"Hello," said a girl with "Nessa" on her T-shirt. "Did you see that snobby girl leaving? I can't stand her type." Jo asked, "What did she do?" Nessa replied, "She didn't do much. She just looked around, made a face, and giggled, saying, 'Is this all there is? Oh dear,' in a fancy accent. We wouldn't have her here, right, Pauline?" Pauline wore a very colorful shirt and had bright hair. Jo was surprised because Pauline was a punk. Jo had seen punks on O'Connell Street but never talked to one.
"I'm Jo, I work at the post office, and I called about the flat," Jo said. Nessa said they were about to have tea and brought out three mugs. One said "Nessa," one said "Pauline," and the other said "Other." Nessa said kindly, "We'll put your name on it if you stay."

'Dolphins and Their Problems People love dolphins. We like to see them at the beach, in movies, and on TV. But the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society says dolphins are in trouble. Mark Simmonds talks about why dolphins are in danger. Dolphins are special to us. They are very smart animals. They understand human feelings, and they make us think of freedom in the ocean. TV shows like Flipper and Seaquest make us love them more. But these shows do not show the real problems dolphins face in dirty and overfished seas. The number of North Sea harbour porpoises (a type of dolphin) has gone down by up to 89,000. You might think dolphins are protected by law and live in safe places. But this is not true, and not helping them could be a big problem for wildlife. There are 40 kinds of dolphins in the world. In northern Europe, the most common dolphins are the striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The first two live far out in the sea. We only see them in small groups near ships, and we do not know much about them. The large grey bottlenoses and harbour porpoises used to be seen near European coasts. Bottlenoses are very social and were found on the Channel coast and in British rivers like the Thames. Now, they are only found in a few places in Scotland and Wales, and they have skin injuries that show they are stressed. Dolphins have complex habits, so it is hard to know why their numbers are going down. Overfishing is a big problem. It reduces fish stocks and hurts local fishing industries. Porpoises need to find food quickly. If fish are taken away by fishing, they may not find food in time. They can also get caught in fishing nets, which they cannot see. Modern fishing uses big nets that float or move fast in the sea. Many dead dolphins have been found on beaches in France and Cornwall. Marks and cuts on their bodies show they were caught in these nets. Waste and chemicals in the sea can stay in dolphins' bodies. For example, pesticides dissolve in fat, so dolphins can eat them, and they build up in their bodies. Female dolphins then make milk with pesticides, passing the poison to their babies. There is a case of a baby dolphin dying from its mother's milk. Another problem for dolphins is human noise. Dolphins live in groups and use sound to understand their world. In the sea, noise from ships and oil wells travels four times better than in the air. This noise may bother dolphins in ways we do not know yet.'

**GETTING FIT**
Exercise is very important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you stay balanced when life feels busy and stressful. You might think, "Oh no, another article about exercise!" But there are many good reasons to exercise. 
Exercise makes your muscles stronger and changes your body shape quickly. It helps you stand or sit better, which is called good posture. Good posture is important because it stops muscle problems that can cause injuries. Exercise also helps your heart, lungs, and blood circulation.
Exercise can make you feel less sad and tired. It helps you sleep better and manage stress. It can also help with some health problems. 
There are many types of exercise you can try, like aerobics, jogging, or lifting weights. But be careful not to train too hard or lift too much weight, as this can cause injuries. Start slowly and carefully. If you are unsure, ask your doctor what is best for you.
Good posture is very important. It affects how you look and feel. If you slouch, imagine a balloon pulling your head up to the sky. This helps you stand straight and breathe better. It also makes your body look slimmer.
Stretching your muscles is important too. It makes you more flexible and helps prevent injuries. Stretching should be part of your exercise routine. Do it slowly and carefully, four or five times a week.
The best exercise routine includes a warm-up, stretching, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.

**In Their Natural Habitat**
Why do film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman leave their comfortable homes for many months? They want to find the perfect picture. In the jungles and plains of East Africa, it is hard to find Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman. They are in the Ngorongoro Crater, where it has rained for six months. This rain causes problems. Newman said they bought an expensive tool to help when their car gets stuck in the mud. Amanda can then pull him out safely. Together, they have made some of the best wildlife films on TV, like their famous film about leopards. Even when this film was on TV, they were already back in Africa, looking for another shy animal, the jackal. 
Traveling film-makers have been going around the world to film wild animals since TV started. I talked to Newman at a safari lodge. He said they sometimes argue, but they quickly make up. They do not see one person as the leader. They get along well because they both see animals in the same way. When they travel, they set up tents every night. But now, they have a fixed camp. They start their day at 5 a.m., so they make tea the night before and keep it warm in a flask. They eat pre-packed meals, which they heat up. They can be away for up to eight weeks, so food can be a problem, says Newman. 
Living in remote areas is hard, but they like being close to the animals. Once, they filmed a family of lions. One lioness would leave and come back, greeting all the lions. She even greeted their car. Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called 'The Great Rift'. Two years later, they filmed Arctic foxes together. They spend four months in one place to make enough material for a half-hour film. Before they start, they need to get a script approved. Newman says they work well together because they share the same ideas. They want to make films that show the true spirit of the place and animals and touch people's hearts. Newman believes it is better to make people feel something than just think about it.

'In hot water Rachel Mills is a scientist who studies the sea. She works at Southampton University and teaches about the ocean. Rachel also studies underwater volcanoes. She goes in a small steel vehicle, like a car, to the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Inside the vehicle, there is not much space. She can touch the two pilots next to her. They cannot stand up or move much. They stay inside until someone opens the door from outside. A dive lasts 16 hours: three hours to go down, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up. If there is a problem, they can press a panic button. This makes a small escape vessel go up quickly to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has used it yet, but it might not be a nice trip. Rachel was nervous the first time she went in the vehicle. She was on a ship with an instructor who showed her what to do in an emergency. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she went with a Russian team to a place near the Canary Islands. There are many underwater volcanoes there. The Russian team left some equipment to study the volcanoes. When Rachel is not at sea, she is in her office at the university. She loves teaching, but she also loves her research on "black smokers." These are underwater volcanoes that release hot water that looks like black smoke. The water comes out very fast and is very hot. Rachel was scared once when she was with an American team. They heard a loud bang and thought something bad would happen, but they were okay. Diving in the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. She feels amazed every time she sees the volcanoes. She studied them for three years, and seeing them in real life was incredible for her.'

**Interview Tips**
First impressions are very important. People decide what they think about us in the first few minutes. They look at how we dress, our eye contact, our body movement, how fast or slow we talk, and our voice. Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She says, 'I worked hard to get my degree. When I graduated, I was very confident.' She applied for a job at a primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. 'I saw a small hole in my jacket that morning,' she remembers. 'I wanted to change, but I knew it would make me late, and I think it's important to be on time.' Mary didn't get the job. Her friend, who also works at the school, told her the Head Teacher said, 'If someone doesn't try to look their best at an interview, what kind of teacher will they be?' 
Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says: 'People who look like they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. People think it's what's inside that counts, but in an interview, you should try to look your best.' Many people forget how important it is to look professional. For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an assistant in a big accounting firm. When the office manager left, she applied for the job but didn't get an interview. 'I thought it was a mistake, so I asked the Director of Personnel what happened,' she says. 'He told me I didn't look like an office manager. He suggested I dress better before I apply again. I was shocked. I do a good job, and the way I dress shouldn't matter.'
How we move and our gestures also affect the interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 7% of our message comes from words, 38% from our voice, and 55% from our facial expressions. If our facial expressions and words are different, the listener will believe the facial expressions more. So make sure your words and body language match. Mixed messages will confuse the interviewer. It's also important not to look too desperate for the job or too eager to please. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion. Her interview went well, and she got the job right away. 'I was happy,' she remembers. 'But I showed too much excitement. When the boss saw how excited I was, he knew I wouldn't say no. So, he offered me a lower salary than I wanted. I'm sure I could have got more if I controlled my excitement.'
Finally, think about what you say and how you say it. David Artesio, a manager at an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. 'The annual report, for example, will tell you about the company. Mention something that interests you during the interview. This will show you are interested in the company.' Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests having a few questions ready and speaking in short, clear sentences. She says, 'Poor communicators talk in long paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and clear points.'

**A New Life**
**The Farmer**
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London. Now, he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years, but it became boring and not fun anymore. He lost his job suddenly and used the money he got to start the farm. He met a chef from a famous hotel, and now he sells meat to them and also by mail. He is happy not to be in an office, but he still works long hours.
**The Painter**
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising. Now, he is an artist. Painting was his hobby, and he enjoyed it more than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. A career counselor helped him. Most people need to work for money, but Ron's children were grown up, so he didn't need to support them. He moved to the north of England, far from his friends, but they still visit him.
**The Hat Maker**
Katherine Goodison was a lawyer. Now, she makes hats in her London flat. She liked her job as a lawyer, but the hours were too long. She didn't want to work more, so she left. People thought she would get bored, but she didn't. She has many deadlines because of fashion seasons. She is happier and less stressed now. She misses talking to colleagues but likes being responsible for her work.
**The Masseur**
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years. Now, he is a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He started working in finance at 22 but didn't find it rewarding. He almost lost his job in 1989, so he quit and traveled for a year. He wanted to work in health, so he visited gyms and talked to owners. He took courses in massage and got a part-time job at the Life Centre. He is happy now and feels in control of his life.

**Dedicated to Their Sports: Four Young Sports Stars Talk About Their Lives**
**A. Darius (Runner)**  
I have always liked sports. I played many sports, but I was best at football and running. When I was 14, I tried out for a professional football team, but I chose to focus on running instead. My best moment was when I ran for my country in the youth team and won a medal. I hoped to get some sponsorship because training is expensive, but I didn't get much attention from the media. I train at home in the winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It's fun because there are great places to train and good nightlife. But I have to be disciplined. If friends ask me to go out before training, I have to say no. I want to go to the next Olympics. That would be amazing.
**B. Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so I see the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are often early in the morning. So, I can't go to late-night parties. I don't mind that, but I like to sleep in, and I have to give that up too. It's worth it because I won the National Championships last year. After a win, I like to have a big night out, and if I win money, I go somewhere nice. Winning the championship helped me get a job on a TV surfing show. I guess I'm a bit famous now.
**C. Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
When five guys are on a boat, we have a lot of fun. We celebrate wins in a big way. Some people say we act like kids, but we don't try to get media attention. Reporters sometimes care more about our celebrations than our races. I'm away for eight months a year, so it's nice to come home and hang out with friends who do different things. You can't think about the sport all the time. I'm known in sailing, but I don't get recognized on the street often. I don't want to be a celebrity. I get letters from people asking for signed pictures, and I reply to all of them. It takes time, but I don't mind.
**D. Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It's great to play tennis and feel the crowd supporting you. At the last tournament, it got a bit crazy with people around me. I like it when fans recognize me when I'm shopping. But it can be hard. My last girlfriend didn't like it when I got attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that's why we broke up. It was hard, but you have to be serious and professional in sports. I'm okay with focusing on my game now. I can do other things in life after I retire because that happens early in tennis.

'Shopping with Children Shopping with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it's not a sweet breakfast cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually all three. I can't buy all this, and I feel bad for saying no all the time. I try not to take them shopping, but then I worry they won't learn how to make choices. I can't win." Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes in a supermarket. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising to children, mostly on TV. This number will probably grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising works best. Children often don't understand why parents say no to buying things. They don't believe that sugar is bad for teeth when they see fun and exciting ads. Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always right. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents don't like competing with ads and having to say no to their children." The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, does not allow ads to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But, as Dibb says, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. So even if they can't say, 'Tell your mum to buy this,' the ads still try to make that happen." Some parents find it stressful to decide which things to buy for their children and which to refuse. One mother says she talks a lot with her children about food and ads. Her son listens to ads but is critical of them. They look at labels together, and now her children don't ask for things she doesn't want to buy. Parents also say they are not always fair when they say no to their children's requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We say no to sweets because they are bad for him, but we buy cream and chocolate for ourselves. It's fun to buy nice things, and it's normal for children to want them too. But I still get annoyed by their demands. It depends on how I feel. If I'm happy, I'm more likely to say yes. It's hard to be fair all the time." Supermarkets could help by not putting sweets near the checkout or by having play areas for children. Parents might spend less if their children are not with them, but shopping without a child's demands might bring more customers.'

'Luxury and Modern Technology at the Merrion Hotel The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It took almost two years to change four old houses into this hotel. The hotel has the latest technology for both staff and guests. The General Manager, Peter MacCann, wants his staff to know guests by name. For other details, he uses a computer system. This system helps give special service to guests who come back. It cost a lot of money, but MacCann says it will save money in the long run. The system remembers what guests like. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs, they will have them ready next time. Many guests complain about room temperature. The hotel has a system to control this. Guests can change the temperature a little in their rooms. The front desk can also change it more if needed. Business guests will like the technology in the rooms. MacCann thinks 65% of guests will be business people. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine, and video-conferencing. The hotel is ready for future technology changes. They have extra cables and rent TVs so they can update them easily. Even with all this technology, the rooms are comfortable and welcoming. The hotel has 145 large rooms, a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a nice garden. The food at the hotel is very good. Chef Patrick Guilbaud moved his famous restaurant to the hotel. He has a new kitchen and better parking. The hotel benefits from having a popular restaurant. With good technology and staff, the Merrion Hotel is set to do well.'

Title: How I Get My Energy
Emma Marsden asked six women how they stay energetic and happy. Here is what they said:
A. Jeanette Kupfermann, Journalist and Author: "I get energy from excitement and challenges. Learning new things gives me a lot of energy. I am learning flamenco dancing now, and it makes me feel great. Dance is fun and gives me energy. If you are bored, you can feel tired. Doing something useful, even if it's small, gives you energy."
B. Linda Kelsey, Magazine Editor: "I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it. Work is not hard for me because I like it. I need a lot of sleep, and when I sleep well, I feel good. I try to exercise, like doing yoga once a week. Exercise makes me feel better. In the afternoon, I feel tired, so I eat something to feel better."
C. Annie Nightingale, Disc Jockey: "I get energy from being happy and positive. I don't like negative people. I think we should enjoy life. I love my job, and it is exciting. I like being around young people. I enjoy taking photos and writing songs for fun. It helps me relax when I travel."
D. Floella Benjamin, Author and Children's TV Presenter: "I get energy from doing things I love. I believe in my work and my family. Being positive helps me. I love working with kids because they have a lot of energy. Smiling at people and getting a smile back makes me feel good. I try to eat healthy and don't smoke or drink. I play with kids for exercise."
E. Deborah Moggach, Author and Playwright: "I love making a garden from nothing. I once turned a concrete area into a garden. It was better than any workout. I also get energy from knowing people want to read my writing. I like exploring nature, even if it's private land. It makes me feel like a child."
F. Katherine Monblot, Therapist: "You need to like and respect what you do. I like taking risks and get bored easily, which keeps me active. Doing things you don't like makes you tired. I used to be on committees, but they took too much of my time. Use your energy for things that matter to you."

**ICE SKATING**
Ice skating is a very old activity. People have been ice skating for thousands of years. Long ago, people used skates made from animal bones. These bone skates were used until about the year 200 AD when iron skates came to Scandinavia. In Scandinavia, rich people thought skating was an important skill. 
In the early 1900s, skating was calm and stylish. But in 1924, at the Winter Olympics, an 11-year-old girl named Sonja Henie showed a new, more active way to skate. This made skating more popular. Today, skating is a mix of art and sport. It is beautiful and also hard work.
When you start skating, balance and control are very important. You can go faster as you get better. To keep your balance, your legs should be a little bent, and your knees should be bent too. Your body should lean a little forward. Relaxing is very important in skating. 
To start skating, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. Push forward with one foot and make a small move with the other foot. It is not too hard, right? As you practice, you can make your movements bigger.
Learning how to fall is one of the first things a skater should know. Even the best skaters fall. To fall safely, try to stay relaxed. This helps reduce the impact when you hit the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand up.
Once you can skate well, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance skating, speed skating, and skating in pairs. It is best to start with figure skating and then try simple freestyle. Most ice rinks have teachers who can help you learn the basic moves. After that, you can learn turns, jumps, and spins.
Good skaters look relaxed and move easily. To be like them, you should do exercises regularly. It is not safe to skate with a stiff body. Warm-up exercises should include moves for your legs, back, and shoulders, especially your ankles and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to avoid stiffness.
Skating helps improve balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It is good for your heart and lungs and makes your body stronger. If you also swim or jog, it is a great way to stay healthy and fit.

**Trills and Medals**
Seeing a talented child win a medal can make you cry with happiness. Julia Gregson talked to three young stars and their mothers about their lives.
A. **Annika Reeder, 15**  
Annika won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "The work is very hard now. I don't have time to watch TV or go out with friends. I just do gym and school. I try to take each training day by day. When I am very tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but not often. You can't take too many days off, or you get stiff."
B. **Annika's Mother**  
"Annika showed great talent from a young age. Some parents push their kids, but it doesn't work. To perform like Annika, you have to want it yourself. People say we gave up a lot, but they don't see what the sport gave us. We love it and what it did for Annika. She was shy and sucked her thumb, but now she has met people from all over the world and is confident."
C. **Sarah Stokes**  
Sarah started show-jumping at ten and won the British National Championship. "It's good my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me to events. Shows last one to five days. I never get tired of it. I love show-jumping; it's exciting and fun. Even without my parents, I would do it because I am determined. My goal is to join the British young riders team. I want to win a gold medal at the Olympics."
D. **Sarah's Mother**  
"Sarah loved horses from age 1. At 5, she got up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for big shows, you have to jump all over England. We save money by sleeping in our horse box. Sarah is well-organized and happy on a horse. Watching your child succeed at something they love is amazing."
E. **Jane McShane, 10**  
Jane is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. "Tournaments are friendly. I know everyone, and it's fun. When I play, I don't concentrate much. I should, but I just look around. I'm not afraid of being proud. I don't talk about my success at school because I don't like embarrassment."
F. **Jane's Mother**  
"Jane played her first chess game at 5. My father said, 'Let's see if she likes it.' He tried to teach me, but I was bored. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves, and by 6, she was beating adults. I'm happy when she wins, but if she wanted to stop, I wouldn't stop her. I don't want to hold her back if she has a gift. Let her reach her potential."

'We are all getting taller Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, 'Do you want to be the flagpole on a ship?' because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is the tallest man in Britain. Every ten years, people in Europe get about one centimeter taller. More and more tall people are being born. This does not mean we are becoming a new super race. We are actually going back to how we were as cavemen. We are now eating better, which helps us grow to our full size. Professor Chris Stringer says we are becoming like the Cro-Magnons, who lived 40,000 years ago. In the past, people got food from many places: women collected herbs, fruits, and berries, and men hunted animals. They ate about 85 different wild plants. But about 9,000 years ago, farming started, which changed everything. Farmers took over green areas, and now three plants - wheat, rice, and maize - give us more than half of our food. This poor diet made people less healthy and smaller. In Ohio, scientists found that when people started growing corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sick and underweight farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn was not a blessing but a health problem. Farming spread because it could support more people than hunting and gathering. But most people were not well-fed and were smaller. Only recently have richer countries started eating better again. In Europe, the US, and Japan, people are eating like our ancestors. Now, the average man in the US is 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is good, but it also causes problems. Beds are still 190 cm long, as they were in 1860. Leg-room in planes and trains seems smaller, and clothes makers have to change their sizes. We cannot grow forever. There must be a limit. Robert Fogel from the University says it could be 193 cm, and we might reach it this century. But scientists say that while individuals are getting taller, as a species, we are getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, people were rounder and taller to keep warm. As the climate got warmer, we became thinner and smaller. If the planet keeps getting hotter, we might get even smaller. So, global warming could make us shrink.'

'Studio Audiences What is it like to be in the audience when a TV show is made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Studio audiences are a common part of TV, but many people don't know much about them. We see them excited on game shows and wonder - who are these people? Some people think studio audiences are not very important. Even people who work in TV sometimes don't respect them. I thought studio audiences were just people who wanted to be on TV for a short time. But there is no typical studio audience. They come from all kinds of backgrounds. TV shows try to get different people for different shows. Some people like to watch TV at home and don't understand why others go to a studio. Why would someone get tickets, travel far, and sit for hours in a studio to watch something they can see at home? One idea is that people want to be on TV for a moment. I didn't believe this until I talked to Angela. She said she came because she might be on TV. Another idea is that people are curious to see behind the scenes. But many people said they came because a friend gave them a ticket. Not many of us have been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it's like. You sit with strangers, and someone shows signs that say APPLAUD or LAUGH, and you clap or laugh. This might be true for some shows, but not all. A studio manager said, 'We hope a show is good enough not to need these signs.' Is there a difference between being in a studio and watching at home? Claire thinks sitting in a studio is 'more exciting', and Charlotte liked being part of live TV. 'Last year I saw my favorite comedian. At home, you miss a lot.' I missed seeing live actors because I could only see the back of someone's head. The first scenes were so far away that I watched on a studio screen. Going to a studio might not be the best way to watch TV, but that's not the point. For most people, it was just fun and a free night out.'

**Bruce**  
I don't like places with no people. I like places with people. When I travel, I like villages with old buildings, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I rode my bike to a village called Lastingham. Riding my bike was fun and made me feel free. I liked to see the hills, valleys, and old villages. I am from Scotland, so the land looked the same but also different. I still visit there today. I wrote about my trips in a diary. That was my first try at writing about travel, which I became famous for later.
**Sophia**  
There is a small train that goes from Hythe to Dungeness. It is run by people who love trains. I always travel first class because it is not much more expensive. The view is not amazing. The train goes through Romney Marsh with sheep and next to a canal. But I like when the train goes through people's back gardens. We can see people doing things like making tea or washing dishes. I see myself as a woman in a small train looking into homes. I like the simple view of fields, sheep, and the sea. It makes me look closer to find something special.
**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a beautiful and quiet coast. The beaches are hard to get to and have many rocks, so not many people go there. Some brave surfers come, but most people like to look at the sea. The coast faces the Atlantic Ocean and is known for shipwrecks. There are walks along the coast and trips inland to valleys with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in simple places with a family in the village of Southole.
**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland. It is a big open area perfect for hiking. Not many people live or visit there. It is a quiet and empty place, and I like the space. I found it by accident when I was a student. Since then, I visit every year, sometimes alone, with my boyfriend, and now with my son. It has not changed much since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits special. It makes me sad that he is growing up in a city.
**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain. I wanted peace and to feel connected to my English roots. I grew up in Sri Lanka, but at twelve, I went to school in Devon, England. I used to ride my bike around the moors and village streets. We had a story about a place we never rode past: if you went down the driveway, you would never come back. That place was Glenthorne. It is my dream place. It is a quiet, hidden, and romantic house. You can only hear the sea, wind, and birds.

Title: ANIMAL ADVENTURE
We are a family who loves animals. One day, my daughter called me at work. She found a pine snake and asked, "Can we keep him?" I said, "Yes, but only for one night." We have a special tank for animals we find, so we can look at them and read about them in our nature book.
I came home late and started cooking. Suddenly, I heard my sons shouting, "Oh, Mother! Help!" I ran to their room. Our cat, Domino, had caught Bianca, a white mouse I got for Mother's Day. Domino was running around with the mouse in his mouth. I tried to catch Domino but tripped and fell.
While I was on the floor, I saw the snake escaping from its tank. The room was full of noise with the cat, mouse, kids, and even our dog barking. I quickly turned off the stove and went back to the room. I caught Domino by the tail and saved the mouse. The mouse was okay, and it lived a long life.
Next, I had to catch the snake. I sat on the floor and waited for it to calm down. Slowly, I picked up the snake and took it to the garden. I wanted it to go to a tree, but the snake wrapped around my shoulders like a scarf. My eldest child, DJ, said, "Mum, you're warm, and the shed isn't."
We all helped the snake move to the tree. It finally went up the wall and over the roof. As the snake's tail disappeared, my three-year-old, Clay, said, "Boy, that was one big snake!"

'Write me a letter! In our fast world of phones and computers, writing letters is disappearing. But for me, getting a letter is special. It is exciting to see who it is from and to read it. I have been writing letters for a long time. I started with little notes to my mother. She always made me write thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday presents. It didn't matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters. When I left home at 18 to study in London, I wrote letters every week to my mother, and she wrote back. Sometimes my father wrote too, and his letters were funny and long. The letters from home talked about everyday things. We also made phone calls, but I remember the letters more. I also got letters from boyfriends. Writing letters helped our relationships. I could say things in writing that were hard to say in person. I love letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but a letter with lots of news is better! I have friends who write to me from Sri Lanka, Australia, and Canada. I also have a friend in France. We met in a restaurant, and I asked for her address. Now we write to each other often. I can practice my French because she doesn't speak English. We have visited each other too. My biggest letter-writing success was this summer. My family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing for 29 years but never met. People were surprised that we wrote for so long. The local newspaper even wrote about it. I am happy my children also write letters. Like my mother, I make them write thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just like I did to my mother. She and my son have penfriends in Texas. I think it is important to keep writing letters. Don't let it become a 'lost art'.'

Title: Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art in France
In France, there are very old pictures on rocks in the French Alps. These pictures are about 4,000 years old. They show cows, fields, and gods. But now, these pictures are in danger because tourists are damaging them.
Many people visit this place, and some do not take care of the pictures. They write graffiti on them. Some tourists even step on the pictures or take pieces of rock home. Others rub the pictures to see them better, which makes them fade.
Experts are worried. Jean Clottes, an expert on rock art, says if this continues, the pictures will be gone in 50 years. Some people think the best way to protect the pictures is to stop tourists from visiting. Henry de Lumley, a museum director, thinks only guided tours should be allowed. But Jean Clottes disagrees because local people might not like this idea.
David Lavergne, an architect, also wants to keep the site open. He says it is hard to stop people from damaging the pictures because the area is big. He thinks maybe they should charge money to visit, but there is no money from the government to pay for guards.
Annie Echassoux, another expert, is worried because it is easier for tourists to get to the site now. She thinks they should block off the area and have guides. She says money must be found to protect the pictures because they are important for future generations.

Title: Climbing Walls
In the past, climbers went to mountains. Now, people can climb anywhere, inside or outside. At the World Cup Climbing Championships in Birmingham, a French climber named Francois Lombard is climbing on a wall. He is hanging upside down by his fingers. This event is at the National Indoor Arena, which is also known for the TV show Gladiators. Both events have a big wall.
Before the 1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs. In winter, they climbed in cold places like Scotland. But climbers needed to stay fit all year. So, they started using brick walls to practice. This helped them keep their fingers strong.
In the 1960s, sports centers began building special climbing walls. Don Robinson, a teacher, made a climbing wall at Leeds University. He used natural rock in concrete blocks. Many walls like this were built in the 1970s. But these walls had problems. They were only straight up and down, unlike real cliffs. Climbers got bored because the walls couldn't change.
In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny made a new material for climbing. It looked like real rock and could be put on any wall. Climbers could change the holds when they got bored. French companies also made panels with steel frames. These were lighter than concrete and could be moved easily. This gave climbers many new ways to climb.

'Do you want to be an actor? If you tell someone you want to be an actor, they will probably say it is 'risky'. Acting is a risky job because there are more actors than jobs. Some friends might say you are crazy, but others might think differently. Everyone will give you different advice. It is your choice, and you are responsible for your dream. There are no easy ways to become an actor. There are no exams to pass, and no guarantee you will get a job after training. It depends on luck and talent. There is always a need for new actors, and acting can be exciting and glamorous. Sometimes, it can also be rewarding. People often ask what talent is. I think it is natural skill and imagination. Imagination is hard to measure. Talent also needs courage and belief in what you do. Why do people want to act? It is hard to explain. In the theatre, the important thing is the connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is important in all acting. It is why actors love to act. If you ask actors how they succeed, they might not know. They know about their skills and others' skills, but they do not take success for granted. They know they are only as good as their current job, and fame might not last. Disappointment is a big problem for actors. Last month, you might have been out of work, selling clothes, or waitressing. Then, you get an audition, but you might not get the job. Actors do not talk about their chances. They find ways to handle the stress of auditions and rejection. Nobody likes being rejected. Remember, rejection can happen from the first time you try for a part. You are saying you are available, willing, and hopefully talented enough for the job. It is up to you because if you do not care enough, no one else will care for you.'
