Farmers took over green areas, and now three plants - wheat, rice, and maize - give us more than half of our food. This poor diet made people less healthy and shorter. In Ohio, scientists found that when people started growing corn, they became sick and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Farming spread because it could support more people, even if they were not well-fed. Only recently have richer countries started eating better again. In the US, the average man is now 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is good, but it also causes problems. Beds are still 190 cm long, and there is less leg-room in planes and trains. Clothes makers have to change their sizes. We cannot keep growing forever. There must be a limit. Robert Fogel from the University says it could be 193 cm, and we might reach it this century. But scientists say that while individuals are getting taller, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, people were rounder and taller to keep warm. As the climate got warmer, we became thinner and smaller. If the planet keeps getting hotter, we might get even smaller. So, global warming could make us shrink.'

**A New Life**
**The Farmer**
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London. Now, he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years, but it became boring. He lost his job suddenly and used the money he got to start the farm. He met a chef from a famous hotel, and now he sells meat to them and by mail. He is happy not to be in an office, but he still works long hours.
**The Painter**
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising. Now, he is an artist. Painting was his hobby, and he enjoyed it more than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. A career counselor helped him. Ron and his family moved to the north of England, where they didn't know anyone. They left their friends, but many friends visit them now.
**The Hat Maker**
Katherine Goodison was a lawyer. Now, she makes hats in her London flat. She liked her job as a lawyer, but the hours were too long. She didn't want to work more, so she left. People thought she would get bored, but she didn't. She likes having deadlines and being responsible for her work. She misses talking to colleagues but enjoys being in charge.
**The Masseur**
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years. Now, he is a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He started working in finance at 22 but didn't find it rewarding. He almost lost his job in 1989, so he quit and traveled for a year. He wanted to work in health, so he learned about massage. Now, he works part-time and feels in control of his life.

Title: A Childhood Game Becomes a Business
Two brothers, Dave and Norm Lagasse, are using a game from their childhood to start a business. They live in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA. The game they play is called pichenotte. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, brought the game from Quebec, Canada, to the USA. The family loved playing it on weekends and holidays.
The pichenotte board was made by their grandfather from old wooden food crates. Even after moving to New Mexico, the family continued to play. Visitors were curious because the game was not known in the southern USA.
Three years ago, Dave noticed the old board was damaged, so he made a new one. It was so nice that a relative and a friend wanted one too. The brothers took the board to a sports bar in Santa Fe. At first, people were not interested, but soon they loved playing it.
Dave researched the game's history. It started in India as 'carroms', then became 'squails' in Britain, and finally 'pichenotte' in Quebec, Canada. The game is for 2 to 4 players. Each player has 12 pieces or 'pucks' to flick into a hole for points. The game lasts about two minutes.
Seeing the game's popularity, the brothers made more boards and sold them at markets and fairs. They even started a championship with a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup'. The boards sold quickly, so the brothers decided to make pichenotte their full-time job. They set up a workshop in their garage and have made over 450 boards. Each board is made of birchwood and mahogany, weighs 12kg, and costs $595.
There are no professional pichenotte players or TV shows yet, but the brothers hope their business will grow. They dream of one day having a luxury car in their garage instead of wood and tools. Until then, they enjoy playing the game they love.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**
When you come to the Model Village, it is hard to believe that a few years ago, this place was just empty land with lots of wild plants. People thought it was useless land. But one man, with help from his wife, worked hard to make it beautiful. They moved a lot of soil and clay to change the flat land into the nice shapes you see now. Machines helped, but there was also a lot of hard work by hand. They brought in about 1,000 tonnes of good soil to make the grass, flowers, and rock gardens.
Many trees and bushes were planted. They had to choose plants that could live near the sea and in strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden shops, but some came from far places like Canada and New Zealand.
Colin Sims thought of the Model Village. He made over 100 models by himself over nine years, starting in 1972. The models are made from stone, concrete, special wood, and plastic to last in all weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts to learn about materials, but soon he became an expert too.
You will see that the models are all made to the same size scale, with lots of detail. This took patience and special building techniques. The Model Village is very popular because of its high quality. The building techniques are now used in other model villages in England and are taught in some schools.
The models show traditional British buildings. One of the best is the Manor House, a 13th-century stone building with a brick tower. You will also see a Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is new.
Please stay on the paths and do not touch the models. If you fall, it can take us a long time to fix the models. You can take photos from the paths. Dogs are welcome if they are on a short lead.
To enjoy your visit more, you can press buttons in front of some models to make them move. At the end of your visit, we would like to hear your thoughts. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us. Tell us if any models are not as good as the others. We are always fixing and updating them.
We hope you enjoy your visit and come back again. Please tell your friends about the Model Village.

'Every week, British tabloid newspapers show pictures that invade people's privacy. These pictures often break the rules that newspaper editors should follow. Sometimes pop stars pose for photographers, but this is not common. Usually, these pictures hurt famous people because they show private moments on the front page. However, not many people ask the Press Complaints Commission (PCC) for help. The PCC is an organization that deals with these problems. These pictures are rarely important for the public. For example, do private photos of pop stars help solve a crime? How did a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony help public safety? The actress was upset about these pictures before. She was in a hotel, a place where she should have privacy, so she had a reason to complain, but she didn't. The PCC did not investigate, which is surprising. They should also look into a recent story about a pop star's love life. The pop star, like the actress, did not complain. Shouldn't the PCC do something about these attacks? At first, this seems like a good idea. It would lead to many decisions against newspapers. Other newspapers and TV would talk about it. The public would not support the newspapers, and editors would stop publishing such pictures. Photographers would also be affected because they couldn't make money by hiding and taking pictures of celebrities. If the PCC acted like a 'police officer', there would be problems. How would it decide to start an investigation? Should it ask the victim to complain? And if the person still didn't want to, should it continue? Also, famous people might expect every story about them to be investigated and be upset if it wasn't. The job is too big. How could the PCC watch all British newspapers and magazines? There is also the embarrassment to think about. Even if someone's privacy is invaded, would they want more attention from an investigation? Most people probably want to forget and move on. Some might have other reasons to stay quiet. They might have a worse story they don't want the press to find out. So, even the PCC might seem like the enemy. A British comedian also had problems with the press. He and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon. He didn't complain then or later when his family was photographed on holiday. He was afraid the newspaper would show the pictures again with a new story about his anger. They might say it was just for fun and that, as a comedian, he should have a sense of humor. This fear is understandable. People think they will be targeted again if they challenge the tabloids. It is hard to find an easy solution to this big problem.'

Many people give advice to students who finish college and start their first job. This article talks about moving to a second job. We are not talking about people looking for a temporary job while searching for a permanent one. We are also not talking about people leaving a bad job in the first few weeks. We are talking about people who want to take a real step in their career. You have learned some skills and have an idea of what you want to do. What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. Do you want to focus on one area, move up to a higher position, or change to a different field? Whatever you choose, pick your second job carefully. You should plan to stay in it for two to three years. This job is important for your future career. It should help you grow and give you more responsibility. If you want to travel, now is a good time. You can do temporary work when you come back and then find your second job. Future employers will be happy to see you have traveled and are ready to focus on work. 
Juliette Davidson worked for three lawyers after leaving St. Aldate's College. It was a good first job because the people were supportive. She learned about office work and improved her computer skills. But there was no chance to move up. So, she quit, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year. Now, Juliette is a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. In two and a half years, Juliette has become more skilled, and her job has grown. Her boss wanted to help her develop. Her job title is the same, but her duties have changed. She started with typing and phone work and now does most of the letters and budgets. She also answers questions from company leaders and people who want to start a business. Brenda includes her in all her work and gives her special projects and events to organize.

Title: How to Be Confident
Confident people seem like they were always confident, but they learned it. Nina Hathway talks to five people about how they became confident.
A. Jenny
When I left school, I was very shy. At 25, I helped at my daughter's school. I thought I couldn't do it, but I did well. Someone suggested I go to university. I was nervous on my first day, but my confidence grew. Working at the school changed my life.
B. Michaela
Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to run the family business. I was scared and acted too aggressive. I learned that to be confident, you must believe in yourself. If work is too hard, I don't feel bad about finishing tasks the next day. When things are difficult, I remind myself I have nothing to lose. Fear makes you less confident, so I talk to myself to calm down.
C. Lisa
People think I'm confident, but I get scared. In TV, looking confident is important. Interviewing people showed me that everyone gets nervous. My mom once said, "Who's looking at you? Everyone worries about themselves." I remember this. You gain confidence by doing things that scare you. I was nervous for my driving test, but I passed. After that, I felt less scared.
D. Barbara
I enjoy my work, which makes me confident. I've built confidence over the years. If you learn from mistakes, you're more confident next time. I work hard and am liked at the restaurant, but not everyone likes me. I don't let it bother me. You should like yourself for who you are. My company has training courses that help my confidence. Setting small goals helps me see my progress.
E. Kim
After college, I worked as a secretary. I was scared to speak in meetings. I finally got the confidence to speak up. In politics, I was nervous speaking in public. I told myself, "People do this every day, so you can too." Writing notes helped me feel better. Everyone gets nervous speaking in public. The secret to confidence is telling yourself, "Nothing is impossible."

'Visit to Malaysia Paul Forster goes to a kite-flying festival and spends a night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled when I gave him his broken kite. 'You should keep it,' he said, 'it's a tradition - if the line breaks, the finder keeps it ... and I have many more.' He showed me a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All were 120cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and bamboo. We sat next to them under the trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, and watched Malaysia's biggest kite festival. In the middle of the beach were 10 platforms, where helpers held the kites, and a line of competitors waited for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered and the kites flew up like rockets. More than 500 men and boys joined the competition, which lasts five days every year. Each person entered four different kite designs, judged on decoration, stability, and flying ability. 'Flying kites isn't hard,' said Adnan, 'but making them needs real skill. Visit me at home and I'll show you how it's done.' I accepted his invitation. At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers in a big room. As it got dark, he asked me to come back the next day to help fix his kite, but I couldn't. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur, into mountains with thick rainforest. I took a wrong turn, and the road ended at a river. A boat was there to take people across. Nearby, a small sign said: 'Jelawang Jungle 3 km.' Before starting, I didn't know that most of the path was uphill, steep, and slippery. When I reached the track, I found a man with a flask of tea. This was Baba, who took care of a tented kitchen and some bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about insects under my thin mattress. The night was very dark, full of sounds. A waterfall roared nearby, and many creatures moved and made noises. In the morning, there was a great view of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First, the wind blew, then lightning hit the treetops. Soon, I was soaked. Sliding downhill, I wondered how the big butterflies avoided the rain. I also worried about my car being washed away and the chance of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, the car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the track. In Kota Bahru, Kelantan's capital, people asked me questions: 'Where are you from?' 'How old are you?' But they were very friendly. Kelantan is famous for its kites, but I remember it more for its kind people.'

**What kind of shopper are you?**
Everyone goes shopping, but we all shop differently. Do you know what kind of shopper you are? Abby Edwards asked some people:
**A. Melanie, 22, dancer**  
I love shopping! I spend a lot of money when I can. I can't walk past sale signs without buying something. My boyfriend is the same, so we shop together a lot. We are a shopping couple!
**B. Brenda, 40, office manager**  
I don't like shopping. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks. I take my kids, who are 6 and 14, to buy clothes, but I don't enjoy it because we like different things. I don't buy things for myself often, and when I do, I feel guilty. I don't tell my husband the real price because it sounds too much.
**C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager**  
I only shop for things I need. I don't like shopping and only go when I must. I know what I want and don't buy anything else. Shopping makes me tired, and I prefer doing other things.
**D. Anita, 35, TV producer**  
I like to look around sometimes, but I know what I want and where to find it. I shop quickly. I have some clothes I bought by mistake, so maybe I'm a careful shopper who sometimes makes mistakes.
**E. Lizzie, 41, secretary**  
I don't like shopping at all. I can't find what I want, and the shops are too noisy and messy. I don't shop for clothes often because people give me clothes. I do food shopping once a week and finish it quickly.
**F. Lisa, 22, actress**  
I am a happy shopper. I go shopping with my friends, and we often buy things. I don't look for anything special, but if I see something nice, I buy it.
**G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant**  
I am a careful shopper. I like shopping, but I don't buy much. I know what I want and don't spend too much. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but I feel worse if I spend too much.
**H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker**  
I love shopping, but not on busy days like Saturday. I am a careful shopper. I know what I want and look in different shops for the best price. I take a long time to shop.
**I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager**  
I don't like shopping. I work in the city, so shops are not interesting to me. When I shop, I don't try clothes on because it's too much work. Sometimes clothes don't fit, but I don't mind. I prefer making a few mistakes to spending a lot of time shopping.

'NEW CHANCES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE The Open University is like other universities and can give you a degree. But, you can keep working while you study. It can also help you find new hobbies. If you have never studied before, you will enjoy learning new things. You will meet many different people. Your degree might also help you get a new job. You do not go to the Open University for classes. You study at home using TV, radio, and computer programs. You can go to one class a month at an Open University center if you want. There are exams to take, just like in any university. If you want to know more, fill out the form below. It could be the start of a great new time in your life.'

**Gallery News**
**Easter Quiz for Children**
During the Easter holidays, children can join a fun quiz about surprises. You can get the free quiz sheets at the Orange Street entrance. Kids will look at 14 surprising paintings and answer questions about them. The quiz is available from 25 March to 9 April during normal gallery hours.
**New Picture**
The Gallery has a new painting by Dutch artist Jan van Os from the 18th century. It shows flowers and fruit in bright colors. The painting is big (89.1 cm x 71 cm) and is painted on wood. It was made in 1777 and 1778 because the artist waited for flowers to bloom in different seasons. Miss Violet Churchman gave this picture to the Gallery in memory of her sister Ida Nancy. You can see it in Room 25.
**Special Exhibition**
A special exhibition called 'Painting in Spain during the late 18th century' started on 15 March in the Sunley Room. The Gallery has new paintings by three Spanish artists: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu. The exhibition also includes works by Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italian artists, Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition is open until 31 May.
**Lecture News**
There are lectures every Wednesday about the special exhibition. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will talk about Melendez. On 12 April, Sarah Symmons will talk about Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will talk about Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists tell stories with their pictures.
**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**
The Gallery restaurant now has better service and more food choices. There are new kitchens, and you can enjoy hot and cold dishes at good prices.
**Information for Visitors**
Free guided tours of the Gallery happen every day at 11.00 am and 3.00 pm, except Sundays. These tours show some of the Gallery's best pictures and important European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

'Little Chefs
For one group of children aged between ten and fifteen, Saturdays are for learning how to cook. Their cooking classes are very popular, and 30 children are waiting to join. Parents pay £280 for the course where children can have fun and learn to make good food. 
Bill, who is ten years old, says, 'I love my mum's cooking, and now I can cook better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we eat the food we made together.' 
Flora is twelve, and she finds cutting onions difficult. 'I love cooking. I cooked a meal for ten friends, and they liked it. My mum said I should have a hobby instead of doing nothing at weekends. I liked staying at home, so I wasn't sure at first. But now I'm happy I came.'
Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, but the kitchen is not always tidy when they cook! As adults, we keep learning about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking when they are young, they will know how to cook for themselves when they leave home.''

The Outdoor Centre Fees are for a car with four people. Each extra person costs 50p. You pay the fees at the main office. The centre is not a private club. It is a place for everyone to enjoy outdoor sports and fun activities. If you are coming with a group, please tell the centre before you visit.
Windsurfing - One-day course Beginner windsurfing courses are on Saturdays and Sundays if the weather is nice. Learning to windsurf is very fun. You will remember the first time you sail on the water. We have boards with small sails for beginners. Course fee: £32.50 (includes all equipment)

All staff know First Aid and are trained to teach the activities. We make sure all children do activities that are right for their age and abilities. 'STAMP COLLECTING - A FUN HOBBY FOR EVERYONE Many people, young and old, enjoy collecting stamps. It is a fun and interesting hobby. Every year, more people start their own stamp collections. You can find stamps easily. You might get them from holiday postcards, birthday cards, or letters from friends. When you want to collect more stamps, you can join the Stamp Collectors' Club. This club helps you get new British stamps. As a member, you can choose special sets of new stamps for your collection. You can get these stamps in three ways. We can send you a complete set of stamps on an envelope with your address. Or, we can send you the same stamps in a colorful pack with interesting facts. If you like, we can send you the stamps to put in your own special book. The Stamp Collectors' Club has about 70,000 members. You can join too! It costs just £5 for two years. If you join with friends, you can pay less. When you join, you get a Starter Pack for free. This pack has 100 stamps and a nice box to keep them in. You also get a 4-page guide with tips on collecting and addresses of shops that sell stamps. Every two months, you get a club magazine. It has competitions, quizzes, and lets you exchange stamps with people around the world. Why not start this fun hobby? You will enjoy looking at the different stamps in your collection. Join the Stamp Collectors' Club today and have fun with stamp collecting. To join, fill out the form and send your fee. You will get your Starter Pack in 28 days.'

'MONEY What is money? Money is like a gram or a kilometre. But you can use money to buy things. For example, with five pounds, you can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or two cinema tickets. The five-pound note is just a piece of paper that is cheap to make. Long ago, people did not have money like we do now. There were no banks or shops. Mr. Green, the farmer, would trade his corn for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a trade between two people who had things the other wanted. Over time, people made their own 'currencies' to trade more easily. These currencies joined together, so now everyone uses a national currency.'

'Write a winning story! You could win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and have your story printed in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other lucky people will win £100. We are looking for people who can write good stories. The judges are Mary Littlejohn, a novelist, Michael Brown, a TV reporter, and Susan Hitchins, the editor of Keep Writing. They want interesting and original stories. Last year, detective stories were popular, but the winner wrote a love story. You can write about anything you like. Here is some advice: Write about what you know. This is important for every writer. Last year, many people wrote about love, family, and problems with friends. You need to make ordinary situations interesting. Make the reader want to keep reading by writing about ordinary things in a new way. Get your facts right. If you describe a town or explain how something works, make sure it is correct. Hold the reader's attention. Make the beginning interesting and the ending a surprise. Develop the story carefully and think of something unusual for the end. Think about the characters. Use good words to make the people in your story seem real. Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, and typed, double-spaced, on one side of each sheet of paper. We cannot accept stories by fax or email. You must include the application form with your story. We cannot return your story or discuss our decisions. You should not have had any fiction printed in any magazine or book in this country. The story must not have appeared in print or on radio or TV anywhere in the world. Your fee of £5 will go to the Writers' Association. Make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story. The closing date is 30 July, and we will tell the winner within one month. If you win, you must agree to have your story printed in our magazine.'

'THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST
Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. She was the first woman scientist to be in history books for many years. Hypatia's father was the director of Alexandria University. He made sure Hypatia got the best education. This was special because most women did not have many chances to study at that time. 
Hypatia studied in Athens and Rome. Then she went back to Alexandria and started teaching mathematics. She became famous for her new ideas. We do not have her books now, but we know she wrote important math books. Hypatia also liked technology and made some scientific tools for her work.
At that time, many rulers were scared of science, and people who worked in science were in danger. In March 415, Hypatia was attacked on the street and killed.'

**NENE VALLEY RAILWAY**
**About the Railway**
The Nene Valley Railway is 12 kilometers long. It goes through the beautiful Nene Park. The train starts in Peterborough and goes to Wansford, which is next to a big road. There is a 2-kilometer extension that takes passengers through Wansford Tunnel to Yarwell, the quiet end of the line.
**Ticket Prices:**
- Adult: £10.00
- Child: £5.00
- Family (up to 2 adults and 3 children): £25.00
- Special prices may apply on public holidays.
**Nene Park**
Nene Park is a great place for a family day out. It has golf courses and a large Caravan Club site. There are many hectares of parkland with boating lakes, picnic areas, and a nature reserve. There is also a small railway.
**Wansford**
Wansford Station has a special collection of old trains from Europe. You can see famous trains like the De Glen Compound from France and the German Class 52 Kriegslok, the largest working steam engine in Britain. You can visit these trains all year, even if the Nene Valley Railway is not running. The buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are open only when the train is running. There is an entrance fee of £2.00 for adults and £1.00 for children at Wansford.
**A Famous Railway**
Nene Valley Railway is popular with filmmakers because it can look like a railway from any part of Europe. The James Bond movie "Octopussy" was filmed here. Come and see where it was made.
**Services for Schools**
From May to July, the Railway has special services for school groups. Teachers can set projects for students to do at the railway or in the classroom. An educational pack is available for £1.50 plus postage. At other times, schools can hire the train called 'Teddy Bear' with up to 3 carriages on non-service days. Book one month in advance. There are special low fares for groups of 60 or more students. Call 01780 784444 for more information.
**Private Hire of Trains**
The Railway is a great place for family events or company visits. You can have a fun afternoon or evening with special programs, including buffet, bar, entertainment, and discos. For more information, contact the General Manager at Wansford Station.

Grass
Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are more than 9,000 different kinds of grass, and you can find them everywhere on Earth. Grass is the only flowering plant that can live in the very cold places like the Arctic and the Antarctic. Many animals live in grasslands, from small insects and birds to big animals like cows and lions. All these animals need grass in some way. Grass grows back quickly after it is cut or hurt. Unlike other plants, new grass leaves grow from below the ground, not from the top. This is why many animals can live in one place. When they eat all the grass, new grass starts to grow again, so they always have food.

Kal Kaur Rai is very interested in fashion. She just won the Young Achiever of the Year award at the Asian Business Awards. Since she was a child, Kal liked drawing clothes and making patterns. Her parents own a supermarket, and she never told them she wanted to make fashion her job. She thought they wanted her to work in a more traditional business, so she studied management at university. After university, she moved to London and worked in an advertising agency. She had to go to events but couldn't buy expensive clothes, so she made her own skirts and tops. Her friends liked her clothes and asked her to make some for them too. A small shop in London agreed to sell her clothes. They sold very well, and nothing was returned. This made Kal confident, so she left her job, took a PS20,000 loan, and started her own women's clothing brand. Kal's parents were not upset about her new career and said they would support her, which made her happy. Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business makes more than PS500,000. Her clothes are in fashion magazines, she designs for pop stars, and she just won an award. Kal feels very lucky. She says, "What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this."

SUNNINGDALE HOTEL
The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. Many people from all over the world have stayed here. In the last 80 years, over 50,000 guests from 174 countries have visited Sunningdale.
The hotel is on a main road that goes to the town center. It takes about 20 minutes by bus to get to the center. Buses to other parts of the town stop outside the hotel. Do not take buses with the blue sign "Express" because they do not stop near the hotel. There is an underground station less than 100 meters away.
The main building has 200 single rooms. Each room has hot and cold water. Showers, baths, and toilets are at the end of the corridors. The hotel has a shop, sitting rooms, four TV rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. There are also eight pianos for guests to use. You can park your car at the hotel. Free newspapers are available, and you can buy stamps at the office.
Guests staying for a long time must pay weekly in advance. You need to give one week's notice before leaving. Both short-term and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests get rooms first.
Meal times are: breakfast from 7 am to 9:30 am, lunch from 1 pm to 2 pm, and dinner from 5:30 pm to 7 pm. During the week, if you study or work late, you can ask for dinner until 11 pm by writing your name on the late list or calling before 7 pm. There are 10 menu choices for breakfast and dinner.
No animals or fires are allowed. Please keep noise down, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. If you arrive by train, it is best to take a taxi to the hotel because it is far from the main railway station.

'Tom Cruise Tom Cruise is a very famous actor in movies. But his life was not always easy. When he was a young boy, Tom was shy and had trouble making friends. He liked acting in school plays. After he finished high school, Tom went to New York to find a job. He worked as a porter and also went to drama classes. In 1980, a film director named Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, Tom was very successful and was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood. He earned millions of dollars for each movie. Today, Tom still acts in movies and is very popular with many fans from all over the world.'

'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? Bo the cat went into a big truck for furniture. She had a big adventure! The truck driver found her after driving more than 500 kilometers. It was a long day, and both the driver and Bo were hungry. He gave her some milk and tried to find her owner. He called his last customers, but no one lost a cat. It was late, so he took Bo home for the night. The next morning, he took her to an animal hospital. Bo's owner was looking for her too. After searching everywhere, he remembered the furniture truck that came to a neighbor's house. He remembered the company's name and called them. Soon, Bo was back home safely.'

'The Ghan Train Mark Ottaway traveled by train from Darwin, in the north of Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train goes across Australia, from the warm north to the colder south. It is often called the 'famous Ghan', but it is known for being late. People wanted a train from Darwin to Adelaide since the 1920s. They built a line from Adelaide to Alice Springs, but there was often flooding. A new line was finished a few months before my trip. The train can go up to 115 kph, but it is not a fast train. There are few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. The Ghan is not a luxury train like the Orient Express, but the food is very good. The railway was first built to carry goods, not people. It was thought that sending goods from Europe to Australia's south through Darwin and the train would save time and money. The Ghan says it is the world's first north-south railway. As I waited to get on the Ghan, I saw that everyone was excited. Most of the travelers were older Australians. Our first stop was at Katherine, where the train waited for four hours. Some people got off and took a boat trip. I left the train at Alice Springs and went on a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, so we just walked around it and watched the sunset. From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south, so many people stop here. After Alice Springs, the view from the train is not very interesting. There is a lot of flat land with cattle. On the third day, at dawn, we reached the hills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was over. The train might not have been as good as the advertisements said, but it took me to some of the most amazing places in Australia.'

'Climbing to the top of Britain Every year, many people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is in the north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first time on Ben Nevis. It was February, my first big winter climb. We went up the north side of the mountain to Tower Ridge. It is 600 meters high - maybe the longest climb in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are like big bowls in the mountain walls halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need them because the snow is very hard, like ice. Even though some people in our group were very experienced, we took all kinds of safety equipment, like lights to get attention, hard hats, and extra clothes. The weather forecast was good, with no strong winds, but we still felt nervous when we started. Ben Nevis in winter is always difficult. The path soon went up, and my legs felt tired. I was the weakest in the group, so I had to rest more often. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but when I reached them, they started again. I promised myself to train better before a climb next time. After 200 meters, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the path to the top of Ben Nevis. It is only one and a half meters wide, and the mountain drops hundreds of meters on each side. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on every step as we moved slowly. After seven hours, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, 48 kilometers away. But we were not lucky because there was mist. On Ben Nevis, going back down to camp can be as hard as going up. You need to read a map well because a wrong turn could lead to dangerous slopes in winter. I was happy we took turns to do that job. That first time, I only felt happy when I was safe in the tent. But at least I made it to the top.'

Anna's New School
This week has been very exciting because we moved to our new school building! The building is amazing. It is made of wood, like our old school, but it is also very good for the environment. It took a long time to build, and we watched it happen. It was exciting to see the builders work, but some nice open land is gone now. The building machines were very loud, and sometimes the builders had to stop because of the rain. We thought the building would never be finished.
Now, we have five big classrooms. They are much bigger than the ones in our old school, which was very old. We also have a room that people in the town can use for meetings. There is a nursery, a nice dining room, and big changing rooms. We will use them when our new sports field is ready.
When you come into the school, you will see there are no heaters! The heat comes from us - the children, the teachers, and the computers. The building keeps all the heat and sound inside. When we sing, it sounds like we are in a concert hall!
Another interesting thing is the tree on the roof! The builders put it there because it is a custom in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We visited it with our teacher yesterday. It moves very fast and is so big you can see it from far away! We took pictures to put on our website.
Even though we are using the new school, some parts are not finished yet. For example, we are doing a play for parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall for it. The new hall will be ready next year. We are very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we will learn faster here!

'No Title A month ago, I didn't know that I would be hanging 30 meters above the ground on a Saturday afternoon in November and enjoying it. Now, I looked down at the river far below me and understood why people love rock climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The place to stay wasn't great, but we had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be out of the city and in the fresh air. On Saturday morning, we met the other ten people in our group. Cameron came with two friends, Kevin and Simon, and sisters Carole and Lynn came with Amanda. We all came from different places, and none of us knew the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outside, but we didn't know exactly what we would do. Half of us went caving in the morning while the others went rock climbing, and then we switched at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of pushing, we finally got out. We were covered in mud but happy and excited about what we did.'

'Letter to the Newport Evening News On Saturday afternoon, I left my handbag on the bus. Inside, I had my cheque book, address book, and my purse with about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized I forgot it, it was too late. I didn't know what to do. I'm 72 years old, far from home, and I was very worried. I stood by the road and cried. A young man asked me what was wrong, and I told him. He gave me some money for the bus fare home. When I told the bus driver, he said I should keep the fare. I got home safely, and soon the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the bus company. He said they found my handbag and offered to bring it back to me. I got my handbag back with everything inside. I want to say thank you to everyone who helped me that day. I really appreciate their kindness and honesty. Mrs. B. James, Newport'

'Sharks Sharks are some of the scariest animals in the ocean. They are good at finding food because they can see very well and feel movement with special lines on their bodies. This makes sharks dangerous for smaller sea animals that they eat. Sharks are like other fish in some ways, but their bodies are different. For example, most sharks need to swim all the time to breathe and stay alive, so they almost never sleep. Also, if you turn a shark over on its back, it can stop moving. This helps scientists who study sharks. It lets them learn more about these interesting animals.'
