'Joining the Kirov Ballet
I'm Nathalie. Last year, I joined the Kirov's ballet school in St Petersburg, Russia. I was one of the youngest foreign students. At my first ballet class, I was nervous because I didn't know anyone. Everyone asked me questions in Russian. I tried to speak Russian, and then they spoke English, so we could talk. Now, six months later, everyone is nice to me. My Russian is much better, and I understand my teachers. 
For the first two weeks, my mum stayed with me. When she left, I was a bit sad. One night, I called home because I felt lonely. The classes in Russia are harder than in England. I eat a lot to have enough energy. This helps me perform well. In the evenings, I watch my favorite films on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before the film ends. Now, I feel at home here. I like walking around the city and visiting shops, even in December when it was very cold. I bought a fur hat because it was minus 10°C, but the Russians said it was not very cold for that time of year! My room is warm and cozy.
We are preparing for a new show, and there is a competition for young dancers. I will enter the competition. I feel very lucky to be here.'

'THE ICEHOTEL For many years, people liked to visit the Arctic in the summer to see the midnight sun. But in winter, only a few people lived there with the snow and ice. In the late 1980s, people thought the cold winter could be a good thing. In the winter of 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit had an art show in a special igloo (a house made of snow) in a small town called Jukkasjarvi on the frozen Torne River. This place, called Arctic Hall, brought many visitors. One night, some visitors decided to sleep in the Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were happy with their night, and the idea of an ice hotel started. Today, the ICEHOTEL is famous around the world. When winter starts, snow builders, architects, and artists from everywhere come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel for that year. When one part is ready, it opens to visitors and guests, while other parts are still being built. The first part is ready in December, and each week a new part opens until January 7th when the hotel is finished. The ICEHOTEL is built outside with natural winter materials, so the finish date can change because of the weather. In spring, when it gets warmer, the hotel melts. Inside the hotel, the temperature is always between -5°C and -8°C, even if it is colder outside. Warm clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves are included in the hotel stay. Guests should also bring sweaters, a scarf, and many wool socks. Shoes should be bigger than normal to fit thick socks. If you plan to visit, you can buy warm clothes and socks on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these when you book your visit, and they will be in your room when you arrive. The hotel is in Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. You can take a bus from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.'

'Shopping for furniture A report by Dave Worthington Homestyle is a new furniture shop. It had to close soon after it opened at midnight last Thursday. About 6,000 people came to the shop. There were many special offers, like a leather sofa for £45 (only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (only between 3 am and 8 am). The shop's normal hours will be 9 am to 9 pm every day. But Homestyle said it would stay open for 24 hours on the first day. However, it had to close in just half an hour. A police officer said: 'We knew many people would come, but they were not patient. The shop was full, so the managers closed the doors. People outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold before they could go in. They did not want to wait quietly. Also, many cars were trying to get to the car park. Some people left their cars in the road and walked to the shop. This blocked the road.' One customer, Jenny Smith, got into the shop. She said: 'I waited for three hours and didn't have time to buy what I wanted. But the staff were calm and explained the situation. It wasn't safe, so they had to close. I will come back when they open again, but I don't want to wait in line again.'

**Membership**
The Short Story Society helps writers in Britain. It started in 1899 and is very active today.
**Society Magazines**
We have great magazines. One is the Short Story Review, with stories by top British writers and new writers. Another is Short Story News, with writer interviews and information about events and competitions. You can read some articles on our website.
**National Short Story Competition**
We have a big competition called the National Short Story Competition. It is for people aged 18 and over. You can write about any topic. Stories should be 1,000 to 1,500 words long. Members enter for free; non-members pay £5. The competition is from April to October. The ten best stories are in our annual book. The winner gets a contract to publish their own stories.
**Education**
For almost thirty years, we have helped writers in schools. We have a project called Young Writer of the Year for ages 11-18. Winners get book prizes and can join a five-day course with professional writers.
**The Writers' Cafe**
The Writers' Cafe is the social place for the Society. It has vegetarian food, coffee, and drinks. You can read our magazines there. The Cafe has exhibitions, short courses, and readings every month. It is in the center of London and is open from 11:00 am to 10:00 pm Monday to Friday, and 11:00 am to 8:00 pm on Saturday. Members get discounts on some products and events.
**Becoming a Member**
We have members all over the world. Anyone aged 18 or over can join. If you want to join The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a form.

'Free-diving in the Caribbean Tanya Streeter is very good at free-diving. Free-diving is a sport where people dive deep into the ocean with just one breath. Tanya holds four world records in this sport. In 2003, she became the first person to dive 120 meters deep and come back up without help. Before that, she used a balloon to help her come up. This time, she held her breath for over three and a half minutes. She was the first woman to break a man's world record in any sport. Fourteen safety divers watched her dive to make sure she was safe. Some people think free-diving is too dangerous, but Tanya says safety and training are very important. Tanya trains a lot. She spends most of her time training on land, in the gym. She also trains in the pool and the ocean. She uses an exercise bike to make her heart strong. She does not run because she wants to protect her knees. Instead, she walks fast to stay fit. When she practices diving, she travels away from home. She does fourteen dives in four weeks, with a rest day after each dive. Rest is important so she does not get too tired. When Tanya is not training, she talks to people about sports products and helps environmental groups. She grew up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman and loved swimming and exploring rock pools as a child. She says her life now is like her childhood dreams. Tanya is famous in some countries, so people listen to her about the environment. Tanya is in her thirties and wants to keep breaking her own records. She started free-diving at twenty-five and does not want to stop for many years.'

CARTOON FILMS
Cartoon films can show many things. If you can draw it, you can make it move on the screen. New ideas and computer programs make cartoons fun for everyone again. In the late 1970s, people thought cartoons were only for kids. But then, some directors had new ideas. They showed that both adults and kids could enjoy cartoons. Not all cartoon films were good. For example, The Black Cauldron did not do well. It was too scary for kids and too simple for adults. Directors learned from this, and film companies started making a lot of money again.

Title: 'Caroline Benson Talks About Her First TV Role'
Caroline Benson is a new TV star. She talks about her first TV role. She says, "I never thought I would spend my first year at university filming The Finnegans. I only acted at school before, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother said I was like Polly Finnegan, and I always wanted to play her. 
Before university, I took a year off to travel. When I was in Chile, my mother emailed me. She said they wanted to make the book into a TV show. I knew I had to try for the part. My mother was surprised, but she sent my photo to the director. She convinced him to meet me. I flew back and got the part. 
Filming started a week after university began, so I got permission to be away for three weeks. When I returned to university, I woke up at 6:00 am to write the essays I missed. I didn't tell my university friends, but they found out and thought it was great. It was an amazing experience, and I feel very lucky. 
After university, I want to be an actress. My family is not in acting, but my grandfather was an opera singer. I tried for other TV roles but haven't got any offers yet. I don't know how I did everything because I also had a busy social life. When filming ended, I didn't know what to do. I have been in two college plays since then. I haven't been home much, and now my first year at university is over. I'm going to Greece for the summer with friends."

'No Title When I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, I just wanted to make enough money to take care of my children. Today, 'The Body Shop' is a big company growing all over the world. Since we started, I have learned many things. I share what I learned in this book because I think our company has important ideas about running a business. This book is not a normal business book, and it is not just about my life. The main idea is that to be successful in business, you need to be different. Business can be fun, it can be done with love, and it can help people. In business, like in life, I want to enjoy myself, feel like part of a family, and be excited by new things. I want the people who work for 'The Body Shop' to feel the same way. Now, this book shares my ideas with everyone. I believe there are no limits to our 'family' and no limits to what we can do. I think that is exciting, and I hope you do, too.'

'A TRIP ON THE BEAUTIFUL DOURO RIVER
JULES VERNE offers a 'hotel ship' trip on the Douro river in Portugal. The ship, MV Lady Ivy May, can take 160 guests. Each room has a window, a private shower, and a toilet. The ship has air-conditioning, a sun-deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.
Trip Plan
Day 1: Leave London Heathrow in the early evening and fly to Oporto. A guide will meet you and take you to the Lady Ivy May to sleep.
Day 2: In the morning, see the sights in Oporto. Then return to the ship and travel to Entre-os-Rios. This part of the trip takes four hours.
Day 3: Continue up the river. In the early evening, stop at Peso da Regua, where port wine is made. Enjoy local food and drink at dinner.
Day 4: After breakfast, take a bus to the old town of Lamego. Visit the cathedral, some churches, and a museum. The museum was once a palace and has many paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. Return to the ship and sail to Tua.
Day 5: The Douro river becomes narrow here. If the river is deep enough, you can take a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. Return to Tua by coach and see many sights along the way.
Day 6: In the morning, drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for a great view of the Douro valley. Return to the ship for lunch. Then take a train ride through the countryside to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting.
Day 7: Visit Vila Real, then return to the ship for lunch. Travel down the river to Oporto and sleep on the Lady Ivy May.
Day 8: Arrive in Oporto with time for sightseeing and shopping before flying back to London Heathrow.'

HONEY
Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It has water and sugars. Bees travel very far, up to seventy-five thousand kilometers, and visit over two million flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The color and taste of honey depend on the flowers the bees visit. There are more than three hundred types of honey. Lighter-colored honey usually tastes milder than darker honey.
In ancient times, honey was the main sweet food because sugar was very rare. Honey was very valuable to the ancient Egyptians, who used it as money. Today, honey is made and eaten all over the world. Research says it can help with tiredness and make athletes perform better. Honey is not just food - it can help with sore throats and is used in many skin and hair-care products.

Norwich is a city in East Anglia, a part of Britain. People have lived there for more than two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. By 1066, it was one of the largest towns in England. Norwich has two cathedrals and a mosque, making it a popular place for different religions. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and recently celebrated its 900th birthday. In 1994, Norwich celebrated 800 years since it became a city with a Royal Charter, which means it could govern itself.
Today, Norwich is smaller than cities like London or Manchester, with about 150,000 people. But in the 16th century, it was the second biggest city in England. It grew for 300 years and became rich, known for having many churches and pubs. Now, there are fewer churches and pubs, but in 1964, the University of East Anglia was built there. Norwich has many students and is a modern business center, especially for insurance services. The city has many entertainment options like theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, cafes, restaurants, and arts centers. Norwich also has a football team called 'The Canaries', with green and yellow colors.
A new shopping center called 'The Castle Mall' is a big attraction in Norwich. Builders made a large hole in the city for over two years to build it. They moved a lot of earth to make a park on the roof of the Mall, with water pools and trees. People in Norwich are happy that the old market is still there, next to the new shopping center. Both places are popular, showing that Norwich has a good mix of old and new things.

The Albuquerque Balloon Festival
Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a city in the south-western United States, becomes full of bright colors. This is because of the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, a nine-day event every year. The first festival was in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. There were about twelve hot-air balloons, and they took off from a car park in the middle of Albuquerque. Now, the festival is much bigger. This year, at least a thousand balloons from many countries will be at the festival, which is now outside the city.
What to see
The pilots talk to each other by radio and light up their balloons at the same time. This is called a 'balloon glow' and is great for taking photos. You need to arrive just after it gets dark or before 5:30 am to see the balloons glow in the dark sky. During the day, you can walk around the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready to fly. The balloons are different sizes and colors, and some look like animals, cartoon characters, or famous products like soft drinks and fast food. Kids will really enjoy it.
In the afternoon, you can go on a balloon ride over the desert with one of the many companies offering flights. Another option is to take a cable car from the desert to the top of the nearby mountains. This is the longest cable car ride anywhere, and you can see the festival from above. There are many other things to do for visitors of all ages, like balloon races and fireworks on the first and last three nights of the festival.
The Albuquerque Box
This is a special wind pattern that is perfect for balloonists. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentle winds at different heights. This helps skilled pilots control where their balloons go by going up or down.
Practical advice
Buy your tickets online before you go to avoid long lines. Wear several layers of thin clothes. It can be cool at night and in the early morning, but during the day, you need sunglasses and sunscreen. Bring a flashlight for night events and, of course, bring your camera. If you use a film camera, you will need high-speed film for evening and night pictures.

The Eden Project
The Eden Project is in the south-west of England. It is a very popular place for tourists to visit in the UK. When you first see it, the big 'biospheres' look like something from a science-fiction movie. Each biosphere has a different climate. This shows visitors how important the connection between people and plants is. It is surprising to see how many things we use every day come from plants, like wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate. There are over 135,000 different types of plants here. Even if it is cold outside, electric heaters keep the plants warm. In the Rainforest Zone, it is always wet because of a big waterfall. Another zone is like the environment in the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa. There are also plans to make a desert zone soon.

'No Title Some people have said they don't like this year's book, New Writing 3, but I don't know why. It has 500 pages of new writing for only £6.99, which is great! Most of the book is fiction, with parts of novels and short stories. There are fun stories by famous writers like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. It's interesting that the less famous writers mostly wrote about food. Be careful with Jane Harris's Those Nails - don't read it after eating because it has some scenes that might make you feel sick! There are also poems by nineteen poets, including R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. You can read parts of novels being written by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. There is a little non-fiction too, like a funny article by Alan Rusbridger about newspapers and a special piece by Ursula Owen about herself. This is a great collection, and I am excited to see what next year's book will have.'

"The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six," says Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher. "This is when you are learning about the world." Margaret lives in London and likes to teach children who are three or four years old, but she also teaches some five-year-olds who are very interested. She started teaching the violin in 1972, and her first class was with her children's five-year-old friends. Margaret's students have group lessons. Each group has about twelve students, and each lesson is one hour long, every two weeks. Also, each student has one private lesson with her every week. Parents must come to the classes too. It is important for parents to be interested in the lessons. From the first lessons, students learn to play by listening. They do not try to read music until they have been playing for several years. For a long time, there is a big difference between how they play and how they read music. Margaret says her method is not meant to make great violinists. She suggests that students who do very well should leave and study the violin with more traditional methods.

'Moonshine The band Moonshine released their third CD last week. 'Here Again' is the new CD after 'The Waves'. There are some changes since the last CD. Tom Wilcott is now playing bass guitar instead of Simon McVee, who left the band last year. Tom Simpson is the new drummer. The first song on the CD is a dance song, showing the band is not focusing on slow songs anymore. The second song is also a dance song and is even louder. Most of the other songs are in the band's usual slow style. These two dance songs will surprise many fans. They could become hit singles because they are very good. Singer Rob Letchford sings perfectly on these songs. Fans should be happy he recorded them before he had problems with his throat. Because of this, the band had to cancel their next tour. (People who bought tickets do not need to worry because all the concerts will be rescheduled when Rob is better.) On this CD, Moonshine shows they can make great music in different styles, from slow songs to ones that make you want to dance. I think the best songs are at the beginning, and the last few songs are not as good. Despite this, 'Here Again' will probably be a big hit and bring more success to the band.'

San Francisco
San Francisco is a city on the coast of northern California. The first Europeans to find the area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola. He saw it for the first time in 1769. Even though San Francisco Bay is a great natural harbor, it was found by people traveling on land, not by sea. In 1849, many people came to San Francisco hoping to find gold. But it was not the gold seekers who became rich. The richest people made money by owning banks and law firms. They built big houses on a hill called Nob Hill. Today, tourists visit San Francisco to see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Many also take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to see the old prison.

'SAMUEL PEPYS Samuel Pepys wrote the most famous diary in English. His diary tells us about life in England from 1660 to 1669. Pepys writes about big news stories, like disease, enemy ships on the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about himself, like when he slept in church or looked at pretty girls. He talks about his home life, like a fight with his wife and how they made up, and his worry when she was sick. Pepys liked books, music, the theatre, card games, and parties with good food and fun. He was a busy man with many important jobs. He was a Member of Parliament and President of the Royal Society. He is also known for his work with the British Navy.'

'The History of Shoes In the past, people did not care if shoes were comfortable or fashionable. Early shoes were probably made from animal skins. People tied them around their ankles when it was cold. We still use leather today, but we also use other materials like silk, plastic, or cotton, depending on what is popular. About one hundred and fifty years ago, people started wearing different shoes on each foot. Before that, both shoes were straight and could be worn on either foot. All shoes used to be made by hand. Now, most shoes are made by machines in big factories. Sewing machines helped make many shoes quickly and cheaply for more people.'

'THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH In the 1880s, people found gold in Alaska, the most northern state of the USA. Many people went there to find gold and become rich. New towns were built quickly. One town was called Iditarod, which means 'far, distant place'. In 1909, Iditarod grew very fast and became the largest city in Alaska for a short time. In summer, boats could bring important things to these towns. But in winter, the rivers and ocean froze, so boats could not travel. In 1910, a winter path was made for teams of dogs pulling sleds. They carried mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. This path was called the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for a team of dogs to travel across Alaska. They stopped at 'roadhouses' where the drivers could sleep and eat, and feed their dogs. The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes started to be used instead of boats and dog teams. But in 1925, the dogs were needed again when a disease called diphtheria hit the city of Nome. The medicine to cure the disease was in Anchorage, far away. Airplanes were new, and people were not sure if they could fly in the cold. Also, the best pilot, Carl Eielson, was not there. So, they decided to use dog teams to bring the medicine. The trip was over 1,000 kilometers, mostly on the Iditarod Trail. It took twenty teams six days to finish the journey. Leonhard Seppala, a man from Norway who came to Alaska for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers. He trusted his dog Togo to find the way in the snow, and Togo was a good guide. The last part of the trip was done by Gunnar Kaasen, who had worked with dog teams in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Balto. At one point, Balto stopped and saved the team from falling into icy water. The diphtheria was stopped, and Balto became a hero. Today, a dog sled race happens every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the 1925 journey. It is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.'

'Sweden's Ice Hotel The village of Jukkasjarvi is in Swedish Lapland. In winter, it can be very cold, sometimes -40°C. But 6,000 people visit every year to see a very special hotel. In this hotel, you eat, drink, and sleep in rooms made of ice. You can even get married there if you want. The bar is also made of ice, so you should not put hot drinks on it! The bedrooms are about -4°C, but guests get special sleeping bags to stay warm. You can also get warm clothes if you need them. The hotel is rebuilt every winter because it melts in summer. To build it, they use 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow.'

Maria Mutola
In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl playing football in a team with boys in Mozambique. "We won," she said. "At first, no one thought it was a problem that I was a girl. But then the team we beat complained." A local newspaper wrote about this, and a man named Jose Craveirinha, who helped other African athletes, heard about Maria. He went to see her and saw her playing football. He noticed she was very fast. "He talked to me about running. I didn't know what he meant because I only knew football. Then he bought me running shoes and took me to train. It was very hard, and my legs hurt a lot."
Jose talked to Maria's parents and told them she could be successful and help their family. They agreed to let her go with him to train. In 1991, Maria finally went to train in the United States. She didn't want to go before because she would miss her family. Her life was different from the girls she met in the US. She said, "They were good athletes, but I worried about my parents having enough food, while they worried about dresses and make-up. They didn't know much about me or my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were great, and I learned a lot."
Today, Maria still runs and lives happily in South Africa with her mother for most of the year.

The Skywalk
The Grand Canyon is in the United States. The River Colorado made the Grand Canyon. People visit the Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and look at the view. The view is very beautiful, and the Skywalk makes it even better. The Skywalk is 1219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform with glass walls and floor, so you can see the rocks below. Up to 120 people can stand on it at the same time. It opened in 2007, and many people have visited it since then. You must wear special covers on your shoes to keep the glass clean. Walking on the Skywalk feels like you are a bird flying high in the sky.

'THE ROCKIES The Rocky Mountains are a long group of mountains in North America. They start in the northwest and go down to the center of the continent. The Rockies are smaller than the Alps, but they are still very beautiful. There are many roads in the Rockies, but the best way to see them is by train. You can start your trip in Vancouver, a very nice city in Canada. Vancouver is close to the water and the mountains. People can ski just 15 minutes by car from the city center. In the past, thirty trains left Vancouver every day to go across the continent. Now, there are only three trains a week, but the trip is still exciting. You can sleep on the train, which is fun, but you will miss some of the beautiful views at night.'

'ZOOS People started keeping animals in zoos over 3,000 years ago. The rulers of China had a big zoo called the Gardens of Intelligence. In the past, animals in zoos did tricks for visitors. Now, animals in zoos do not perform. People go to zoos to see animals acting naturally. Today, most cities have a zoo or wildlife park. Some people like zoos because they help us learn about animals and see them up close. Without zoos, this would be hard. But some people do not like zoos. They think it is wrong to keep animals in cages. They also say that in some zoos, animals live in dirty places and eat bad food.'

'JAZZ By Katie Atkins, aged 14 I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from other local high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different clothes. My band wore black school uniforms, but some bands wore bright T-shirts. We didn't look like adult professional bands, but we were used to playing in competitions. The music was really good, especially because we are all young. Players from each band even made new tunes on stage. It was exciting to watch, but even better when my band played! We have a great jazz band at my school, but not everyone can join. Only about half of the people who want to play get in. But anyone who wants to play can come to jazz practice before school. We also spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning about it. There are trips to jazz summer camps around the country. I've been to a few and learned a lot. Adults are often surprised that young people like jazz. My music teacher thinks it's because pop music is not hard enough for people like me who love music. I find jazz exciting because it is both new and old. You can make your own music, but you also feel part of its history, like the great jazz players before you. My school is lucky because we have great teachers and parents who help us. Without them, we couldn't do well with our music!'

'Watering the Desert In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain anytime from November to March. It doesn't rain often, and when it does, the city's water pipes can't handle the sudden floods. The streets become like rivers. But because many winters have been dry recently, people are happy when it rains. Marrakesh's parks and gardens are not green because of the rain. They are green because of underground channels made in the 11th century. These channels bring water from the mountains all year. Dry places that get water this way are called oases. If you travel further south from Marrakesh, you reach Skoura. Here, people use every piece of land to grow food. They make small squares with water channels. The Atlas mountains, covered in snow in winter, are a beautiful background.'

Gareth Ellis is 13 years old. He is the youngest son of Alan and Kath. Alan is an engineer, and Kath is a nursery teacher. Gareth has older brothers who work in banking and computers. But Gareth always wanted to be a clown. 
Three years ago, Alan lost his job. So, Alan, Kath, and Gareth joined the circus. Kath says, 'People laugh when we tell them, but it's true. Gareth wanted to be a clown since he was three years old when we took him to the circus.'
Alan and Kath found jobs in a famous circus, and Gareth started training to be a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus in the summer and go home in the winter. Gareth's brothers take care of the house when they are away.
Kath says, 'It wasn't easy. We had to think and organize a lot. We only had a car and a small caravan to sleep in, and we left our nice house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths.'
Gareth says, 'People ask about my education. But wherever we go, someone always comes to teach me. I use the same books as my classmates at school, and I have a computer. I have never fallen behind.'
And what about the future? Kath says, 'It was a hard decision, but it was the only way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I'm happy it's working, and we enjoy it.' Gareth says, 'I want to be the main clown in a circus one day, maybe Bippo's circus.'

Eight-eighteen News
Eight-eighteen News is a news group for young people. Our members are between 8 and 18 years old. We collect news and write reports, stories, and articles. We send these to big newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, and websites. If newspapers or TV and radio stations like our stories, you can read or listen to them on the Eight-eighteen website.
We have three places in the country where young people can meet and work on projects. We want to open more places soon. Our news group started in 1994 and was called 'Young News' then. More than 2,500 young people have been members. Sophie was one of them. She says: 'I first heard about Eight-eighteen when they talked to me for an article about young people's thoughts on hip hop music. I was surprised by the chances they had. Age didn't matter; they could do stories by themselves. I went to the Eight-eighteen center in my city, got some training, and stayed a member until I was 18. Eight-eighteen helped me do more than I thought I could. With the skills I learned, I got a job at 19. Now, I am the youngest worker at a big news website, checking articles before they go online.'
Get involved at every level
When you join Eight-eighteen, you will get training and join monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen helps members share skills. 'Peer trainers' are members who are 12 years old and older. They teach new members basic journalism skills. As they get better, some members give talks to young people and adults outside Eight-eighteen, like in youth clubs and summer camps. Older staff always help these young trainers on trips.
Eight-eighteen News has training sessions for new members three times a year. Our next training is in February. If you or someone you know wants to join, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen program is good for children with all levels of reading and writing skills. Membership is free, and there is no test to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**
Welcome to our website. Here is what you need to know before booking a flight.
**About the Flight:**
- **When:** We fly during the short Antarctic summer. We take tourists from Sydney, Australia, over Antarctica, and back.
- **Flight Dates:** Dates for next year are not set yet. If you book now, you can change the date if needed.
**Frequently Asked Questions:**
- **How long is the flight?** The flight is about 12 hours. After four hours, we see sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours over Antarctica. On the way, experts talk about the environment and history. You can see what the pilot sees through a camera.
- **Will I get a window seat?** You get two boarding passes. Halfway through the flight, you change seats. Business and first class have a window seat for half the flight. Economy class has a window or next-to-window seat for half the flight. Over Antarctica, you can move around to see better. The pilot flies in a way that lets everyone see the sights.
- **What if the weather is bad?** We have 17 different flight plans. The captain chooses the best one for clear views on the morning of the flight.
- **Will I see penguins and other wildlife?** Most wildlife is too far below the plane to see. We do not land in Antarctica to protect the environment. To see wildlife, you need a boat tour.
- **Can I take photographs?** Yes! You can bring your camera. We also have fun photo opportunities with Antarctic clothes.

'Little Chefs
For one group of children aged between ten and fifteen, Saturdays are for learning how to cook. Their cooking classes are very popular, and 30 children are waiting to join. Parents pay £280 for the course where children can have fun and learn to make good food. Bill, who is ten years old, says, 'I love my mum's cooking, and now I can cook better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we eat the food we made together.' Flora is twelve, and she finds cutting onions difficult. 'I love cooking. I cooked a meal for ten friends, and they liked it. My mum said I should have a hobby instead of doing nothing at weekends. I liked staying at home, so I wasn't sure at first. But now I'm happy I came.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children listen and remember better than adults, but the kitchen is not always tidy when they cook! As adults, we keep learning about food. If parents teach their children to cook when they are young, they can make food for themselves when they grow up and leave home.''

'Winter Driving Winter can be dangerous because it is hard to know what will happen, and accidents can happen easily. Fog can be at the top of a hill. Ice can be under the melting snow and can make you slide off the road. The car coming towards you might slide across the road. Rule Number One for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. Quick movements can make a car hard to control. So when you turn the wheel, touch the brakes, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee next to you. Drive so you don't spill it. Rule Number Two is to watch what might happen. The more ice there is, the further you need to look down the road. Test how long it takes to stop by braking gently. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. In general, allow double your normal stopping distance when the road is wet, three times this distance on snow, and even more on ice. Try to stay in control of your car at all times to avoid trouble.'

Craigie Aitchison was a painter from Scotland. He moved to London to study law, but he decided to go to art school instead. At art school, he found drawing classes hard, but he kept painting. When he was in his late twenties, the Italian government gave him money to study art in Italy. He liked early Italian artists, and you can see this in his work. He loved the green and brown colors of the Italian fields and the bright light there. He wanted to show this light in his paintings. He painted colors in thin layers, from light to dark, but he says he never knows how it will look in the end. He says, 'It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start by painting yellow, knowing I'm going to put anything on top.' Aitchison makes it sound easy. 'Anyone can do the colors - you can buy them. I just notice what colors go next to each other.' He does not make drawings before he starts a painting because he thinks he might get bored and not finish the painting. Instead, he changes his paintings many times before they are done. He likes models who do not ask to see their pictures while he is painting them. 'If I feel they're worried and want to look at the painting, I can't do it.' Since he moved to London, he does not feel part of the Scottish painting scene. He says he does not want to follow any tradition, but just paints the way he can. However, his work still influences young British painters.

'Rock Band Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a set of drums for his birthday. At first, we did not want to buy them because of the noise. 'It's better than watching TV or playing computer games in my free time,' Ben said, 'and it will keep me out of trouble.' In the end, we agreed. 'Okay,' we said, 'but you must think about the rest of the family and the neighbors when you play.' That was just the start. Because drums are hard to move, the other members of Ben's band started coming to our home with their guitars and other equipment. So, for several hours a week, the house is full of the sound of their instruments and their singing. At least Ben's hobby has been good for our health: whenever the band starts playing, my husband and I go out for a long walk. And I must say that, although their music sounds a little strange, they are a friendly and polite group of young men. I cannot say if they are good musicians - after all, I didn't expect my parents to like the same music as I did when I was a teenager - but they do play regularly in local clubs for young people. Our main worry is that they won't spend enough time on their school work because of their music, though this hasn't happened yet. I always tell Ben how important his studies are. But one thing is certain - Ben was right: it has kept him out of trouble and he is never bored.'

Atlantic College
Last week, I visited Atlantic College. It is a very good private school in Wales. This school is special because it helps young people learn about life outside the classroom. Students can also study for their exams there. The students are between 16 and 18 years old and come from all over the world. In the morning, they study. In the afternoon, they do useful activities. They might help on a farm, take care of people with learning difficulties, or check rivers for pollution.
Atlantic College students come from many different countries and social backgrounds. The school fees are PS20,000 for two years, but many students get help to pay. A quarter of the students are from Britain, and many of them get help from the government to attend.
Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands, said, "I really admire the college for trying to help young people understand each other." She also said, "You learn to live with people and respect them, even if you don't like them. During the summer holidays, my mother saw that I argued less with my sister."
In conclusion, Atlantic College gives students a great education with methods that really work.

'Being an older student I am 32 years old and I have just finished my first year at university. I go to lectures often, and I have learned to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. I worked as a secretary and made good money, but I was bored because I did not have to think much. I felt sad because I thought I would stay in that job forever. I was jealous of the students at the local university. They looked happy and full of hope, and I wanted to be like them. Now that I am a student, it is hard to make friends with younger students. They often think I am a teacher and ask me questions I cannot answer. I also feel different from the teachers because, even though we are the same age, they know much more than I do. But I am happy to study because I know I need a qualification to get a good job, which is very important to me. Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I like spending weekends with my books more than going to parties. There are also good things about being a student, like long holidays and discounts for theatre and cinema. I sometimes worry about what I will do after university, but I hope going back to school was a good decision.'

Henry Ford
Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863, but he did not like farming. When he was fifteen, he started working as a mechanic. In 1893, he made his first car. After driving it for 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and made two bigger cars. In 1903, he started the Ford Motor Company. He used strong but light steel to make cheap cars for ordinary people. In 1908, he made the first Ford Model 'T', which cost $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars every day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was worth $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and cheap, but this sometimes meant less choice. Henry Ford said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it's black."
